PETITION.TITLE: Superannuation Schemes
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:

That we consider the 2 per cent discounting of Commonwealth Occupational Superannuation Scheme pension adjustments on 10 October 1986 to be a serious breach of trust by the Government. The Commonwealth has reneged on an established commitment as incorporated in Commonwealth legislation and benefit promise pensions are not being paid in full. In particular we resent the long-term effect of the discounting. The pension loss is compounded throughout the life of a pensioner and surviving dependants-into the 21st century for many. We consider this Government-induced penalty to be out of all proportion to the short-term ``extraordinary circumstances of the economy'' given as the reason for the discounting.
Your Petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, should urge the Government to:

1. limit the pension discounting effect of the Superannuation and other Benefits Legislation Amendment Act 1986 to the period 10 October 1986 to 1 July 1987 so that pensions are restored to the 9 October 1986 level as a base for the 1987 pension adjustment; and
2. consult with organisations representing pensioners before changing the terms of conditions of Commonwealth Occupational Superannuation Schemes.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Referral to Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Amendment Bill 1986 be referred to the Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs for inquiry and report.

On 26 February 1986 the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Amendment Bill was passed by the House of Representatives. It was introduced into the Senate on 17 March 1987 but has not yet been given a second reading. According to the second reading speech, this Bill is designed to make some fine-tuning amendments to the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act 1977. This description is moot. It is arguable that the amendments it makes will substantially change the spirit of the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act. It is because of this doubt that I have moved for the reference of the matter to the Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs.

To clarify the focus of the inquiry that I propose, I shall detail some of the history of the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act. The Administrative Decisions Judicial Review Act 1977 was enacted with the intention of providing a relatively simple means of obtaining a judicial review of administrative action. The Act seeks to balance the desire to provide individuals with a means of obtaining judicial review of administrative action, on the one hand, with the need to protect public authorities from unwarranted or vexatious litigation, on the other. It provides for the establishment and operation of the Administrative Review Council, which is required to monitor the operation of the Commonwealth system of administrative law. In June 1983 the Administrative Review Council commenced a major examination of the operation of the Act. The first stage of this examination was completed with the presentation to the Commonwealth Attorney-General of a report entitled `Report of the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act 1977 Stage 1' on 13 August 1986. That report was tabled in the Senate on 25 November, 1986.

The Administrative Review Council's report dealt with alleged abuses of the Act, which it described as being `those proceedings which are designed to delay or frustrate Commonwealth Administration (in a broad sense) merely in order to gain a tactical advantage rather than to establish a genuine legal right or interest'. The Review Council found little evidence of such abuses. However, the report recommended that the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act should be amended in order to avert the possibility of abuse. Specifically, the report recommended that the Federal Court of Australia should be granted a statutory power to stay proceedings or refuse to grant an application under the Act where that court considers it inappropriate to grant the application or to continue to hear the proceedings. One factor which is to be considered by the Federal Court is the availability of an alternative avenue of review. The amendment seeks to redress the problem identified by the Administrative Review Council by strengthening the court's discretion under the Act to refuse to grant an application for review or, where there is provision in another law, for review of the relevant decision by a tribunal, authority or person. It also seeks to discourage the disruption of administrative proceedings by narrowing the scope for resort to the Act during those proceedings where legislative provision exists for the review of the decision complained of at the conclusion of those proceedings.

The New South Wales Council for Civil Liberties has argued that the amendment `is designed to curtail and destroy the rights of persons adversely affected by administrative decisions to challenge them'. In a letter the Council pointed to additional technicality, further possibilities for delay and increased costs on applicants as being major problems. The Administrative Review Council has simply noted that, in some respects, the Bill goes further than the Council recommended in its report. Accordingly, I believe that the Bill should receive some additional consideration before it is debated in the Senate. In speaking to this motion, I emphasise my belief that the Committee's inquiry should be confined precisely to the effect of this amendment-that is to say, the Committee should consider exclusively the question of whether there should be a requirement for leave as a condition precedent to making an application for review under the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act where alternative avenues of appeal exist. This being so, the Committee should be able to report in August of this year.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government will be opposing the motion to send the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Amendment Bill 1986 to the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs. I understand that the Bill is not entirely based on the Administrative Review Council report. That may be a cause for concern. I think these matters can be adequately dealt with in this chamber in both the second reading debate and the Committee stage. There will be an adequate opportunity for an understanding to develop within the chamber sufficient for honourable senators to make the necessary decisions during the second reading debate and the Committee stage, if there should be one. I do not think it requires a series of hearings, the summoning of witnesses, the taking of submissions and the preparation of a report by the Constitutional and Legal Affairs Committee to inform and prepare honourable senators adequately for a vote. That would obviously be the reason for the Committee undertaking such a reference. The Government takes the view that it is not necessary.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Amendment Bill 1986 has been considered at quite some length by the Australian Democrats. Prior to Senator Alston moving the motion to send it to the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs, we had determined that we would be opposing this Bill when it came on for a vote. We seek to oppose this Bill for a fairly long list of reasons. We do not believe it is as it is purported to be in the explanatory memorandum to the second reading speech which was incorporated in Hansard. We do not believe it is merely a tidying up operation. We believe it goes much further than that. Hence, we signal that we are opposed to the legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: It becomes somewhat difficult to make a judgment as to whether the reference to a committee is useful. However, we have not yet been able to ascertain from the Opposition parties their attitude to this Bill. On that basis we believe that if the Bill were to come on for a vote it could very well be passed. That is the complete opposite of our intention. Hence, we indicate that on that ground at least we would accept the reference to the Committee in the hope that the added material which is uncovered in the Committee's inquiry would be sufficient to convince the Opposition parties to vote against this Bill.

The difficulty with the reference to the Committee is that this Committee, as with all other committees of the Senate, is already overcommitted in terms of its work load. The amount of time available between now and the Budget session is not only limited but will also get progressively shorter and shorter and the sitting of the Senate is likely to extend into July.

TALK.START.PARA: —Fancy telling us that.

—The discussions this morning have indicated that we will probably need a second up week, probably the week beginning 14 June. It will not have escaped the notice of honourable senators that at the end of today's business we will have had three days in the last two weeks in which no Government business has been discussed at all. We have not even got to Government business, so the indications certainly are that if the Senate is to complete even those Bills which have a deadline on them-the Sugar Cane Levy Bill 1987, for example, which we must get through--
—That is a Queenslander speaking!
—I am not unmindful of the State from which I come. Obviously, looking at the Bills which have deadlines on them, the Senate will need to sit until the end of June.
—Which June?

—I have been asked which June. In terms of the business which we have to get through by the beginning of July, it is obvious we will have to sit till the end of June. I presume that the Government will also require some of the other legislation that does not have a deadline on it. It is fairly obvious, if one looks at the proposed Budget session sittings, that the Government will have limited time to get its legislation through in that session. Hence, if honourable senators wish to discuss at great length a whole range of other matters-and this is our primary role, of course-we will have to sit until July. I think there are great difficulties for the Committee if it is to meet and work on this Bill. I imagine that the Committee and its Chairman will be able to fill us in on these matters. I imagine that the Chairman will be able to indicate that this particular reference will probably be at the bottom of the Committee's list and could very well not be discussed for a long time.

SPEECH.PARA: The Australian Democrats are opposed to this Bill, so this delay does not concern us a great deal. We are not concerned about when the Committee is able, in the fullness of time, to get around to this reference. We imagine that that will be a considerable time down the track and thus this piece of legislation is unlikely to be dealt with again. If that is the case, it would fit in with our intention-that is, to vote against this Bill at the second reading stage. We believe that the Bill takes away significant rights of citizens on appeal and that is unacceptable. We believe that the legislation proposed here will make a significant inroad into citizens' rights of appeal and therefore we cannot support it. For those reasons we will support this reference, not because we believe that ultimately it will lead to an informed debate in this place. I think that the length of time that it will take for the Bill to be considered by the Committee will mean that we will not see it again this session and that it is unlikely that we will see it in the Budget session either. For those reasons we support the reference to the Committee.

calls on the Presiding Officers of the Tasmanian Parliament to immediately take such action as is necessary to reconvene the Joint Sitting of the Houses of the Tasmanian Parliament to fill the vacancy in order that representation of the people of Tasmania in this place be in accordance with their constitutional entitlement, and calls on those members of the Tasmanian House of Assembly and Legislative Council, including members of the Gray Government, who have to date acted contrary to the established convention, to vote at such a Joint Sitting to accept the nominated ALP candidate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the few minutes during which I spoke on this motion before the adjournment last night, I pointed out that the Senate on 19 March had endorsed the principle that a person chosen to fill a vacant place in accordance with section 15 of the Constitution should be a member of the political party duly nominated by that Party to fill that place. That was passed with the unamimous support of all parties in the Senate. On behalf of the Opposition I expressed clear support for that principle. The further event that has occurred since 19 March is the decision at the Joint Sitting of the Tasmanian Parliament on 8 May, which refused to adopt the nominated Australian Labor Party candidate, Mr Devereux, to fill the vacancy caused by the resignation of former Senator Grimes. On that same day the Leader of the Opposition, Mr Howard stated:

SPEECH.PARA: I believe that the person appointed to fill casual vacancies of this kind ought to be the person nominated by the retiring Senator's political party.

It has been perfectly clear for some time where we in this place stand on this issue. One wonders what is the point of this matter being raised again by the Government when it has an enormous amount of business on the Notice Paper, to the extent that the Senate will probably be sitting well into the winter recess. We are constantly being told by the Manager of Government Business in the Senate (Senator Gareth Evans) that time is being wasted by the Opposition, yet the Government has brought forward yet another motion on an issue about which we are all agreed.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are not all agreed.

—We are all agreed in this chamber on this matter, and yesterday the motion was supported overwhelmingly in the House of Representatives, yet here we are debating the same issue again. The only addition in the motion is the proposal that the Senate calls on the:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . Presiding Officers of the Tasmanian Parliament to immediately take such action as is necessary to reconvene the Joint Sitting of the Houses of the Tasmanian Parliament . . . and calls on those members of the Tasmanian House of Assembly and Legislative Council . . . who have to date acted contrary to the established convention, to vote at such a Joint Sitting to accept the nominated ALP candidate.

If Senator Tate and others want to pass this motion, the Opposition will not oppose it. We wonder what possible good it will do. The Tasmanian Parliament has been well aware of the views of the Senate and of the Opposition in this place since 19 March. The Tasmanian Joint Sitting was comprised of a lot of pretty robust Independents who know what they are doing.

TALK.START.PARA: —So-called Independents.

—Whether they can be properly described as Independents may be challenged, but it makes no difference. They know what they are doing; they have taken this step clearly with their eyes open. We may not agree with it and may well believe they are mistaken, but I think that we are deluding ourselves if we think that by passing this motion we will have any influence whatever on the people who sat on 8 May and who took that decision with their eyes fully open after the most extensive public debate on this issue. It was not as though it had merely been debated in this place or had been the subject of comment by Mr Howard or anyone else; in recent months there has been the most extensive public debate. The Press has been absolutely and utterly fascinated with this subject, as if it were one of the major subjects that this nation had to deal with.
—It should be as far as the Tasmanians are concerned as they are the ones who are underrepresented in this place.

—As far as the representation in this place of Tasmanians is concerned-I think I heard Senator Tate being asked a question on this matter on AM-the Opposition has, since the time of the resignation of Senator Grimes, granted a pair. We have offered a pair and we will continue to offer a pair for as long as this vacancy is not filled. We have made it perfectly clear that we disapprove of the action taken by the Tasmanian Parliament in its joint sitting and the views that have been expressed by Mr Gray and so on. But this motion attempts to take up a vast amount of time of this Parliament, both in another place and here. We are continually debating this issue when Tasmania's proportional representation is not disturbed in the Senate, because of the Opposition's decision to continue granting a pair. The Government suggests that Tasmania is in some great state of loss of representation because one of its people is absent when it already has 11 senators and five members of the House of Representatives. For heaven's sake, the amount of travel that honourable senators engage in and the amount of time that States are not represented in this chamber because honourable senators are travelling all around the world on one trip or another make it a ridiculous argument to say that because Tasmania is one person down in the Senate for a time Tasmania's representation is sadly lacking along the lines that we have heard from Senator Tate. If that is the case, senators ought not to travel when the Senate is sitting. That argument is pretty weak. I think I can best sum up Senator Tate's motion and proposals with a quotation from Macbeth. When poor old Macbeth had learnt about the death of his wife he was given to a very emotional soliloquy in the course of which he said:

SPEECH.PARA: Life is but a walking shadow; a poor player
That struts and frets his hour upon the stage,
And then is heard no more: it is a tale
Told by an idiot, full of sound and fury,
Signifying nothing-

Really that is all that this additional motion moved by Senator Tate amounts to. I gave my reasons in the debate on 19 March. I do not propose to make another speech about whether this matter concerns a constitutional convention. We will not allow ourselves to be diverted or fussed about whether, in this quite pointless exercise, we use the term `convention' or `practice' or whatever. The fact is that we agree with what the motion is basically all about. We have agreed with it ever since this debate started. We agreed with it on 19 March and we agree with it again. We will not be diverted, as I have said, by these fulminations about what the Tasmanian Parliament ought to do. There seems to be no reason why we should not express that view, for the little good that it may do.

But if we are to be in the business of making these sorts of statements, surely to goodness we ought to add to the motion the real cause of this problem; namely, the attitude of this Hawke Government, from day one after its election, to the people of Tasmania and their interests. Therefore I propose to move an addition to this motion by way of amendment. I move:

At end of motion, add ``, calls on the Federal Government to maintain and preserve the traditional and Constitutional division of powers between the Federal Government and the State Governments and, in particular, calls on the Federal Government not to use the external affairs power for the purposes of intervening in the affairs of the States''.

Seeking to destroy the traditional balance under the Constitution between Federal and State powers has been a major feature of the Hawke Government. It started to do it, of course, in relation to the Franklin Dam. It has continually pursued this policy, particularly in relation to the Northern Territory which, although it may not be a State, is on the road to statehood. It has repeated this action in relation to the Lemonthyme and Southern Forests issue.

These policies and actions of the Hawke Government-particularly recently, in relation to the Lemonthyme logging issue-have been strongly opposed by the Labor Leader of the Opposition in Tasmania, Mr Batt. They have been opposed by employees in the Tasmanian logging industry and by many other people whose jobs are being threatened by this course of action. They have been opposed by the Australian Council of Trade Unions because it sees the reality of the threat to employment in Tasmania as a result of the policies that the Hawke Government has pursued.

It has pursued from day one a policy of confrontation, in particular with the Premier of Tasmania and his Government. One of the first things it did was to send F111 aeroplanes over Tasmania-the infamous spy flights-to take photographs of what was happening in the area in which it was proposed to build the Franklin Dam. That is one of the most provocative acts that any Minister in any Federal government has ever taken in relation to the States. It met with the greatest outrage, not only in Tasmania but all around Australia. Indeed, the action of the then Attorney-General, Senator Evans, has met with such continuing condemnation and derision all around Australia that one has only to talk about spy flights these days and everybody in Australia knows what one is talking about. That was a classic act of totally unnecessary confrontation towards Tasmania, the Government of Tasmania and Mr Gray. Since the Lemonthyme legislation-a most provocative Act-has been passed and proclaimed, the Government has not sent the Royal Australian Air Force to spy on what is happening in the Lemonthyme, but it has chartered aircraft to fly over the area to find out what is going on.

The actions and the legislation of the Government have been challenged by the Tasmanian Government. The matter ought to be decided in the High Court of Australia. That is the proper way of deciding it. It ought not to be decided by this confrontationist approach. There was a suggestion by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) the other day that the Government may cut funds to Tasmania as a punishment for its action in not accepting the nomination of Mr Devereux. In light of those provocations and confrontations in relation to Tasmania, it is not surprising-it may be wrong, but it is not surprising-that Mr Gray, his Government and his supporters in the Tasmanian Parliament have taken the stance that they have.

People, instead of getting themselves into a great stir about this matter in this chamber and elsewhere, should ask themselves-particularly those opposite should ask themselves-why Mr Gray behaved in the way he did. Provocation has always been a defence available under the law. It ought to be understood and examined. Some sympathy ought to be expressed for this behaviour, as it occurred as a result of such confrontation. The Opposition will not be in the business of condemning Mr Gray. We disagree with him. We believe that he has done the wrong thing. We have said that over and over again. But he has been provoked. All the fulminations that we have had again from Senator Tate and all the sound and fury that we now have in respect of this motion signify absolutely nothing. If the Government is really genuine about losing one Tasmanian from the 12 Tasmanian senators, without expressing any worry when honourable senators from any other State or even from Tasmania go off on junkets around the world at the taxpayers' expense, it should examine its own conscience and see why Mr Gray and his Ministers have behaved in the way they have.

We are going to be asked yet again to debate and vote upon an issue on which our position has been made perfectly clear from the beginning. There is absolutely no doubt that we will continue to maintain that position in the future. Under the Constitution this is a matter where clearly the legal power resides with the Tasmanian Parliament. If the Government disagrees with that, it can take action in the High Court. From what the Attorney-General, Mr Lionel Bowen, has been saying, I do not think it will take that action. The Attorney-General delivered one of his classic statements when he said that he thought the Government may go close to winning in the High Court. The Government does not need to be told that it is no good going close to winning in courts. One either wins or loses. It is clear that the Government knows it would lose. It is not going to take any legal action because the constitutional position, the legal position, is crystal clear-that is, that Tasmania is within its constitutional rights in taking the attitude it has taken, even though it may be contrary to constitutional convention. I do not believe it is a convention, but that is another matter. But we believe that Mr Gray ought to act on the nomination of the ALP in replacing Senator Grimes.

The Constitution was amended in 1977 as a result of legislation which went through this Parliament. Lest there be, as there has been, some talk that there was some omission or mistake in the constitutional provision, I just want to quote what was said in this chamber by the present Leader of the Government in the Senate, Senator Button, in his speech on the Constitution Alteration (Senate Casual Vacancies) Bill 1977. That Bill was brought into this chamber by me, representing the Attorney-General at the time, on 25 February 1977. That proposal was supported by the then Opposition, of which Senator Button was then a leading member. I do not think he was actually the Leader of it, but he was a leading member and he handled this Bill on behalf of the Opposition on 25 February 1977. This is what Senator Button had to say about that constitutional alteration:
There are a number of details in this proposal on which we might offer some criticism.
Incidentally, he did not proceed to offer such criticism or any criticism. He went on:

The fact of the matter is that it is in substance the provision which was approved of by the Constitutional Convention. There is a slight difference. It is in substance the proposal which was approved of by the Joint Committee on Constitutional Review of 1959, although that Committee did not see the way in which it could be carried out. It is a necessary amendment to the Constitution and one which we believe will receive the approval of the Australian people, having regard to the conduct of State governments in recent years. I commend the proposal to the Senate. It will have the full support of the Opposition.

That was the agreed position on which the present section 15 of the Constitution, as it now stands, was based. It was based upon a decision of this Parliament-House of Representatives and the Senate-and was supported without qualification by the then Opposition, for which Senator Button was speaking. Let us not hear any more nonsense about there being mistakes, omissions, failures or whatever in the constitutional provision. The Government's predecessors fully supported the proposal that is now in the Constitution. Do not let us have Government members coming in here and saying that there were mistakes in it and all the rest of it. They supported it at the time and it was and is a sensible proposal. But it does leave the final say to the State governments. If we want to change that, there will have to be another constitutional amendment. The fact of the matter is that Mr Gray and his colleagues in the Tasmanian State Parliament have acted within their constitutional rights. As I said, the Attorney-General of the Hawke Government is prepared to say only: `We would go close to winning a constitutional challenge'. He knows that that is the legal position. I repeat that the Opposition supports the principle that--

SPEECH.PARA: The question is raised about procedure. If the amendment in 1977 was worded as it was and if the procedure was intended to work as we assert that it should, why were the State parliaments still given a role under that amendment? Senator Durack raised some words of Senator Button in 1977, saying that the Labor Party fully supported the amendment but omitting to say that Senator Button said that we would have some criticisms of the proposal.

TALK.START.PARA: —I did not quote that. I said that he didn't provide any criticism.

—That is right-but he said that there would be criticisms. He did not actually go on to explain what those criticisms were. I want to deal with the legitimate question of why the constitutional amendment of 1977, which apparently gives State parliaments the right to make the decision, was not worded differently. Mr Gray says that if the State Parliament is given the right to meet and decide about filling a casual vacancy it should be able to use that right and not be just a rubber stamp. The point is that the State Parliament's role is to be not much more than that. Its importance is to supervise compliance with the formalities. Of course we cannot just have a situation where the Labor Party branch in Tasmania puts out a Press statement saying that John Devereux is its appointee and then he becomes a senator. There has to be some procedure to be gone through, and that is the role for the State Parliament.
—What if the person was disqualified?

—Exactly. If he is not over 18 or is not a citizen, the State Parliament would not be complying with its duty if it rubber stamped his appointment. That is the extent of its role. It is not to interfere in the internal affairs of the Australian Labor Party in determining its candidate. If all the formalities are in order, the State Parliament should approve the nomination. The reason that the State parliaments were given a role in the 1977 amendment, as in the Constitution at the beginning of 1901, is basically that the States would have been offended if their traditional role in the Senate process were removed. Of course the Labor Party went along with it at the time. It was the best that we could get. We would have had a great outcry, unnecessarily, from the conservatives in this country if we had tried to say that the State parliaments should have been bypassed. The State parliaments should have been able to be trusted in their supervisory role. The terms of the amendment-which were not drafted by us, but we went along with them because that was our only option-pander to the anachronistic concept about the Senate being a States House. The terms of the Constitution as it stands maintain that fiction. Of course, fictions are often the basis for so much of our system, and we accept that. That is the answer to Senator Durack about our attitude to the 1977 amendment.
—So you did it deliberately? You left that in deliberately?

—We have to accept lots of things in this world which are not perfect. If I had been drafting that amendment I would have made it clearer, but it was a Fraser Government amendment with its tortuous wording to provide a mechanism intended to ensure that the nomination of the party concerned was accepted.
—You could have moved an amendment, but you left that as it was.
—We were in opposition at the time, Senator Walters, you may remember.
—Order! I would appreciate it if Senator Coates were to address his remarks through me.

—I apologise, Mr Acting Deputy President. I am being provoked once again by Senator Walters. The Australian Labor Party accepted the wording proposed at the time by the Fraser Government. There was no real option. We accepted-perhaps foolishly-that all State parliaments, following the crisis of 1975, would in future accept the conventions of the Constitution. A question has been raised as to whether the decision of the State Parliament is unconstitutional or whether it is acting totally within its powers. I would like to quote briefly from a comment by a senior lecturer in law at the University of Tasmania, Michael Stokes, who asserts that it is actually unconstitutional. In an article in the Mercury last Saturday he said:

SPEECH.PARA: The decision of State Parliament not to elect Mr Devereux to the Senate is unconstitutional.
This is because the Constitution does not allow a State Parliament the option of not filling a vacancy.

Section 15 of the Constitution clearly indicates that it would be unconstitutional for a State Parliament to adopt any procedure for filling a Senate vacancy which could result in no senator being chosen.

This is because the primary obligation which that section imposes on a State Parliament is to choose a replacement. The crucial words of the section are `. . . Houses of Parliament . . . shall choose a person to hold the place until the expiration of the term'.
Mr Stokes goes on:

These words impose a clear obligation to choose a senator. The use of the word `shall' rather than `may' shows that the provision must be obeyed and does not allow a State Parliament to refuse to appoint a sen- ator . . .

He goes on to explain about the time scale because the constitutional amendment does not say that it shall do so within a particular time; it just says that it `shall'. All the other words of the Constitution suggest that time is of the essence because it points out that if the State parliament in question is not in session the Governor shall appoint a nominee in the meantime-that is, on the advice of the State government-and if that procedure takes place the State parliament is given only 14 days either to confirm that appointment or to do otherwise. Those time limits indicate that it is not a matter that can be left. As it stands, if nothing happens between now and 30 June next year when the term of former Senator Grimes ends, Tasmania will have suffered a reduction in representation and an unbalancing of the electors' wishes for 15 months, not for just the four or six weeks or so which is normal in these cases while the necessary party and parliamentary procedures are gone through. The Constitution says `shall', and a short period for those procedures is quite clearly envisaged.

It is important that this motion, which calls on the Presiding Officers in Tasmania to act, should be carried unanimously-without any dissent at all from anybody on the other side of this chamber. The way the Presiding Officers have acted so far they are complices; they share the guilt for not upholding the convention because they voted on this matter. It is the Presiding Officers, above all, who should ensure that proper parliamentary procedures and convention are followed in this matter. The 1977 amendments give recognition to the fact that the most important division in Federal politics is that between the major parties, not amongst the States. I referred before to how the Constitution in its wording maintains that fiction, but it has other fictions as well. As you know, Mr Acting Deputy President, the Constitution does not refer to Prime Ministers or Cabinets or anything like that. All of those procedures are understood and not spelt out. This is another example of that sort of thing.

The point which needs to be emphasised and which has to be pushed with Mr Gray is that John Devereux is and will be the only nominee of the Australian Labor Party. In some ways I envy John Devereux. He is already known nationally. His is a household name. The Devereux affair will go down in history. His library file in this place is already pretty thick. However, he has had to put up with a lot of appalling abuse, not just from Mr Gray but also from a lot of other people, including the so-called Independents in the Legislative Council in Tasmania. As shown on Friday, any other pretenders to the vacancy will suffer immediate expulsion. They will be expelling themselves-there is not any real need for action by the Party, but it has been confirmed-and so be ineligible under the Constitution. That is why the 1977 Fraser amendment was worded as it was. It is the clear intention of the 1977 amendment. It is in the terms of the amendment, in the terms of the Yes case circulated, and in the terms of the second reading debate in the House of Representatives and the Senate. Mr Gray should respect the wishes of the Labor voting people in Tasmania, as represented by our five quotas in this place.

As Senator Tate said in his contribution last night, senators are not delegates of State parliaments or State governments, and Mr Gray is wrong in his attempt to dictate how a Tasmanian Labor senator should be chosen or should behave. He has very little support in this matter around the country, including from the conservative Press, even in Tasmania. It is the political expediency of his actions which has outraged and dismayed Australians. He has hopelessly confused-the Opposition with its amendment today is trying to do the same-an issue, forestry, with the fundamental functioning of Australian society. Forestry is an important issue.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is because they cannot see the wood for the trees.

—That comment could be made. Forestry is an emotional issue. Mr Gray's attempts to keep that issue on the front page of the Tasmanian papers means that he is refusing to accept the Labor Party's nominee, and that is unforgivable. It has been reported that Mr Gray had another motive in refusing to accept John Devereux as the Australian Labor Party's nominee, that is to exploit the legitimate divisions within the Australian Labor Party over the forestry issue. I suppose that was the childish point that Senator Watson was making when he asked us why we did not want a secret ballot. Mr Gray, to his annoyance and, I assume, that of the Opposition, has not succeeded on this count because the unity and solidarity of the Australian Labor Party in the face of an outrageous conservative attack has seen to that. However, Mr Gray has succeeded in increasing the already public divisions within his own party, the Liberal Party of Australia. Senator Chaney initially said that he thought Mr Gray was within his rights to refuse the Australian Labor Party's nominee, then he changed his mind. I have already dealt with Senator Archer's attitude on this matter. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: If there are special reasons why Mr Gray does not like the ALP nominee-
does not like!-
he has every right to reject that nomination.

Thus, the personal whim of an erratic State Premier is to decide how the Senate will be constituted. Senator Archer supports him and other members of the Opposition have not been particularly strong in disagreeing with him. This gives a very clear indication of how the conservatives, in contradiction to that term, are willing to cast aside their beloved democratic institutions, such as State parliaments, Constitutions, High Courts and Senates, when they feel embattled by their political opponents.

John Howard has further revealed that he deserves no credibility at all as Leader of the Opposition. He is unable to persuade Mr Gray to soften his position and so far he has failed to speak out strongly against the violence that Mr Gray is perpetrating on the Constitution. Mr Sinclair apparently showed enough courage to speak out strongly on this matter by saying that it was a stupidity, but when we looked more closely at what he said we saw that he had called Mr Gray's action `a political stupidity', not a constitutional stupidity. Obviously he thought Mr Gray's action would damage his cause. Once again, his contribution in the House of Representatives yesterday was hardly strong support for the motion.

The people of Australia clearly indicated in 1977 that they did not want casual vacancies in the Senate to cause crises. Mr Gray is ignoring the overwhelming wishes of the Australian people. The amendment to the Constitution at that time was carried by a huge margin, which is very unusual for constitutional change in Australia. Mr Gray may be a State Premier-for the time being only-but even in that position he cannot and should not dictate to the Australian Labor Party who its nominee for this vacancy should be. Under the Constitution he is required to ensure that the State Parliament, in its supervisory role of the procedures, provides a replacement for Don Grimes's vacancy and that that replacement should be the Australian Labor Party's choice.

Australia has had enough of the reprehensible power play of this politician in Tasmania. It is not his role to involve himself in the internal affairs of the Australian Labor Party any more than we should interfere in the internal procedures of the Liberal Party, the National Party, the Australian Democrats or any other party that seeks to come to this place. We have a legitimate right to expect the State Parliament to review its appalling decision of last Friday, and that is the reason for this motion. It is not just an expression of opinion, as the March decision was; it is a formal request from this chamber to the Presiding Officers of the Tasmanian Parliament to do the right thing.

DEBATE.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN INSTITUTE OF HEALTH BILL 1987[COGNATE BILL:NATIONAL HEALTH AMENDMENT BILL 1987]

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 11 May, on motion by Senator Gareth Evans:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The House is debating cognately the Australian Institute of Health Bill and the National Health Amendment Bill. I shall concentrate on the Australian Institute of Health Bill, because the National Health Amendment Bill merely points to the Government's lack of control in the field of expenditure. The purpose of the Australian Institute of Health Bill is to set up a new statutory authority. The functions of the proposed statutory authority are that it should collect data, conduct research into the health of the Australian community and evaluate health requirements. All those matters are laudable. I have been a member of at least two committees which have concluded that for proper planning governments need data that are accurate and appropriate. The Senate Standing Committee on Social Welfare, of which I was a member, under the chairmanship of Senator Peter Baume, pushed strongly for evaluation of all Government programs and for data to be obtained on health matters. The Committee made recommendations in respect of both data and evaluation. The report I am referring to was entitled `Through a Glass, Darkly: Evaluation in Australian Health and Welfare Services' and recommended:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Commonwealth Government direct the Australian Bureau of Statistics to raise to an appropriate level the proportion of its budget spent specifically on health and welfare statistics.
That the non-government health and welfare sector be given grants to enable it to report on the data priorities of non-government health and welfare organisations.

Those recommendations related to the collection of data which the Committee regarded as a great need. The Committee's membership included Senator Grimes, who has recently retired from this place. The Committee saw the need for the Australian Bureau of Statistics to be given an appropriate budget level to enable it to operate the database. None of us on that Committee-including former Senator Grimes-saw any need for the setting up of a new statutory body to collect that data. The added cost of establishing such a body is mind boggling. In regard to evaluation, our report said:
This report asserts that, in order to achieve an efficient, effective, rational and equitable health and welfare system, it is necessary to conduct on going evaluation.

Evaluation need not be confining. There is a wide range of possible evaluation methods and no need for any program to be confined to one prescriptive format. Evaluation reports can make it possible to improve programs and rectify mistakes and, at times, they may indicate a need for program termination.
The need for evaluation was regarded by our Committee as crucial. But there was no suggestion that a statutory authority should be set up to conduct those evaluations. We recommended:

That the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet be charged with the responsibility for ensuring that adequate program evaluation is carried out by all Commonwealth authorities, and that it certify annually that the results of such evaluations have been properly reported to the Parliament.
We also recommended:

That the Departments of Health and Social Security provide a consultancy service fee of charges, to enable organisations receiving health and welfare grants from the Federal Government to evaluate their own activities.
At no stage was there any suggestion in our report that there was a need to establish a statutory authority. But we certainly did agree that there was a need.

As I have said, all of the functions that the Government has said that the statutory authority should have can be carried out less expensively by existing organisations. We already have over 500 statutory authorities. The Minister for Health (Dr Blewett) said that there will be no additional costs. But if we have a look at the powers that the Minister is giving to that statutory authority, we find that it will be able to conduct business, indulge in land dealings and so on. It is quite ridiculous for the Minister to suggest that there will be no additional powers. According to the Bill, the Institute will be able to:
. . . enter into contracts or arrangements, including contracts or arrangements with bodies or persons to perform functions on behalf of the Institute;
So it will be able to let contracts. It will also be able to:

. . . acquire, hold and dispose of real or personal property . . . occupy, use and control any land or building owned or held under lease by the Commonwealth and made available for the purposes of the Institute.

Does that sound as if there will not be any added cost? To expect that there will not be is, of course, just ridiculous. I am very suspicious of statutory authorities and the addition of another only adds to my suspicion. If we look at the annual report of the Health Insurance Commission-again, one of the statutory authorities on which this Government places great reliance-we find that there are 17 breaches of the law. I do not know how many breaches there were in respect of Medibank Private, but the number is quite incredible. The law requires that if the principles applying to 1985-86 are different from those applying to the previous year, this must be reported in the annual report. This, of course, was not done. That implies that there were breaches not only in the Medibank Private section of the report but also in the Australia Card and Medicare sections. There are breaches throughout the whole report of the Health Insurance Commission. Statutory authorities are notorious for breaking the provisions of the legislation under which they were instigated. I certainly have no joy in seeing the setting up of a further authority.

The Minister has said that the statutory authority is necessary because it will deal with highly sensitive information relating to private health-related organisations, the health of individuals and the financial position of States and Territories. He said that it is therefore vital that the Institute be independent and be seen to be independent. He said that his priorities in setting up the statutory authority are based on privacy. I do not blame the Minister for being very sensitive about his Department, because his Department just cannot keep confidentiality within its grasp at all. Indeed, on many occasions it has leaked private information, much to the embarrassment of the Minister. But I suggest that the setting up of a statutory authority would make absolutely no difference at all in this respect. We have already had leaks from the Health Insurance Commission, which is also a statutory authority. So the argument for setting up a statutory authority for that reason alone is quite spurious.

A reading of the Commonwealth Government Directory makes us realise just what an enormous department the Department of Health is. Under the Department of Health we already have the Australian Institute of Health, the Corporate Resources Division, the Health Advancement Division, the Health Services Financing Division, the Therapeutics Division and the National Health and Medical Research Division. Why cannot one of those areas do the research? Why does a special statutory authority have to be set up to do the health research for the nation? The Department of Health also has an internal audit branch and an overseas representation branch. The Department has responsibility for the Australian Drug Evaluation Committee, the Australian Health Ministers Conference, the Australian Health Ministers Advisory Council, the Commonwealth Serum Laboratories Commission, the Australian Institute of Health Advisory Board, the Executive Editorial Board Australian Prescriber, the Health Benefits Reinsurance Trust Fund and the Health Insurance Advisory Committee. The list goes on for page after page. Why on earth should the Minister want to set up a statutory authority when already all these areas are covered by the Department? If the Department, very rightly, wants additional statistics, let us give this function to the Australian Bureau of Statistics. The Government should give the Bureau the funds to collect those statistics and we would certainly agree with that.

Senator Crowley, in her speech the other day, told us that the statistics cited by Senator Michael Baume, when he suggested that the incidence of use under the Government's Medicare program had increased, were wrong. The fact is, as we have been told by the Government, that the statistics taken out under the Fraser Government did not include 1.8 million people. Let us get it quite clear: They were primarily people in Queensland who did not see the need to insure because there is a free health system in that State. They were people in the armed forces who were not insured privately because they were fully covered, and a number of others. So, the Government's figures of the increasing incidence of usage under Medicare take in those additional 1.8 million people. Consequently, Senator Crowley's figures were quite fraudulent.

If we look at where the Government should be cutting costs instead of setting up a new statutory authority, we cannot refer to any better source than Professor Penington, because he is the most influential health adviser to this Government. Professor Penington has said that health costs in Australia are out of control and that there is a simple procedure for this Government to follow if it chooses to do so-that is, to stop universal bulk billing.

It does not matter to whom one speaks; everybody recognises that the entrepreneurial types of medical practitioners in Australia-there are only a handful of them-will take advantage of universal bulk billing to an enormous degree. The costs have gone out the window. We know without any shadow of a doubt that Professor Penington-as I said, he is the chief health adviser to this Government-has said: `Stop universal bulk billing'. Only the pensioners and the disadvantaged should be bulk billed. If we allow it for every person in Australia and nobody has to pay a penny for medical treatment, abuse of the system will continue. The proof of that, as I said, is the increasing usage of Medicare since the Medicare system was introduced. There is no credibility to the figures Senator Crowley cited during her contribution to the debate. Her figures excluded 1.8 million people; so they have no credibility at all.

I ask the Minister: Will the Government take up Professor Penington's recommendations? We were told by Dr Blewett last time the professor made those recommendations, in 1985, that he would examine Professor Penington's statement closely before making a comment. Of course, we did not hear any comment at all from him; he just went to water. He knows only too well that the way to cut costs is to cut back universal bulk billing. But that does not fit in with the ideology of this Government. The ideology of this Government is very clear, as I have said in this place on many occasions. One has only to look to Dr Deeble, who is a good old socialist from way back in the Whitlam era and who has been picked up by this Government and added to its advisers. Dr Deeble said that the categorisation of private hospitals was the first step in bringing the private hospital system under the public system. He said that it was only a small step, but it was the long term aim. He set out very clearly the socialist tendencies of this Government in sticking to universal bulk billing so that eventually, when all doctors bulk bill, doctors will be socialised. Let us make it quite clear: Once the Government pays the wages of all doctors, those doctors are socialised. It is as simple as that. It is a back door method that this Government has used on many occasions.

There have been all sorts of rumours about the May statement. We were told by the media yesterday that the gap will be greater for patients in private hospitals. In other words, the patients who can afford to pay the 1.25 per cent levy plus private insurance are paying twice for hospital care because their levy covers the public hospital system. If they do not use it, they pay for it just the same. If they take out private insurance, according to the media yesterday, they will be slugged for additional money. Only 75 per cent of the schedule fee will be returned, instead of 85 per cent. If the Government is serious about that, I assure it that it will be disadvantaging some of the poorest people in Australia. I refer to the health insurance survey of the Australian Bureau of Statistics for March 1986. In that survey the Australian Bureau of Statistics points out, in regard to married couples with dependent children and in receipt of less than $126 a week, that 46.05 per cent of those people take out private insurance. The mind boggles as to how people in receipt of that sort of income can possibly set aside money for private insurance.

What makes those couples struggle to do so? What makes couples who are earning less than $126 a week and who have dependent children struggle to pay for private insurance? The point is that they know that they cannot necessarily get their children and themselves into a public hospital, so they take out private insurance. If this Government cuts the rebate for patients in private hospitals to 75 per cent of the schedule fee, it will disadvantage 46 per cent of those people in receipt of the very lowest incomes in Australia. Let the Government understand that point. It is of no use for the Government to introduce new taxes, set up new statutory bodies, tax people even further, make people pay twice, and think that it is only getting at the wealthy in the community; it is not. Even the poorest people in the community recognise that this Government has made such a hash of the health scheme that, because their families are their priority, they are forced to struggle to take out private health insurance.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collard Sen S.J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLARD
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating two health Bills-the Australian Institute of Health Bill 1987 and the National Health Amendment Bill 1987. The Australian Institute of Health Bill establishes a new statutory authority which is completely unnecessary as its proposed functions are already being carried out by the Department of Health. The National Party of Australia therefore opposes that Bill. Its major functions will be the collection, analysis and dissemination of health-related information statistics. It is supposed to promote research into health services and the health of people. It is not supposed to interfere with or reduce the functions of the Australian Bureau of Statistics. Its financial impact is said to be negligible.

SPEECH.PARA: The intention is quite obvious-that is, to consolidate the little nests of number crunchers that are already scattered throughout the Health Department. It is intended to create a single unit of bovver boys and health restricters. The fundamental premise of Medicare is to provide health care free at the point of delivery. This immediately creates an unlimited demand for services which have to be satisfied from a limited budget. Therefore, the Government has to limit the services it provides. These restrictions, which are being put in place as time goes by, have led to dissatisfaction amongst patients facing long waiting lists and delayed surgical operations, and amongst nurses and doctors, who are now striking, which was once unheard of in both professions. Public hospitals have bed shortages and there is an underusage of private hospitals, and nursing homes are subject to skyrocketing costs.

With all this, what have these people been analysing, collating and disseminating so far? Quite simply, as any member of the medical profession will tell us, they have been analysing, collating and disseminating private doctors' prescribing habits, practising habits, home visiting habits, admission ratios and operation audits. They compare each doctor's figures with his area coverage and, if there is any variation, the Department of Health sends a counsellor to counsel him. The counsellor is often some broken down hack, unable to hack it in the world of private care, who has no idea what it means to take responsibility for a patient's life.

The Government is now spending $16m on investigating and assessment teams to inspect patients in nursing homes. This work has been done free for generations by general practitioners and matrons. It has been done accurately in the past because patients were responsible for their own bills. It is an insult to patients, doctors and nurses to assert that they cannot assess the value and adequacy of their own health care. In the old Medibank days, Mr Whitlam and Mr Hayden asserted that `Health is too important to be left in the hands of doctors,' and that `A doctor owning a hospital is like a judge owning a gaol'. Both assertions are patently wrong and it is time the Government got off the back of the private health care system to enable that system to lift the load off the Government's back. The greatest instrument for containing health costs is to have each patient scrutinising each account. If the patient is paying, overcharging and overservicing are reduced to a minimum.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are against insurance then?
—Indeed, I am not.
—The patient does not pay if he is insured.

—But at least he sees his bill and has a fair idea what the service has cost him, and he is fully conversant with the fact that his premiums are a result of the cost of the service in the long run, the same as with car insurance or anything else. It is only when a third party is introduced into the doctor-patient relationship-a third party over which the doctor has no control-that these problems escalate. Under Medicare, when neither the doctor nor the patient is aware of the real costs of the service, there is no incentive to contain costs. Is it any wonder that the nation's health care is now costing the taxpayer a phenomenal amount? In order to reduce the cost the Government now needs to know what is going on; just what mayhem it has caused. It needs figures, so it invents these nests of number crunchers, bovver boys, health restricters and controllers, subject, of course, to the usual pious privacy provisions, which everybody knows are basically a sham.

SPEECH.PARA: The report of the Senate Select Committee on Private Hospitals and Nursing Homes, entitled `Private Hospitals in Australia: Their conduct, administration and ownership', was recently tabled in the Senate. It is a direct result of the Government interfering in the conduct of the institutions as a third party. Of course, the interference starts with the government subsidy. This subsidy has been built into the economies of the institutions. Once the institutions become dependent on the Government subsidy, the Government is then in a position to control them. This is what has happened to private hospitals and nursing homes in Australia today, and it follows the old proverb: `Whoever pays the piper calls the tune'. The government subsidy has increased all the costs of these institutions and it is because of these high costs that the Government has had to commission its program of restrictions. But it first has to get the figures, and this is what the Australian Institute of Health is all about.

The second Bill, being debated cognately, is the National Health Amendment Bill 1987. This is merely a patch-up and a band-aid Bill to correct many of the administrative weaknesses and failures that have come to light during the administration of that horrendous albatross around our neck, Medicare. If evidence were needed to show how cumbersome and inadequate our health care system is, this Bill is it. The National Party of Australia is not opposing the Bill, as it is at least an attempt to tidy up a number of areas in the administration of the pharmaceutical benefits scheme. The maladministration of the scheme under Pharmpay resulted in a processing backlog of 50 million scripts as at last September. The bureaucratic bungling of this scheme led to the Government being chipped by the Auditor-General for instituting an illegal payments scheme for pharmacists. The Bill provides that pathology services performed after a patient has left hospital but while he or she is still under hospital treatment should be eligible for benefit from a registered health benefits organisation in order to provide a safety net for those who are chronically ill and needing multiple prescriptions. As I indicated, the National Party will support the second Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank honourable senators for their contributions to the debate, irrelevant as most of them were.
—In your humble opinion.

—I interjected during the honourable senator's speech that it was not, in my view, his best speech, but it was certainly his worst after the one he made earlier today. Senator Walters, in the course of her speech, as will be recorded in Hansard, sought to refer to the Australian Institute of Health Bill, which we were debating, and then said: `I have not got the Bill'. Her speech just demonstrated that point. She talked about everything except the Bill. It is not my purpose in reply to debate the whole range of issues which Senator Walters raised. Basically she is concerned about Medicare, and she has been for a long time, without ever declaring any interest which she might have in it.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Collard largely reiterated points which had already been made. I should indicate that the Australian Institute of Health has been the subject of discussion between this Government and the States. It is believed that the co-operation of the States and Territories in the provision of data will be more readily obtained if the Institute is seen to be a collection agent independent of the Department of Health. The States are concerned that such provision will not prejudice their position in negotiation for funding and so on. They will also have requirements about confidentiality, which the statutory authority is probably best able to ensure.

There were one or two matters raised by the Australian Democrats, which will perhaps be raised again in the Committee stage. Let me just make the point that the amendments to be moved in Committee of the Whole by the Australian Democrats are acceptable to the Government. Further, there has been discussion on the intention behind he use of the word `researchers' in paragraph 5 (1) (h) of the Bill. I indicate on behalf of the Minister for Health (Dr Blewett) that that is to enable any genuine research person to obtain health information and statistics for the purposes of engaging in health research. The word `researchers' is not confined to academics in tertiary institutions. The main purposes of this legislation were explained in detail in the second reading speech, and I have nothing to add. I commend the Bills to the Senate.
Question put:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Powell Sen J.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (2) Page 4, subclause 8 (1), at the end of subclause, add the following new paragraph:
``(h) a member nominated by the Consumers' Health Forum of Australia.''.

I foreshadowed the amendment during the second reading debate. The amendment brings into the work of the Australian Institute of Health in a very positive way the Consumers' Health Forum of Australia. The Australian Democrats believe that under the Australian Institute of Health Bill as printed the Institute will be made up of academic and bureaucratic appointments. The establishment of the Consumers' Health Forum was a very forward looking and useful exercise by the Minister. Through this amendment we seek to bring the Forum into a very active role in the new Institute, the establishment of which we support.

The Forum has very exciting potential, as I said during the second reading debate. The Consumers' Health Forum should be guaranteed membership of the new and vital Australian Institute of Health. We are very pleased to note that the Minister has taken into account our arguments in favour of the Forum which, as I said, has been established by the Minister. We are pleased to have the Government's support for the amendment in the interests of Australian consumers. We believe that the amendment will ensure that the Institute gives emphasis to preventative health measures and has a clear focus on the needs and wishes of the consumers of health care and health services.

We are pleased that the Minister has assured us that in relation to clause 5 (1) (h) there will be the widest possible definition of `researchers'. The Australian Democrats hope that the Institute will promote procedures for the automatic recording of adverse reactions to drugs and therapeutic devices, probably under clause 5 (1) (e). I note that in the case of the Dalkon shield, for instance, the voluntary reporting which was available was not very successful and I ask the Minister whether the Institute will assist in the development of procedures to enable ready notification for people who are using therapeutic devices or drugs which are discovered to be causing problems for health consumers. I commend the amendment to the chamber and thank the Government for supporting it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The coalition, or at least the Liberal Party, opposes the creation of the Australian Institute of Health-and we just voted against the second reading of the Bill which provides for its establishment-because we regard it as an unnecessary way of bringing about a desirable end. As a result, the constitution of the Institute, as outlined in clause 8 (1), is within that framework of opposition. The Liberal Party certainly takes the view that this whole structure is unnecessary. Let me outline what the structure is: According to the Bill, there should be 11 members of the Institute; and the amendment moved by the Australian Democrats proposes that there should be 12. There would be a chairperson, the director, three members nominated by the Australian Health Ministers Advisory Council, the Australian Statistician, the Secretary of the Department, a member nominated by the Public Health Association of Australian and New Zealand, and three members nominated by the Minister. Now the Democrats have proposed that a member be nominated by the Consumers' Health Forum of Australia. This simply demonstrates and underlines the phoniness of this whole proposal.

SPEECH.PARA: We heard during the second reading debate the proposition that there had to be an independent body because the State health authorities do not trust, do not get on with and are in continual warfare with the Federal authorities, and that it is vital, therefore, to have a separate statutory body like this. We denied that in debate. Now we see that the Secretary of the Department, who is apparently not trusted, not liked and does not get on with the State authorities-they are in such constant warfare that a separate Institute has to be created-is going to be a member of that Institute.

The Government must really be pulling its own leg. The structure of this body underlines the nonsense involved in the argument that the only way in which to solve this problem is to have a separate statutory body, the Institute of Health. It was demonstrated quite properly in the second reading debate that one can achieve the objectives of this body without creating such a structure at all. It was intriguing that at the conclusion to the second reading debate, the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button) did not even bother to counter the very sound points made by the Opposition. For example, he did not counter the point that one of the many recommendations about improving the source of information research in this area which this Institute is supposed to achieve supported the creation of a statutory body like this. That was not responded to by the Government.

It seems to me contemptuous of this place that we should have a round-up to a second reading speech such as that provided by Senator Button. So the opportunity given to us in the Committee stage must be taken to dramatise those areas referred to specifically in the clauses where the Government arrogantly disregarded the sound objections made by the Opposition to the creation of this body. For example, we see that the Australian Statistician is included in the constitution of the Institute. I suppose, if we are going to have to have this Institute, it is useful to have him as a member. However, I am surprised that the Government wants him there, having heard the incredible accusations made by Senator Crowley, for example, about his refusal to provide the statistics in an adequate way despite continual requests from the Government. There was a recognition apparently from Senator Crowley that this Government is incapable of requiring its public servants to act in a manner which suits it.

If the Australian Bureau of Statistics was incapable of performing this function, as Senator Crowley insisted it was in her speech in the second reading debate, I must say I find it most curious that the Government should appoint the person who is in charge of this body, which does not do what the Government tells it to do, to join the Australian Institute of Health. The Government is really having two bob each way. Either the Australian Statistician is competent, capable, willing and able in this area or he is not. The reality is that he is competent; he is capable; and, given proper governmental direction, he would certainly be able to provide the sorts of statistics that are required and which, as we demonstrated, are not being provided at the moment, largely because it appears--

TALK.START.PARA: —On a point of order, I would like to be clear, on a ruling from you, Mr Chairman, that the Opposition senator is not actually debating issues and is in fact taking a second reading position on this point. Could I be advised whether he is not actually straying from the Committee stage?
—The Committee is considering the Bill as a whole and Senator Michael Baume's remarks are in order.

—Thank you, Mr Chairman. Specifically I am discussing the fact that the Australian Statistician is included in the constitution of the Institute, despite the fact that Senator Crowley has behaved in such a contemptuous way of him and his ability to provide statistics in this area.
—That is a lie. That is not what I said.

—I recall only too well that Senator Crowley said that the Statistician was not providing the information required, that he had no interest in doing so and that he had failed to deliver what the Government itself wanted.
—Wrong.
—If the Senator wants to deny that, she should produce what she said in Hansard.
—I did. You go and do the Hansard.

—The reality is that this whole question of statistics is one of major concern. I refer to Hansard of 29 April when Senator Crowley, for example, accused me of misrepresentation of the facts. At page 1992, she is reported as saying:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . he needs to do some more homework.

The senator said that I should not falsify figures, and talked about `misrepresentation of the facts'. These allegations by Senator Crowley emerged because she claimed that the statistics I was using were inaccurate and the statistics that she had were truthful.

TALK.START.PARA: —But she didn't understand them.

—Exactly. As Senator Walters said, she did not understand them. The reality is that when, in much more moderate terms than Senator Crowley used about me, I responded to her even moderately in kind, she bleated that she was being grossly and disgracefully attacked. Now look, Senator Crowley, you know, presumably, something about heat and kitchens, and I promise you that if you behave--
—Order! Senator Michael Baume will address his remarks through the Chair.

—I can assure Senator Crowley that if she wants to indulge in this kind of personal attack on me, as I have outlined already by quoting it, she will receive exactly the same kind of response. I point out to her that when she bleats, as she did yesterday, that it was unfair and disgraceful of me to respond in kind to her, she is adopting double standards.

SPEECH.PARA: Now that we know exactly where we stand, Senator-through you, Mr Chairman-I think we can deal with this whole question of whether or not the composition of this body is necessary. I am making the point that it is totally unnecessary except that there is a clear need for honest statistics in this area, as is demonstrated by the Government's misuse of those statistics. There has been not one response by the Government in this debate to the clear fact that I demonstrated that it is impossible for the Government's claim, for example, about the incidence of services per head having declined under Medicare and bulk billing, to be true when in fact each Budget since then has indicated a 7 or 8 per cent or so increase in utilisation per head. As Senator Walsh knows, one cannot increase utilisation per head every Budget and then try to pretend that some phoney figures suggest that it has fallen. Government senators not only suggested but asserted that utilisation had fallen under Medicare and bulk billing. That is patently false, yet Senator Crowley repeated it yesterday after having had that fact demonstrated to her.

So there can be no doubt of the need for better statistics. The Opposition's complaint is that the structure as outlined in clause 8 is the wrong way to go about it. The figures were quite wrong, and there has been no concession or admission-or even discussion-of that by the Government in this debate. Not only were the Government's figures quite wrong, but they were self-evidently wrong in that they excluded in the comparison to 1983 1.8 million people and then tried to say that that related directly and strictly to the figures which now, of course, include the total population; and, as I pointed out, there was that one hidden word. The reality is that there is a difference in the degree of cover involved in the 1983 figures, as I understand them, and the 1986 figures, which the Government has been quoting as showing a fall in utilisation.

There is no doubt that there is a need for honest figures in order to keep the Government honest in this area. That is why, as I said, it is intriguing that the Government is now including the Australian Statistician in the membership of the Institute, having claimed that he was not doing as he had been asked; that he had somehow failed in his duty. I suggest that Senator Crowley go back and reread her speech. She may not have intended to convey that impression, but she certainly did convey it, and in fact I interjected on this matter at the time.

Whether or not the Consumers Health Forum of Australia would be an appropriate body to be added to this Institute is clearly a matter on which I am not going to take a strong stand, because, quite frankly, I am opposed to the existence of the Institute anyway. It seems to me that increasing the size of the Institute from 11 to 12 members is not a matter of great moment. I should have thought that, if there were a need for a representative from the Consumers Health Forum of Australia, that could well be met under the existing structure as outlined in this Bill, with three members to be nominated by the Minister. Why could not the Minister give an undertaking that one of those three would represent consumers? Without making any particular comment on the Consumers Health Forum of Australia, I point out that there has been a tendency for consumer groups in some areas-I am not necessarily saying in this area-to represent vested interests that are not necessarily the interests of consumers. It may well be a trend that does not necessarily lead to better government. The Opposition, having opposed the creation of the Institute, will certainly oppose this amendment as well but does not intend to call for a division on the matter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crowley Sen R.A.

I believe that the honourable senator, in continuing to make that claim about my remarks, is misrepresenting me.
