SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is no doubt that Senator Michael Baume has caught Senator Crowley criticising the Australian Bureau of Statistics. For her to try to back off now by citing criticisms of the Australian Bureau of Statistics and saying that they were not her criticisms but that she was using them as evidence is really quite a stupid way to go about things. The fact is that Senator Crowley was caught being critical of the Bureau, which she does not like because it does not sound too good. Of course it does not sound too good, because the Bureau is a completely independent body of great integrity. For Senator Crowley to try to back off now is just stupid.

SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition has said that the Bureau of Statistics is indeed a very credible organisation. It is totally independent, as every senator in this place would know. There is no doubt at all, at least on the Opposition benches, about the Bureau's credibility, and I would very much like to see it being given the money to enable it to collect the statistics that everyone in this place agrees are necessary. Senator Baume has just indicated that statistics are thrown around this chamber like confetti, and that is because we have not got proper statistics, particularly in the health and welfare areas. Several committees have said exactly this-that we need more reliable and better statistics.
We have had this situation in other areas, such as the welfare area, where the numbers of homeless youth drift from one million to a couple of hundred thousand.

TALK.START.PARA: —But we cannot take notice of the Liberal Party's corrupt statistics.
—As Senator Elstob would know, because he and I sit on the Standing Committee on Social Welfare, we have not a clue what the statistics are.
—Yes, we do.

—Senator Elstob sits on the Committee with me and he acknowledged in its report that we did not know what the statistics were. We definitely need a better database not only in the area of health but also in the area of welfare. There is no argument there. The only argument is whether we need to set up a costly statutory body to collect the data. We already have the Australian Bureau of Statistics. If it is given the right amount of money it can collect the data without the cost of establishing a whole new statutory authority that needs land, offices and the whole thing. Absolutely unquestionably, the taxpayers will not put up with this Government spending any more of their money when facilities are already available to provide the database and to allow the research and the necessary evaluation to be undertaken. There is no doubt at all that the taxpayers will not tolerate their money being wasted on the establishment of yet another statutory authority. We have, as I have already said, over 500 statutory authorities, and there is no intention in the Opposition's mind of allowing yet another to be added to that list.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The point that has yet to be made, largely because of the inadequate response by the Government, and one that must be made in these circumstances, is that the Government has not in this Committee debate, or in the second reading debate, established any need for a statutory body such as that being created by clause 8. The failure to establish a real need is demonstrated by the composition of the Australian Institute of Health, as recommended in clause 8.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN POSTAL AND TELECOMMUNICATIONS UNION: WORK BANS

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Finance both in that capacity and as Minister representing the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations. The Minister will recall my asking him last week about bans imposed by the Australian Postal and Telecommunications Union in a dispute with the Commonwealth Government about proposed changes to workers compensation provisions. He will further recall saying that the matter had gone before the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission and that, if the campaign aimed at sabotaging the collection of public revenue continued, the Government would have to consider what action it would take. I ask the Minister: Is he aware that the union is now in open defiance of an Arbitration Commission ruling to lift the bans which are stopping mail deliveries to branches of the Australian Taxation Office and preventing collection by the Government of hundreds of millions of dollars in tax payments? Are the bans already having an impact on public debt interest payments-a potential result of the dispute acknowledged by the Minister last week? If not, how long will it be before this happens? On the eve of the Hancock report legislation, which will make it harder for employers to resist union pressure, will the Government reconsider its refusal to re-introduce the legislative provisions which it repealed and which gave it power to deal quickly and effectively with its employees who refuse to do the work for which they are paid?

—The answer to the last part of the question is no because it is unnecessary. Stand-downs of the people concerned have already taken place. That action was taken very rarely by the Fraser Government. Senator Chaney says he did it once. It might have happened on one or two occasions, but it certainly did not happen very often and it did not happen very quickly. As for the rest of the question, I repeat-I ask the unions to note-that this Government will not tolerate the sabotage of public administration by union industrial action.
—I ask a supplementary question. I thank the Minister for that reply, but I ask him: When did stand-downs commence and what is the number of officers who have been stood down?
—This is subject to correction, but I think there were some last Friday. I do not know whether there have been some since, and I do not know the number. I will find out.

—Has the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce seen reports in the Tasmanian media which are critical of the Government's decision, announced last week, on future protection arrangements for the processed vegetable industry? Is there any justification for the alarm expressed by the Managing Director of McCain Australia Pty Ltd, Mr John Clements, and by Mr Nick Evers, the Tasmanian Minister for Primary Industry, about the future of the processed vegetable industry in Tasmania, particularly in the potato products sector?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have had some of these comments drawn to my attention. It is an issue in respect of which both Mr Clements and Mr Evers, the Tasmanian Minister, have expressed concern, and also Mr Lawrence of the Australian Vegetable Industry Council is reported as expressing concern. I find the comments which have been made alarmist rather than alarming, which is the word that Senator Aulich used in his question. Last week the Minister for Primary Industry and I made an announcement of the Government's decision in response to the 1986 report of the Industries Assistance Commission into the potential for the development of the fresh vegetable and vegetable products industry in Australia. In a minute I want to come back to what the Government decided about that matter. I just make the point that the Industries Assistance Commission report was published in April 1986 and it was in November 1986 that, in full knowledge of the fact that the IAC report had been published and recommended a 10 per cent tariff rate for processed vegetables, the McCains company moved to Tasmania. That matter was fully within its knowledge at the time.

ANSWER.PARA: I might go briefly to the decision which the Government made. The primary aim of that decision is to assist the sector to become more export oriented and attuned to market needs. The Government was very clear in relation to the regional significance of the industries, and I believe the decision taken reflects this understanding and the Government's intention to assist, not impede, the development of those industries. The decision, in summary, provides a final general tariff rate of 10 per cent for processed vegetables and fresh mushrooms, and minimum rates for fresh and unprocessed vegetables. This will involve declines in protection for some highly protected sectors and increases in protection for some others, so that there is a uniform rate of 10 per cent. There will be a phased in introduction of new rates, with more liberal phasing in for tomato and potato products. Tariff reductions will be phased in over periods of up to seven years to assist adjustment processes in the industry. Rates will commence to fall from 8 May 1987. Removal of a number of by-laws and the import prohibition of fresh potatoes are other issues dealt with in the decision.

The Government's expectation is that the new protection regime, combined with a wide range of development measures that we have under way, will enhance the growth and export prospects of the industry. Those development measures include the plant variety rights legislation, a review of export inspection regulations, additional funds for rural adjustment, a $25m program over five years to assist innovative agricultural marketing programs, the introduction of the national industry extension service-

TALK.START.PARA: —Put it in a book.

—I know it is long, but it is very important for vegetables. I thought it might have interested the honourable senator, for that reason. The development measures also include the preparation of an export strategy for Australian processed food. Consumers should also benefit from these changes. I want to indicate the general import of the decision and say that the criticisms which have been made are not to the point and are alarmist, as I said, rather than alarming.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: ABORIGINES: GOVERNMENT EMPLOYMENT AND TRAINING PROGRAMS

TALK.START.PARA: —Can the Minister representing the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs say whether the Government is satisfied with the participation rate by Aborigines in government employment and training programs? Has the Government considered the benefits of running a high profile campaign giving actual examples of employment and training opportunities taken up by unemployed Aborigines? Does the Minister agree that such a campaign would give realistic incentives to unemployed Aborigines and, at the same time, counteract the usual negative publicity given to Aborigines?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —In reply to the first part of Senator Elstob's question, I stress that our Government is not yet satisfied with the extent of participation by Aboriginal people in government employment and training programs. Although there has been a great increase in the participation by Aboriginal people in these programs, both in mainstream programs and in those specially designed for Aborigines, the Government considers that the rate of participation needs to be greatly improved. In August 1986 the Government announced the establishment of the Aboriginal employment development policy to address these issues. This policy represents a fundamental shift from welfare dependency, or the approach of the past, towards measures to enhance Aboriginal independence. The details are being developed currently for further consideration by the Government.

ANSWER.PARA: The initial promotion of the Aboriginal employment development policy occurred in late 1986 and further promotion will be undertaken as further details of the policy are announced. One of the new AEDP programs-the Aboriginal employment action program-which is administered by the Department of Employment and Industrial Relations, involves facilitating the development of improved Aboriginal recruitment and training practices in the corporate sector. This program promotes private sector employment for Aborigines which, I am sure Senator Elstob will agree, is just as important as public sector employment opportunities. I agree that such promotion is important as it informs the Aboriginal community of the employment and training opportunities available, as well as presenting a positive image to the wider community of the fact that Aborigines want to work and not depend indefinitely on welfare payments.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister for Resources and Energy to the report of the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs entitled `The Role of the Parliament in Relation to the National Companies Scheme'. Is it the case that in a submission to that Committee, the former Commonwealth Solicitor-General, Sir Maurice Byers, who is now the Chairman of the Government's Constitutional Commission, argued that the Commonwealth, through its corporations power, had the power to control the mining and trading activities of companies, a position agreed to by the Senate Committee? If so, is it not the case that the Commonwealth has ample scope to use these powers to halt sand mining on Moreton Island if its sand minerals are sold domestically? How does the Government reconcile the arguments of the Senate Committee report with the curious and apparently increasingly isolated stance of the Minister for Arts, Heritage and Environment, Mr Cohen, who only three weeks ago told the Brisbane Courier-Mail that the Government does not have the power to intervene over the mining of Moreton Island?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government is indebted to Senator Macklin for his continued support of a wide-ranging reach for the corporations power, in particular in the context of national companies and securities legislation. That is a campaign after my own heart and after the Government's own heart as the Attorney-General, Mr Lionel Bowen, has made clear recently. In that context there is no doubt whatsoever about the scope and reach of the corporations power, nor is there any doubt about the propriety of using the corporations power in order to advance manifestly sensible national objectives. I hope that in due course, and sooner rather than later, we will have a national companies and securities scheme reflecting that, the interests of the business community and, increasingly, the views of all parties in this country about the way to go in that respect.

ANSWER.PARA: On the question of the use of the corporations power to achieve other policy objectives, such as environmental controls and so on, it must be acknowledged that the availability of that power, technically speaking, is much more problematic. I am aware that opinions have been expressed by people such as Sir Maurice Byers, whose opinions I very much respect, that the corporations power will extend to just about any kind of activity in which trading, foreign or financial corporations engage. However, there are others who take the view that the power in question extends only to the trading activities of such corporations or matters pertaining to their essential character as corporations, which is the sort of thing that companies and securities law is all about. I do not believe, the Government does not believe and clearly, from what Senator Macklin says, Mr Cohen does not believe that the power is conspicuously, self-evidently available in the context of environmental issues of the kind to which Senator Macklin refers. Whether it is or not is something to which the Government would have close regard in considering its approach to such issues. Obviously, a whole variety of policy considerations, apart from the question of the availability of constitutional powers, is relevant there and on these policy issues I refer Senator Macklin not to me, as either Minister for Resources and Energy or Minister representing the Attorney-General, but rather to the relevant departments, including the Department of Arts, Heritage and Environment.

TALK.START.PARA: —I address my question to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. Is it a fact that when this Government came to power in 1983, Australia's gross overseas debt was of the order of $30 billion? Is it also a fact that at the end of 1986 Australia's overseas debt had risen to $105 billion, a threefold to fourfold increase? What policies of his Government have caused this debt, which took 83 years since Federation to reach the high level of $30 billion, to be more than tripled in the very short period of just 3 1/2 years? Do the reasons include excess government spending and borrowings domestically, so forcing local private sector borrowers off-shore? Will the Government play its part by at least cutting out hundreds of indefensible silly grants, such as $3,100 to study the ritual significance of bark cloth in Fiji, $5,750 to study the songs and dances of the Chinese new year, and $88,000 as a community employment program grant to two Aboriginal women on the Gold Coast for them to learn the total concept of breastfeeding?

His question reveals a degree of economic illiteracy which I hope is not characteristic of the new Nationals, which emerged from this old collection of flotsam and jetsam that we have had here for so long. It is true that the gross national debt of this country has increased. I would imagine, without being able to provide precise figures off the cuff, that one of the reasons for that is that the value of the Australia dollar has gone down considerably.
—Ha, ha, ha!
—Senator Walters laughs. I do not know whether I need explain that to her but I think Senator Brownhill understands the point.
—Why do you think it has gone down?

—Because it was floated, because it was overvalued at the time of the Fraser Government in order to keep inflation down. I am not an advocate of what Senator Brownhill would describe as silly grants. I have not been through all those grants, but I do not think Senator Brownhill will solve our economic problems by ticking off four or five such items. Perhaps I may be so humble as to suggest that he go back to the drawing board and try to correlate the gross national debt, which incidentally fell in the last quarter for the first time for a long period.
—Net or gross?
—It fell in net terms. If Senator Brownhill tries to correlate that figure with the grants he is talking about and comes back to ask another question, I shall have another go at it.
—I ask a supplementary question of the Minister. Do the reasons include excess government spending and borrowings domestically, so forcing local private sector borrowers off-shore?
—That is a matter of judgment. If one looks at the Government's view, expressed by various spokesmen, the answer would be to some degree yes.

—I direct my question to the Acting Minister for Foreign Affairs. Has the Minister's attention been drawn to recent media reports of illegal activities by United States trawlers in the South Pacific? Has there been any detection of such activities in Australian territorial waters? What are the international criteria for fishing by foreign boats within the exclusive zone of individual South Pacific nations, including Australia? What avenues of interrogation, surveillance, detention and punishment are available to countries in the South Pacific whose territorial waters could have been trespassed upon by outside nations?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President-
—What about the Soviets sitting off-shore at Portland and getting stuck into all those fish!
—Order!
—I thought you were going to ask Senator Lewis to answer the question, Mr President.
—You have to draw the line somewhere.

—Senator Colston is correct. My attention has been drawn to the reports of illegal fishing activity by United States trawlers. It would not be for the first time, as the Solomon Islands people are well aware. On 5 May Kiribati arrested a United States tuna vessel called The Tradition for allegedly fishing without a licence in Kiribati's exclusive economic zone. This follows reported sightings by Royal New Zealand patrol aircraft of a number of United States fishing vessels in Kiribati's EEZ. Australia hopes that the incident will be resolved quickly. Last week the meeting of the Forum Fisheries Committee issued a communique which was strongly critical of the activities of the United States tuna fleet. The multilateral fisheries access treaty between members of the Forum Fisheries Agency and the United States Government, which was signed in Port Moresby last month, will avert such incidents when it comes into force. We hope that that will be so by the end of the year. Until the treaty enters into force, fishing by United States vessels in the region could be covered by interim arrangements between the United States tuna industry and the island governments.

ANSWER.PARA: At the signing ceremony in Port Moresby, representatives of the governments of Kiribati and the United States, as well as other signatories, expressed strong support for the treaty as a means of successfully responding to a major long-standing regional problem. There have been no reports that the view of any of the signatories on the desirability of ratification of the treaty has been changed by the arrest. In fact, if anything, the arrest confirms the desirability of early ratification of the treaty. The treaty requires ratification by 10 members of the Forum Fisheries Agency, including Kiribati, Papua New Guinea and the Federated States of Micronesia, before it enters into force. Australia has sent its instrument of ratification to the Government of Papua New Guinea, which is the depository. There has been no detection of any fishing by United States tuna vessels in Australia's territorial waters, to answer that part of the honourable senator's question. International law recognises the sovereign rights of coastal states to explore, exploit, conserve and manage fisheries as well as other resources in the EEZ to which they are entitled. The avenues of interrogation, surveillance, detention and punishment available to coastal states in the South Pacific in cases of trespass in their territorial waters are determined by the coastal state involved. For example, both Australia and New Zealand, in consultation with the island states, undertake surveillance in the South Pacific to this end. I think that answers all the different parts of the honourable senator's question. If there is anything else, I would ask him to put it to me.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations. Has the Minister's attention been drawn to the latest statistics on industrial disputes in Australia, released by the Australian Bureau of Statistics today? Do those figures indicate that the level of industrial disputation in Australia continues to be low compared with the years of the Fraser-Howard Government? To what extent is this improvement the result of the Hawke Government's policies?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have seen the statistics referred to. In the 12 months to the end of January 1987, the total number of working days lost due to industrial disputes was 1.4 million, which is not quite as good as the 1.2 million in the year to January 1986 or the 1.3 million in the 12 months to January 1985. It does, however, compare quite startlingly with the figures for the Fraser-Howard years. In 1980 four million days were lost due to industrial disputes. These figures are all, incidentally, for the 12 months to January. In 1981, 3.3 million days were lost and, in 1982, a staggering 4.4 million. Thus, in that 12 months period ending January 1982, more working days were lost because of industrial disputes than in the whole three years to January 1987. Also, something like half a million more people, and possibly a few more than that, are employed now than were employed at the beginning of 1982.

ANSWER.PARA: Given that evidence, it is rather startling that the people who presided over a level of industrial disputation approximately three times that which has prevailed in recent years want to return to the system which produced both the wages explosion of 1981 and 1982 and the industrial disputes that went with it, and would sweep away the achievements of this Government. Recent detailed econometric research by two Australian National University academics demonstrates that the policies of the Hawke Government have had a great deal to do with what has been achieved. The academics are Drs Beggs and Chapman, who recently released a paper entitled `The Effect of the First Three Years of the Accord on Australian Industrial Disputation: The International Context'. I refer to a couple of the highlights in that paper. I mention firstly, as I mentioned yesterday, that Beggs and Chapman utilised a wide range of methods to demonstrate the difference between industrial disputation in Australia and in 13 other Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development countries during the first three years of this Government's life. Whereas in the 13 OECD countries there was a decrease of 36 per cent, in Australia there was a decrease of some 59 per cent. I will quote directly from the paper. In regard to the validity of those international comparisons, Beggs and Chapman said:

. . . it is apparent that the Australian data are relatively comprehensive. It follows that collection and inclusion criteria are such as to exaggerate industrial disputation in this country compared to most other countries.

In other words, they are saying that the bare statistical conclusion actually understates the magnitude of the achievement in Australia. Finally, I say again that I am amazed that, given empirical evidence as decisive as this, there are still people who would, if they could, go back to the system which produced the vastly inferior results-indeed, the catastrophic results-of the early 1980s.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Trade. I refer to the Government's short-sighted decision last year to close down the Australian Embassy in Lima. Is the Minister aware that since that time New Zealand, which immediately upgraded its mission, has launched a major export drive to promote dairy and sheep products in Peru and in Chile via major New Zealand companies such as Fletcher Challenge and Carter Holt Harvey? Is the Minister also aware that the New Zealand Dairy Board has invested about $500m in extensive pinewood projects and a virtual takeover of the local dairy industry? In the light of this sustained burst of activity and the Japanese Government's recent decision to allocate some $US30 billion in aid and trade to South America, has the Australian Government written off the continent as a potential expansion region? What is the Australian Government doing to counter the New Zealand menace?

—I am glad that, with the wisdom of hindsight, Senator Alston is able to describe the decision made last year as short-sighted. It was not seen to be so at the time by any commentators or, indeed, any members of the Opposition-not that that is particularly relevant, I concede. I am fully aware, first of all, of the New Zealand initiatives in some countries in South America-which go beyond Peru, I believe-in terms of developing particularly agricultural markets of one kind or another. Initiatives of that kind have been taken by a vast range of countries around the world--
—Not Australia.
—Yes, there are.
—Not in Peru or Chile.

—No, but New Zealand has not taken initiatives in other countries where there are Australian initiatives. That is the point I am seeking to make. There is no sustained burst of activity proposed at present to counteract what the honourable senator has described as the New Zealand activity in Peru, and I am very doubtful whether there will be. Australia's trade relations with the various countries of South America are represented by Austrade and diplomatic posts in a variety of capitals mostly in countries which have significantly larger populations than that of Peru and therefore greater export potential-and that is the way I believe the situation will remain. But if the honourable senator has any further suggestions the Government will, of course, look at them.

—Can the Minister for Resources and Energy advise why two Ipswich coal mines have been selected for closure by the Queensland Government? What impact will the closures have on unemployment in this region? Was the decision related to the Queensland Government's intimidation of mining unions responding to anti-worker legislation in that State?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have seen the reports on the closure of Westfalen and Box Flat coal mines near Ipswich, which are owned by the Bundaberg Sugar Company. I understand that some five mines are involved, employing around 250 people, with closure to take effect next month, on 12 June. It has been known for some time that mines in the Ipswich area supplying coal to the Queensland Electricity Commission would risk closure if a satisfactory arrangement for the future supply of coal to southern Queensland power stations could not be negotiated by the mine companies and the Electricity Commission. In recent years, producers in the West Moreton coal fields have recognised that, as their share of Queensland domestic coal consumption has fallen, they have had to look to supplying export markets to ensure continuation of mining. The region did export nearly 1 1/2 million tonnes of steaming coal last year. But, clearly, at current steaming coal export prices, further market penetration, given the relatively small volumes that are available to these mines, would be very difficult.

ANSWER.PARA: In the past some West Moreton miners have been able to find employment in the coal mines in northern and central Queensland, and some of those retrenched as a result of the Westfalen-Box Flat closures will be looking to find employment elsewhere in Queensland. It is to be hoped that previous redeployment arrangements developed by the Queensland mining companies and the coal unions will be used to maximum effect. Clearly, in the present circumstances, it is not possible to be greatly optimistic about the employment opportunities.

The closures are a direct result, it should be understood, of the State Government's decision to phase down the Swanbank power station as part of its plan to discontinue the operation of older, higher cost generating plant. Currently, Swanbank's coal stocks stand at more than one million tonnes, compared with an annual `burn' of about 300,000 tonnes. I notice that the Queensland Premier is apparently silent on the problem. Perhaps that has something to do with the fact that while his policies aggravate the hardship of workers in the West Moreton fields the Rolls Royce of the new power stations, at Tarong, is on the very borders of his own electorate.

In August 1985 the State Labor Party's shadow Minister for energy and resources matters, Mr Ken Vaughan, speaking in the Queensland Parliament, drew attention-I think very rightly-to the bad planning by the Government and the fact that well over $30m of Queensland taxpayers' money has been spent on power stations which will be closed down. He said that because of extremely bad planning the State currently has power stations capable of generating 4,800 megawatts while the maximum demand is about 3,500 megawatts. Because of Government propaganda about all of the industries flocking to Queensland from the rest of Australia and overseas, the Queensland Electricity Commission has had to plan power needs in accordance with the propaganda rather than with the reality. There have been a series of such phantom industries, which include two coke plants, a chemical plant, a pulp mill, a steel mill, a coal-to-oil plant, an oil-from-shale plant, two or three aluminium smelters, a uranium enrichment plant, and a number of other power consuming industries. None of them has materialised and electricity consumers, as a result, have been left with a huge bill to pay.

Ken Vaughan placed all of these matters on the record in the Queensland Parliament on behalf of the Opposition, as I said, a couple of years ago. He has been proved to be absolutely right. Those chickens have come home to roost. As a result of the monumental misplanning of the Queensland Government, the talking up of non-existent booms, the encouragement of non-existent industries, the requirement that State utilities plan on the basis of fantasies rather than reality, mines are being closed and jobs are being lost-and in areas which are least equipped to cope with that. It has been yet another disgraceful record on the part of the Queensland Premier. It should leave no doubts in anyone's mind not only about the folly of his grander aspirations to strut the national stage but also about the absolute economic devastation and havoc he has wreaked in his own State during his unfortunate years of stewardship there.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Veterans' Affairs. The Minister will recollect that it was claimed that the new veterans' entitlements legislation would drastically reduce the delays in processing claims and appeals and that initially this happened. Is it not a fact that, because of the new requirements for the veteran to furnish proof and because determinations are based on the balance of probabilities, claims have now been reduced to a mere trickle? In these circumstances, can the Minister explain why delays are now back to about 10 months for a repatriation determination and even longer for an appeal?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —The purpose of the new determining system was to overcome a very bad situation in which delays in processing claims for pension entitlements and assessments were in excess of a year-between 300 and 400 days. The aim of the new legislation was to reduce the waiting period for the single determining officer process, which was an innovation in the determining system, to 90 days. That has been achieved in about three of the six States. It is anticipated that within the next few months it will be the practice throughout the determining system; veterans will be able to have their cases dealt with at the primary level within the 90 days. That is regarded as being the best possible result from the veterans' point of view, having regard to the fact that records have to be provided and assessments made on the evidence produced by both the Department, in accordance with the Act, and the veteran.

ANSWER.PARA: When the veteran is not able to convince the single determining officer, the matter goes on appeal to the Veterans' Review Board. It is true that there is an unacceptable delay at that level. I attended a conference on Monday in Melbourne. I raised with the officers of the Veterans' Review Board the current difficulties that are being faced by veterans in having their applications dealt with at the second and final level. What emerged from that conference was a tendency on the part of many persons in the system not to be ready at the point at which their cases should be dealt with by the Veterans' Review Board. Other applicants in the queue are placed at a disadvantage if the advocates, who do a lot of excellent work in preparing the cases for the veterans, are not able to proceed, despite the fact that they have indicated prior to the hearing that they are ready to proceed.

Steps have been taken and resources have been allocated. There has been an overall reduction of about one-third in the number of those who were waiting in the system when I became the Minister. So, contrary to what has been asserted-I think there is an assertion in Senator Lewis's question-there has been a dramatic reduction in the waiting time.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question, which is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer, relates to the proposed spending cuts in government health outlays outlined in the Monash University's Centre of Policy Studies book entitled Spending and Taxing which was released last week. Is the Government considering implementing any of the savings options outlined in that book in relation to health? Can the Minister provide any information as to whether the Centre's proposed cuts in health outlays have the support of professional associations with interests and expertise in the health area?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —As far as I know, the only professional organisation which has commented publicly on the health spending cuts proposed in the book entitled Spending and Taxing is the Pharmacy Guild of Australia. Although the Pharmacy Guild has been providing financial support to the Centre of Policy Studies, which published the book, the Guild was very quick to distance itself from the recommendations in the chapter on health because it found the recommendations extremely embarrassing. That chapter recommended the abolition of the pharmaceutical benefits list, the compulsory prescription system, and the dilution of training requirements for persons retailing pharmaceuticals. All of those recommendations have been condemned by the Pharmacy Guild as being contrary to the best interests of the Australian community.

ANSWER.PARA: It is perhaps the first of what I am sure will be many demonstrations that to many groups deregulation and the withdrawal of government is a great idea as long as it applies only in the abstract or to somebody else. When it affects a particular group-I would be interested to hear Senator Townley's views on this-and these recommendations are seen to impact adversely on a group, even on a group which has been funding the Centre of Policy Studies, it says: `Enough; this must not be done'. Mr Matthews, the Guild's National President, has been reported in the Australian Financial Review as having said that Australia has now the most `effective prescription insurance systems in the world'. He also said that the suggestion to abolish the list of approved pharmaceutical benefits was not worthy of serious consideration. He criticised that chapter in the COPS book as being uninformed, superficial, uneducated and irresponsible.

I think one should add to that that the effect of what is advocated there would be to add about 6 per cent to the consumer price index as well, and to set up a health delivery service modelled on the United States experience which would ultimately be vastly more costly than the present system. In the United States 11 per cent of gross domestic product is spent on health services and in Australia the figure is 7 1/2 per cent. If we were to go down the American road, as well as the initial 6 per cent increase in the CPI we would have a much bigger kick in the CPI later because an additional $9 billion would be spent on health services in reaching the US level of 11 per cent of GDP.

It is interesting to note that the Pharmacy Guild seems to have got much less value for its dollar in sponsoring the COPS team than, for example, the Housing Industry Association, building materials having been exempted from the proposed list of commodities which should be subject to a value added tax, recommended by the Centre of Policy Studies some time ago.

Finally, I would invite other professional bodies, and in particular Dr Bruce Shepherd, who is indirectly, through the Australian Federation of Employers, a funder of the Centre of Policy Studies and the national priorities project, to give their views on those recommendations in the health chapter.

—Mr President, I think that the interjections Senator Chaney is making here are quite improper. QUESTION.PARA: If the Government fails to pass the `is it being fair dinkum' test, then Australia's already serious troubles will worsen.

I am not sure who will be marking the test, but I predict that the response of the Opposition will be along the lines of saying that we should not have cut back on anything that we have cut back on but that we should have cut back in total by more than we have. I am quite confident that in the main the response will be that almost all the cuts will be said to be terrible, inhuman and likely to induce the demise of Christian civilisation in Australia as we know it, but in the aggregate we should have cut more, although how this should have been done will not be specified. TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Finance and it follows his readiness to discuss what the Opposition's response will be to the mini-Budget. Baker, United States Secretary of the Treasury. Marsh, United States Secretary of the Army.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: VISIT TO AUSTRALIA BY MR JALANDONI

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday Senator Jessop asked me a long question about the visit to Australia by Mr Luis Jalandoni. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard the lengthy text of the answer.

ANSWER.PARA: Leave granted.
The answer reads as follows-

Mr Luis Jalandoni, who describes himself as the `international representative' of the National Democratic Front of the Philippines (NDF), is visiting Australia on a public speaking tour, at the invitation of a private group.
The NDF advocates violent action against the Government of the Philippines. It is an illegal organisation in the Philippines.

The New People's Army (NPA)-the military wing of the Communist Party of the Philippines (CCP)-is described by the NDF as its main armed force. The NPA is engaged in armed insurrection against the Government of the Philippines.

The Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs approved the issue of a visa and Mr Jalandoni arrived in Australia on 1 May. Prior to his entry Mr Jalandoni was cautioned about refraining from advocating the cause of violence whilst in Australia.

The decision to approve a visa in no way implied any recognition of Mr Jalandoni's status as an international representative of the NDF, nor acceptance of any claims by the NDF to international recognition.

The violent activity espoused by the NDF, against the democratically elected Government of the Philippines, is opposed by the Australian Government and is viewed as totally contrary to Australian values.

This point was made directly to Mr Jalandoni by an officer of the Department of Foreign Affairs in the course of a general discussion about the Philippines on 12 May. This meeting took place at the request of Mr Jalandoni.

The Departmental Officer also made clear to Mr Jalandoni that the Australian Government welcomes the restoration of Democratic institutions in the Philippines since President Aquino took office and strongly supports her Administration's commitment to maintain constitutional Government and the Democratic process.
Prior to issue of a visa to Mr Jalandoni the Government was not aware that he had attended the recent World Matabah conference in Misurata, Libya.
Mr Jalandoni has subsequently acknowledged his participation in that conference.

We have noted a report in a Philippine Newspaper that, at the recent meeting of so-called revolutionary movements held in Misurata, Libya, Mr Jalandoni is said to have stated that the NDF is seeking help from Foreign ``Anti-imperialist Forces'' in the ``militant fighting against U.S. imperialist Aggression'' in the Philippines.

The Government has seen unconfirmed reports that the NDF is proposing to open an office in Australia, including the report in the Far Eastern Economic Review of 26 March. That report did not as claimed by Senator Jessop, suggest that the reason for Mr Jalandoni's visit to Australia was to open a disguised front office for the NDF.
The Government is not aware of any such plans.
The Government assumes that as the Matabah is a Libyan-front organisation there would be some form of Libyan funding behind the establishment of any Matabah office in Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the sixth report for the sixty-second session of the Standing Orders Committee.

INTERJECT.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I inform the Senate that I have received the following letter, dated 13 May, from Senator Vanstone:

INTERJECT.PARA: Pursuant to Standing Order 64, I give notice that today I propose to move-
``That, in the opinion of the Senate, the following is a matter of urgency:
The need for the Government to reconsider the allocation of the Coastwatch contract to ensure adequate surveillance of Australia's northern coastline.''
More than the number of senators required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone Sen A.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That, in the opinion of the Senate, the following is a matter of urgency:
The need for the Government to reconsider the allocation of the Coastwatch contract to ensure adequate surveillance of Australia's northern coastline.

I am sure that most Australians do not need to be told just how carefully and for what reasons we need to watch our northern coastline. As Michael Yates, a journalist for the Melbourne Herald, put it on 19 March:

There are about 12,000 kilometres of rugged and mostly unpopulated coastline between Broome, Western Australia, and Cairns in Queensland. This is the top end: The front line in Australia's battle against hostile neighbours, drug runners, illegal fishermen and immigrants. It is a battle that many people believe we can never win.

I am sure that that quote outlines just why coastal surveillance is so important to Australia. The contract for coastal surveillance is let out by tender to private operators. Over the past three years that contract has been carried out by a firm called Skywest. Early this year the tender for a new contract was let out to another firm. On 12 March the Acting Minister for Transport, Mr Scholes, announced the award of the contract to Amann Aviation Pty Ltd. There were eight tenderers. The Minister said:
This Australian company, which will be based in Darwin, won the $17.7m contract from a field of eight tenderers and is expected to begin aerial surveillance in early May.

There are a number of interesting points in that statement. The Minister said `this Australian company' as if it already exists. However, he then acknowledges his error by saying `which will be based in Darwin'. The word `will' implies the future and that it is not based in Darwin at the moment. My information is that the company which has won the contract is not based anywhere at the moment-that it is not yet in existence. Nonetheless, that is basically what happened. Eight firms tendered for the coastal surveillance contract, and one firm, referred to as Amann Aviation-not the firm that has handled this matter in the past-won the contract.
The Minister for Transport, Mr Peter Morris, said on 18 March that he was quite satisfied that the tender had been properly let. He said:

The Tender Committee was satisfied that the successful tenderer had sound financial backing, fully understood the requirements of the contract on offer, had made realistic provision for costs, and that it had the necessary arrangements in hand to enable an early start up.

He was presumably referring to the Acting Minister's statement of early May. The current contractor, Skywest Airlines Pty Ltd, is a firm of 20 years experience. At the time of tendering it employed 161 staff, including 59 pilots; operated 29 aircraft, including three fan jets; and operated scheduled airline services from Perth to 13 destinations and from Port Hedland to five destinations. It was a very experienced firm, and it did not get the tender. In other words, its contract was not renewed. The contract has gone to the would-be firm referred to as Amann Aviation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is it incorporated?

—I think it is appropriate to ask what is Amann Aviation and whether, as Senator Baume asks, it is incorporated. I was informed in Estimates Committee E that Amann Aviation was owned by Robert Amann and his wife; Joseph Gostner, the chief pilot, and his wife-those four people holding together a 50 per cent share-and a company called Continental Venture Capital Ltd, owning the other 50 per cent. But it is interesting to note that the information given in the Estimates Committee indicates that the officer from the Department of Transport answering the question was not too sure of the facts. I will come back to that matter.

SPEECH.PARA: I am informed that a search done yesterday, admittedly, by one of the unsuccessful tenderers-but I have no reason to believe that the search was not properly conducted-does not show Amann Aviation as being an incorporated company anywhere. There is a firm called Myruse Pty Ltd-perhaps `ruse' is the appropriate terminology for that contract-and that firm does have as its principals Robert Amann and a number of other people, but there is no application to change the name to Amann Aviation Pty Ltd, nor can any incorporated company in the name of Amann Aviation Ltd be found.

So the contract has been let to a company that does not yet exist. It has been let to someone who had the limited experience of a charter and freight business at Camden in New South Wales and in central Queensland for the last five years. I am told that Amann Aviation, as it is to be, half of which is owned by Continental Venture Capital Ltd, is a company listed on the second board of the Sydney Stock Exchange. I am also told that its 1986 annual report suggests that the biggest deal the firm has been involved in up to date is a $1.4m contract, yet it is now participating in a $17m contract. It is worthwhile to note that the Federal Minister for Transport denies there has been anything wrong in the allocation of this contract-no impropriety and no failure adequately to assess the capacity of Amann Aviation. A newspaper article states:
A ministerial spokesman said the tender board was obliged to choose not only the cheapest-
in fact Amann Aviation was the cheapest-
but also the most technically competent.
It is required to consider each tenderer's technical and professional expertise, facilities and financial backing.

Yet, as I have said, the contract for the coastal surveillance of the northern coastline of Australia has not been renewed with Skywest, the firm that has adequately performed that contract for the past three years. It has not been given to anyone with any great experience in the aviation industry; it has been given, effectively, to a Mr Amann and his wife and a company that they are planning to set up. I cannot see how, that being the case, the Minister can possibly say that the tender assessment committee did anything other than simply give it to the lowest tenderer, because if one looked at the technical capacity and experience of Amann Aviation, being a two-bit charter pilot operation, one could not possibly say that one would award the contract to that firm.

What has the reaction been to the awarding of the tender to the so-called Amann Aviation? The Minister will undoubtedly say, as others have, that whenever a $17m tender is let the unsuccessful tenderers are unhappy, and one would accept that, but the complaints have not come only from them. The Australian Federation of Airline Pilots, which has no peculiar interest in seeing that one company or another gets the contract, said this:

The Government in believing that a person with a totally inadequate aviation background, no maintenance facilities, no check and training organisation, no appropriate licences and no management structure, just a line of credit from a high interest finance company and a bank, can establish the nationally vital coast watch services in the remote areas of Australia commencing in under two months and fully operational in six months, demonstrates the almost complete lack of understanding of aviation by the Minister. The awarding of this tender is absolute nonsense.

No one has pointed out to me any particular interest that the Australian Federation of Airline Pilots could possibly have in this matter. A headline in the Australian Financial Review of 17 March indicates the concern that other people have. It reads: `Grant of coastwatch tender to ``unknown'' criticised'. A headline in the Australian of 31 March reads: `Ability of coast watch operator questioned'. A headline in the Sydney Morning Herald of 6 April reads: `Dogfight rages as aviation novice gets $17m coast watch contract'. The General Aviation Association had this to say:

There is no possible way this company could qualify for this contract as they do not meet any of the requirements of the tender documents. We find it extremely difficult to understand the logic behind the granting of the coastwatch contract to Amann.

So it is not just the unsuccessful tenderer that is unhappy, but the deed has been done. The Government has made the decision to give the contract to Amann, so we might well turn our minds to how the Government is planning on handling the handover to Amann Aviation, as I understand it is going to be, from Skywest-how it is planning to phase out the old and bring in the new. Skywest's contract was to expire on 31 March, and late in February or early March, presumably when the Department knew who was going to get the tender, it was invited to extend its tender from the end of March to the end of June to accommodate the changeover, irrespective of who got the new tender, whether it was Skywest or someone else. On 12 March Skywest was notified that it did not have the contract but that the tenderer who had been awarded the contract had told the Department that he would have aircraft here in April, possibly with some bases operational in early May-we will see later that that is either a blatant lie or a joke-and that all his aircraft would be here and he would be fully operational by 1 July.

At the end of March the scene had changed. Department of Transport officers told the current tenderer that they had advised the unsuccessful applicant not to go ahead so quickly and that they wanted to extend the implementation of the phase-over. They said they wanted an extension. They asked Skywest, the current holder of this contract, whether it could provide an extension to cater for the incompetent bungling of the Department of Transport and the Department of Aviation and, for that matter, any public servant involved in this matter. So the unsuccessful tenderer has been asked, in effect, to pick up the bits left by the mess created by this Government. The unsuccessful tenderer, of course, has pilots resigning.

He has spotters resigning. They know that their company, the company for which they currently work has not got the contract. They have wives and children to feed and they have to find other jobs. Yet the Government is going to this firm that it has told that it will not have the contract and asking it to hold the situation together until the Minister gets his act together. It is very difficult to recruit staff for part time jobs when the people cannot be told how long they will be needed. That is the situation with the vital surveillance of our northern coast at the moment. It is an absolute bungle. The Government has not only awarded the contract to someone who is manifestly incapable of carrying it out; but it cannot even manage the switch to that person from the person who previously had the contract.

It is relevant to note that the Skywest firm, which had the contract, has been negotiating with the Government in the best of faith to sort out some circumstances under which it can help us and the Government by continuing with this contract. It has made a very detailed offer to continue under certain circumstances. The firm indicated that it required acceptance of that offer within seven days of the date of sending the letter, and that is today. My last conversation with the chief executive of Skywest indicated that the Government has not yet accepted that offer. The Government obviously treats the coastal surveillance of northern Australia as something to which it does not need to pay attention and on which it does not need to concentrate and to do well.

The Opposition canvassed these matters in the Estimates Committee. One might think when one is there that one is reasonably successful, however from the Estimates Committee transcript I see no less than eight occasions on which I was given an answer by the Department which proved to be not quite right when I checked the facts. Let me deal with the first one: Who is the tenderer? Dr Kay, an officer of the Department, said that the tenderer was trading under a different name, as R. and P. Amann Aircraft Hire. Senator Lewis then commented:
That was a business name . . .
Dr Kay responded:
It was a small company.
Senator Lewis proceeded:
But it was not a company at all, it was a business name.
Dr Kay then said:
Yes, it was a registered business name.
In other words, if one persists for long enough, one will get the right answer. That is not what I thought was the function of Estimate committees.

TALK.START.PARA: —What are they, then?

—The Government Whip may well ask what they are. They ought to be committees where one does not need to persist to get an honest and direct answer. In my view, misleading answers were given to some questions. Details were not appropriately given with respect to the tender assessment committee. We were told that people from all sorts of departments were on, and we were not told that the person from the Department of Aviation showed up at only three of the six meetings. We were told also that there was only one operator who had experience in this area; yet I am informed that there are at least two other operators apart from Skywest who had experience. It is not a big point, but it indicates that the person who was answering at the Estimates Committee was not, in fact, fully informed on the subject and did not have it all on board. We asked questions about the taking on of Skywest staff, and we were told that a transport officer who went around with Amann speaking to Skywest staff left the meetings whenever the question of recruitment was discussed. I have been told that that is absolute rubbish. I do not know who is lying. I do not know whether the person of the Estimates Committee was deliberately misleading me or whether he has been misled, but somebody surely has. We were told that at the time of tender the aircraft had to be indicated by tail number; yet now we find a number of things indicating that that is a load of rubbish. We were told that negotiations were proceeding at a time when Skywest said that it had not even had an implementation plan from the Government. I could go on about that but I shall not.

SPEECH.PARA: We now have more information to reinforce our concern. Dr Kay, the Chairman of the tender assessment committee, indicated in a number of places the tender assessment committee's satisfaction with the capacity of Amann to carry out this contract. But we now find out that the aircraft we were told that it had bought-one of which was here and more of which were coming-are not suitable. Aircraft are coming which are different from what we were told at the Estimate Committee not very long ago. We are not told that the plane that Amann was to buy, the 680 FL Commander, overheats and burns out engines at a typical surveillance speed of 140 to 160 knots. We might now very much question what will happen because, as anyone knows, when one changes aircraft one has different capital costs, different modification costs, different insurance costs, different air navigation charges, different airframe maintenance costs, different engine and propellor overhaul costs, different spare parts costs and so on. In other words, the whole ball game changes. There is now a clear indication that Amann Aviation was never at any stage in a position to carry out this contract adequately.

The Opposition claims today that this is a serious matter. I have indicated that the surveillance of the northern coastline is very important to Australia. I have indicated that a tender process was put in motion and that the successful tenderer is regarded by every commentator other than a Government one as being incapable of carrying out that contract. I have indicated that the changeover from the old to the new is being bungled in the extreme, and the people to whom we are looking to carry on the job are desperately trying to get from the Government some indication of what it wants. I have also indicated that either we were misled at the Estimates Committee or the Department was misled-one or the other-and that we now have information which confirms absolutely that the Department could not have been satisfied with respect to the capacity of Amann to carry out this contract. Accordingly, it is a matter of urgency that the Government should reconsider the coastal surveillance contract to ensure adequate surveillance of our northern coastline.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I cannot for the life of me understand how any person can claim that this is a matter of urgency and of such importance as to justify spending two hours debating the acceptance by the Government of a contract dealing with the surveillance of our coastline. Questions have been asked of me in the Senate, and a great deal of time was spent at the Estimates Committee by Senator Vanstone and Senator Lewis, in an endeavour to establish whether a proper process was involved in dealing with this tender and this contract. One can only wonder why Senator Vanstone has been chosen to carry the bag for Skywest. The truth is now out, of course: She has indicated that she is the spokesperson for Skywest.

—Mr Deputy President, I raise a point of order. It is quite disorderly to impugn the motives of the honourable senator. The expression that Senator Gietzelt used concerning Senator Vanstone is thoroughly objectionable to me, and I believe to the Senate, and it should be withdrawn.
—The remarks of Senator Gietzelt did imply improper motives to Senator Vanstone and should be withdrawn.

—If Senator Vanstone has any objections, I am quite happy to withdraw the remarks, but she herself said she had been in touch with Skywest and she had been told certain things. If she is prepared to carry its bag in this place, one is entitled to say that she is the spokesperson for that organisation.
—Order! Senator Gietzelt, you must not repeat the remarks that you have been ordered to withdraw. You should withdraw again and not continue on that line.
—I withdraw, Mr President.
—I raise a point of order.
—Is it a new point of order? The remark has been withdrawn.
—I did not understand, Mr Deputy President, that the remarks had been withdrawn. I understood the Minister to say that if I objected they would be withdrawn, and I indicate that I do object.
—On the second occasion he did withdraw the remarks.

—Senator Vanstone has said nothing new or startling in this debate. I really find it hard to appreciate why so much concern and so much enthusiasm are being expressed by the Opposition on this issue. It is obviously part of a very concerted campaign being waged by Skywest to try to upset a legitimate and properly conducted public tender process, as a result of which Skywest lost a very lucrative contract. That is accepted, but with every tender there is a winner and a loser. In this case, there are losers. Even if all the things that Senator Vanstone and her colleagues have raised over the past couple of months were substantiated in respect of Amann Aviation Pty Ltd, Skywest would still not have succeeded because it was the third lowest tenderer in this process. The Government takes the view, correctly, that it has an obligation not only to assess in the proper due processes the viability of the tenderers but also to save the public dollar, to save taxpayers' funds. It has done that precisely in the way in which it has dealt with this tender.

SPEECH.PARA: Since the announcement was made that the three-year coastal surveillance contract had been awarded to Amann Aviation Pty Ltd a barrage of sniping criticism has been levelled at the Government, and at me personally, alleging a whole host of improprieties. The Government and I reject that any evidence at all has been produced, other than assertions and allegations by a loser in the tendering process. All of them have emanated from Skywest. When one considers the hundreds of tenders with which government deals from time to time, it is a matter of regret that we should be spending so much time and energy on one particular complaint which has not been substantiated and for which there is no basis of fact.

We have heard today exactly the same sort of nonsense as Senator Vanstone and her colleagues parroted in the Senate Estimates committee and in questions that have been asked from time to time. They have not addressed some of the more important policy issues involved-for example, the rationale of coastal surveillance, which we accept is a very important objective for government and which the community expects. There is a need for protection of our country from agricultural diseases, illegal immigration, illegal fishing, drug running and all other matters that can be put under the general heading of misdemeanours or crimes. All we get is a rehash of the diatribe which amounts to nothing more than a squeal from the Opposition which clearly is batting for Skywest, which lost the contract.

Let us look at what has been said-that the Government has been improperly handling a particular contract. Firstly, it is the cheapest and most dubious of all the tactics to suggest that the Government has acted improperly. It was a scrupulously fair contest in which various government departments were involved in the contract processes. A committee ws set up involving the Department of Transport, the Department of Primary Industry, the Department of Aviation and the Australian Federal Police. Is the Opposition really saying that that group of men and women has acted improperly in some way in making a recommendation to government? Of course that is what it is alleging; that is what it is asserting. Senior members of the Opposition know the processes by which interdepartmental committees are set up from time to time to deal with these matters. Responsible senior officers write the terms of reference and the tendering documents and then invite public interest. On the basis of that they then assess those who seek to have their tenders considered.

The Department of Transport has the responsibility for organising the logistical basis of the Federal Government's coastal surveillance program, but it provides this service for other departments which, as clients, pay for the service according to their perceived needs. Many flights are scheduled by the Department of Transport in Canberra. The clients include the Department of Primary Industry, with respect to quarantine and fishery surveillance, and the Australian Federal Police, which has responsibility for law enforcement, including drug problems.

The current contract for littoral surveillance of the north Australian coastline from Broome in Western Australia to Cairns in Queensland was let to Skywest in April 1983, with a subsequent 12-month extension and another 3-month extension which was taken to 30 June this year. The new tender is for five bases and was advertised in August 1986. Eight tenders were received, of which six conformed with the specifications. Even within that process, there would be areas of disagreement. The three lowest offers covered all five bases-Broome, Darwin, Gove, Weipa-or alternately Thursday Island or Bamaga Island-and Cairns. All were technically able to meet the tender specifications. I might add-I cannot emphasise it too much-that the calling, the handling and the assessment of tenders for the coastal surveillance contract were conducted fully in accordance with procedures applying to all Commonwealth purchasing. They ar not procedures that were brought in in March 1983; they are procedures which have operated for decades under the way in which the Commonwealth deals with such matters.

Not only were the guidelines adhered to but also they were augmented by the establishment of a special tender assessment committee of the type to which I have previously referred. Each tender was carefully assessed from the standpoint of compliance with every aspect of the tender specifications. Interviews were held with each of the three lowest tenderers-Amann, Lloyd Aviation Jet Charter Pty Ltd and Skywest. Because the lowest tenderer, Amann, was new additional and particular care was taken to assess whether that organisation was capable of doing what was done in 1983, to check as thoroughly as propriety would permit-that is, we are dealing with matters of confidentiality and privacy-the company's bona fides and competence. Its potential competence was also examined. Independent checks by the committee were conducted with the police and with potential financiers. The Government, through its committees, took every available opportunity to check out the bona fides and the competence with which the successful tenderer would be able to meet the Government's requirements.

The tender assessment committee was obliged to, and did, satisfy itself that the lowest tenderer, Amann Aviation, has sound financial backing and fully understood the requirements of the surveillance contract and what was entailed from an operational and management standpoint. What more could be asked of any organisation, whether it be government or private, in respect of this matter? The committee assured itself that Amann had made realistic provisions for costs and had the necessary arrangements in train to enable an early startup in the event that the tender was successful. It was entitled to do that, and it did so. Despite this scrupulous and thorough analysis, we still have this concerted campaign being waged by Senator Vanstone and her colleagues, obviously on behalf of a dissatisfied person.

TALK.START.PARA: —On a point of order, Mr Deputy President: I take objection to the Minister's remarks. The implication clearly has been raised again that the Opposition-me in particular-is putting this matter on behalf of an unsuccessful tenderer. I would have thought that, had the Minister been listening to my speech, it would have been abundantly clear that that is not the case.
—Order! The honourable senator's point of order is valid. I ruled on that point before, Senator Gietzelt. That should be withdrawn-
—What the Opposition is seeking--
—It should be withdrawn, Senator.

—It is withdrawn. The Opposition is seeking to say that the Government has acted improperly. It is seeking to denigrate the Government, the public tender process and Amann Aviation to a point where the whole contract will be overturned. It knows that that will not happen, so why are we being subjected to this continual barrage of innuendo and allegations against the propriety of the Government and the officers concerned? The purpose would be to enable Skywest to resubmit its tender and retain the cash flow that it needs to keep its total operation running in the manner to which it has become accustomed. If Skywest felt that it had the matter all sewn up-and one is entitled to draw the conclusion that it did not have a competitive price-of course the Government was not only entitled but also obligated to go beyond the tender price submitted by that company.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us have no confusion about the motives behind the motion or the activities of Skywest. That company has lost a lucrative contract in a fair and square contest. It is upset with the umpire's decision and it is making sure that its views are being expressed in the Parliament. It is a very poor reflection on the Opposition that it should make the assertions that it has made about this contract. The Opposition has not been able to produce any evidence that Amann could not carry out its responsibilities. The same sort of licence is being given to Amann as was given to Skywest when it was the successful tenderer against another company in 1983. That company was entitled to feel aggrieved at that time. The Government was satisfied that the successful new tenderer-Skywest-had the maintenance and staffing infrastructure already in place. It also had some of the equipment, even though some upgrading was required. Any small business, any person seeking to enter this area, would need to set out the expenditure, equipment and certification required. Amann has satisfied the Government that in each of these areas it can carry out its tender obligations successfully.

One cannot deny that the loss of a contract potentially worth more than $18m over the next three years would be a severe blow to any organisation. However, business is business. Small business is small business. Competition is competition. It is precisely those processes to which members of the Opposition are objecting. It is the Government's responsibility to ensure that taxpayers' money is properly spent. Should we overturn the recommendation of a properly constituted committee and a properly constituted tender process? If so, on what grounds? Senator Vanstone has not given us any ground and I do not believe that any other honourable senator will be able to do so. Where is the evidence that there has been impropriety or lack of good business competence? Nothing that Senator Vanstone has said today has any basis at all; it is just innuendo, allegation, gossip and guesswork.

On the question of public expenditure, Amann's bid was 28 per cent lower than the current contract amount being paid to Skywest. That is a considerable saving-28 per cent difference. Yet members of the Opposition, who spend half their time talking about waste watch operations and the way in which taxpayers' money has to be protected, complain when this is applied in practice, not in rhetoric, allegations and gossip. The Government is being put on trial by these inane and weak allegations from Senator Vanstone and obviously her colleagues.

The largest single complaint being put out by those who backed Skywest's tender is that Amann Aviation is new and unknown. That is an old scare tactic from way back. This is supposed to be the Opposition that claims to represent small business. This is the Opposition that claims we must save money, wherever that can be done. This is the Opposition that believes in competition. Yet when the Government applies these basic business principles to its tendering processes, it does not get support from the Opposition but criticism, allegations, innuendoes and suggestions of impropriety. Impropriety on whose part? That of the Minister for Transport or that of senior officers in the Australian Federal Police, the Department of Primary Industry, the Department of Aviation or the Department of Transport? To whom does this allegation of impropriety apply? All we have is a consistent whinge by someone who lost in a fair and competitive way. It is about time that the Opposition accepted the fact that in every possible way the Government has operated this contract in a competent, business like fashion and in a way which will save the taxpayers about $3m. To that extent, the Government stands on its record and not on the rhetoric of the Opposition.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have listened with some care to the speeches of Senator Vanstone and the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Senator Gietzelt) on this matter of urgency. Although I have no brief for or knowledge of Amann Aviation Pty Ltd-I do not know it from a bar of soap-I am concerned at the virulence, especially by way of interjection, with which this business firm has been attacked. Presumably it attempted to get a contract and was successful. I really cannot see that that sort of attack is justified and should be made here under privilege. It is not an argument against any organisation that it cannot do a thing because it has not done it before. The theory that nothing must ever be done for the first time is too common in government and it is quite improper that it should be raised here. It has been put to the Senate that Skywest Airlines Pty Ltd should continue to have the contract, despite the fact that if the Minister's figures are to be believed-I have no doubt that they are reliable and the Opposition can tell me if they are not-Amann's tender was 28 per cent lower. We all know of the traditional situation in which the person doing the job puts in a tender and loses because somebody else undercuts him. But that is business, as Opposition senators ought to know. That is what it is all about. Although Amann has not done this job before, it is a fairly routine aviation task. It does not involve the running of a responsible passenger service or an air ambulance, or anything like that. It is a routine task, the parameters of which can be laid down and established fairly readily. I take it that that has been done and I assume that the Government, in accepting the tender, has satisfied itself that certain requirements will be met within a certain time.

SPEECH.PARA: The only other point of substance which the Opposition has raised is that there has been an aircraft change. I would have thought it was proper and responsible that if Amann-whoever it is-found on investigation that the aircraft it proposed to use was not satisfactory for prolonged running at surveillance speeds in tropical temperatures, it should change the aircraft. I agree that something would have been wrong had the tenderer decided to proceed with that aircraft, after it was established as unsuitable. There would have been the risk of a high rate of breakdown and things of that kind. As I understand it, that is not the case. The people concerned understood that that aircraft was not suitable for that function and as a result they are changing it. It would seem that this change of aircraft has caused delays in implementation. I would have thought that that would be so. The Minister has not said it, but perhaps a later Government speaker-if there is one-might check that out. I think it would be useful for the Senate to know whether the delays were due to the aircraft change. From any reasonable point of view it would seem that that might be the case.

This matter of urgency takes up the Senate's time unnecessarily. At least it will have the advantage of putting Amann and the Government on their toes. I assume that since Amann is aware of the degree of opposition here to its successful tender and the feeling that Skywest should have got the contract, it will do its very best to do the job properly. I think that any reasonable business would do that.

Senator Knowles put her finger on the point when she inadvertently, or perhaps advertently, agreed with the Minister that surveillance was important. This urgency motion is important because of the larger issue it raises, which is the security of northern Australia. The Democrats are not convinced that the Opposition has made any kind of case to justify the reconsideration of the coastwatch contract at this stage. We do not propose to vote for the urgency motion. We do not believe that it is a matter of urgency for the Senate. However, we agree that surveillance should be improved. We must consider that matter. I feel it proper at this stage of the debate that we also consider, as should have happened at the beginning, Australia's surveillance problems in the north, with particular regard to the defence of this continent, because Australia is not adequately defended.
