The Government's recent review of Australia's defence capabilities clearly demonstrated this.

The adequate surveillance of Australia's vast and largely uninhabited coastline in the north and west and our huge exclusive economic zone must be one of the most difficult defence tasks in the world. We need a consensus of view and co-operative effort rather than too much quibbling over details, and statements that people will fail before they even start, which is not a very constructive thing to say-and in this case presumably referring to people who have already spent money, bought aircraft and are setting up bases. It seems to me that to go back to square one is not really helping our task. Australia must have adequate means of surveillance of the coastline and its neighbouring waters. What we need in this modern world-the Democrats have said this before, and I say it again-is a computer-monitored coastal surveillance system which could be locally designed and manufactured, which Australian industry has the potential to do. It would be an automatic high technology system. One strategy for automatic monitoring would be a system of registering changes of movements that are checked against known and expected changes. Detailed scans could be carried out at any point where significant aberrations were pin-pointed. This would make surveillance of the entire coastline feasible, allowing the detection of smuggling and illegal entry.

The real point in considering the degree of surveillance is that it should depend wholly on other circumstances. Those circumstances bear on the risk to Australia and the security or otherwise of our northern approaches. Granted a situation like the present one, in which most of our defence forces are located in the south eastern section of Australia and are known by a potential enemy to be in that part of the continent and not capable of being moved to the north and west quickly, and granted a possible future zonal rivalry in the waters to our north, it is possible to see a situation in which any amount of surveillance that we could muster-ten times what we have now-would not be enough. When most of our population is in the south and very few of our resources are in the north, we could have a situation in which that northern area is virtually in a state of siege. We probably could not afford or handle such a situation adequately. We have to use diplomatic and other means to ensure that that situation does not develop. That is the most important consideration at the bottom line of any discussion of surveillance of the northern approaches.

On the other hand, given an effective neutralising of our northern approaches, given good relations with our neighbours and given a good defence presence in the north, the surveillance issue does not assume the importance it would otherwise do, and necessarily so. When I talk of a good defence presence, I mean the reality and the appearance to nations outside Australia of forces sufficiently powerful, flexible and mobile to discourage any thoughts of attempting invasion of this country. Those forces ipso facto-their mere presence, the fact that they are exercising in the northern waters-would discourage the other areas of surveillance that would concern us, being illegal entry and smuggling.

It is important to realise when talking about the present coastwatch contract, which implies basically a fairly crude surveillance technique-an aircraft flying over areas regularly or irregularly and using spotters-that the ability to evade such a system is so easy on relatively low profile activities, such as drug smuggling and illegal immigration, as to be laughable. People have to work to some sort of schedule. If one wanted to drop somebody in and get past aerial surveillance of this kind, it would not be difficult to do so. One has only to watch for a while and to note the schedule of the aircraft.

TALK.START.PARA: —No night surveillance.

—No night surveillance, as the honourable senator says. The situation is completely open-a net whose mesh is wide open and which allows small fish and even large fish to slip through without difficulty. If one is to take the position seriously, we should not have the token system we have now. We should be looking at our scientists achieving purely automated radar systems which can use electronic means constantly to monitor what is going on in the north, and to pick up areas of aberration, so that they can be investigated closely. This is where aircraft are desirable and necessary. Plainly, once an area of aberration is picked up, it must be investigated. As the situation now is, the areas of aberration, especially regarding low profile activities, will escape detection. Whether it is Amann or Skywest that operates the system will not make the slightest difference. That is a matter of serious concern to this country.

SPEECH.PARA: While our surveillance methods are of that kind, the Australian Democrats believe that it is essential for us to pursue with intelligence the diplomatic and strategic options that are available to us. We see our best means of defence as the maintenance of close friendly relations with our neighbours and the removal of prime nuclear targets from Australian soil, targets such as North West Cape and Pine Gap. In this context, it is of vital importance to the South Pacific region, and indeed to the world, that a workable and thorough South Pacific Nuclear Free Zone Treaty is established and strictly enforced as soon as possible. Without that there will be tensions, strains, rivalries and perhaps countries allying themselves on one side or the other, as we are beginning to see even now. If those zonal rivalries arise it could greatly increase the danger to Australia and greatly increase the need for surveillance, to the point where it became an almost impossible burden for the community to bear.

The Government will also be aware, of course, that the South Pacific Nuclear Free Zone Treaty makes it a binding legal international obligation on Australia that Australian uranium cannot be exported. The Government, for the good of international relations, particularly in the Pacific zone to our north, ought to realise that it can no longer allow the export of Australian uranium to France. By crossing that bridge, the Government would begin to approach something which would give us a rational, controllable situation to our north. That is necessarily the first step that has to be taken towards the rationalisation of a situation which otherwise will become intolerable.

The most likely physical threats to Australia, as I have said, are the threats of smuggling and illegal immigration. They are particularly insidious because of their low profile and physical presence, which make them very difficult to detect, and of course because of their potentially massive harmful effects. Invasion and conquest of an Australian territory or protectorate must also be considered, as must the invasion of a close ally of Australia such as Papua New Guinea. These are far more likely threats than a physical attack on Australia itself. We cannot consider surveillance of the north without considering our relationship with Papua New Guinea.

I noticed that yesterday Senator Walters in another context called the Democrats left wing because we had advocated some sort of defence relationship with Papua New Guinea. Indeed, I did advocate such a relationship, but my reasoning was sound and very much in the context of this debate, namely, that it is necessary for us to consider Papua New Guinea as probably the most important place that is necessary to be defended other than our own territory-and possibly as important as our own territory. If one goes to the Torres Strait and looks at the areas of low sandbanks and narrow waters, one can see that New Guinea is our northern gateway to the rest of the world. Any threat to the security of Papua New Guinea is a threat to the security of Australia. If Senator Walters does not realise that, I suggest that she is living far too far away in the south, in Tasmania, to understand what happens up in the north. But Tasmania, regardless of its problems, is still, as I understand it, a part of Australia. Senator Walters ought to do her homework on this matter and get herself a little more informed.

It is worth noting that invasion and conquest of part of Australia-let us say, north-western Australia-and conditions of a world war or of total anarchy resulting from a world war would create a situation which would make it very difficult indeed for Australia to regain that territory. This may seem a truism, but it is the bottom-line consideration of great importance to us-or it should be.

The upshot of all this is that we must start from scratch and rethink our entire coastal defence policy, because adequate coastal defence is the only way in which we can handle that surveillance problem. There is, I think, some indication that the Government is doing that. We have encouraged that while we have been in this Parliament. We have encouraged the Government not to think of a blue water navy but of fast, mobile ships-perhaps hydrofoils-all missile armed, that can deal with the coastal situation and we are delighted to see that that is now being done. We should have a modern small ship navy, augmented by submarines-we agree on the submarines-with wire guided torpedoes and fast, heavily armed missile ships possibly, as I have said before, in hydrofoil combination. All the material is there. This is the real bottom line for surveillance. This argument over whether Skywest or another company, Amann, should have the contract is, frankly, a very minor and somewhat sordid intrusion on an important subject.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Knowles Sen S.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will state the matter of urgency we are debating today:

SPEECH.PARA: That, in the opinion of the Senate, the following is a matter of urgency:
The need for the Government to reconsider the allocation of the Coastwatch contract to ensure adequate surveillance of Australia's northern coastline.

What we are really considering in this debate is the true protection of the northern coastline of Australia from the people that Senator Vanstone mentioned earlier-drug runners, illegal fishermen, illegal immigrants and hostile neighbours. We saw probably the greatest display of ministerial ducking, diving and weaving that we have seen on this subject from the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Senator Gietzelt) when he addressed the Senate earlier and said that the matter was not important enough to discuss in this place. He said that a matter of urgency about Australia's surveillance is not important enough to discuss in this place. It is absolutely disgraceful to say that that is not an important issue for this Parliament.

He also made the assertion-as he has done repeatedly in this place-that when this contract was granted to Amann Aviation Pty Ltd, it was in the same position as Skywest Airlines Pty Ltd was in when it got the tender in 1982. The Minister continually said `1983' when attempting to correct himself after saying `1984'. He would not have the faintest idea when Skywest got the contract: It was back in 1982. As Senator Durack pointed out to the Minister on 31 March, Skywest had been in business for over 20 years; had employed 161 staff, including 59 pilots; was operating 29 aircraft; and was running scheduled services from Perth and Port Hedland to many destinations in Western Australia. Skywest sent the Minister a copy of its record, yet again the Minister today had the audacity to say that Skywest was in the same position as Amann.

Let us look at the position of Amann. This Government is undertaking-and continues to undertake-a snow job of absolute blizzard proportions on this Parliament. The Australian people will not wear it when this contract collapses. The Minister for Veterans' Affairs, Senator Gietzelt, who represents the Minister for Transport and Minister for Aviation (Mr Peter Morris) in this chamber, has deliberately not answered any questions asking for clarification put to him by Senator Durack, Senator Archer and me over a number of weeks. That is a disgrace of the largest proportions. But the facts, as of this day, are as follows: Amann, as it was when it was awarded the contract, was a $2 shelf company-a position far different from that of Skywest when it was awarded the contract. In order that Senator Robertson and Senator Reynolds, the Labor senators who are to follow me in this debate, do not also say that I am simply pushing a barrow for Skywest, I will say right here and now in unequivical terms that I am not simply pushing a barrow for Skywest; I am pushing a barrow for the continued secure surveillance of the northern coastline.

To return to Amann, it had a totally inadequate aviation background, no maintenance facility, no check and training organisation, no appropriate licences and no management structure when it was awarded this contract. And this is the company that this Government considers is at a suitable stage to to take over this business. Dr Kay, who gave evidence to Estimates Committee E on 9 April and who is the Acting Senior Assistant Secretary, Safety Operations and Pollution Branch, Maritime Safety Division, said that, yes, Amann was trading under a different name when it got the contract; yes, it was a small company; and yes, it was only a registered business name. That is the type of business background to which this Government has given the contract. Its experience is nil. I believe it had only one aircraft. The company was run by a man and his wife, and I believe that now it also has a pilot and his wife. I suppose the local cat and dog and mouse and anything else that runs around, if it wants to, can be part of it.

We are very concerned about the staff and the training of professional people. I have had the privilege of going out on a coastwatch exercise. The pilot and the observers were some of the most professional people I have had the privilege to watch operate. The way in which they conducted their business was absolutely scrupulous. These professional people were promised that they would be considered by Amann for continuing employment. They have consistently asked for assistance both from members of parliament and from the Department to ensure that they get some continuity. They had the audacity to ask questions about salaries, zone allowances, leave entitlements, medical cover and the like. Presumably because of this these pilots who are experienced in this business have now been overlooked. They were advised yesterday that it looks as though only three pilots from Skywest will be taken on. Heaven knows what the fate of the observers will be.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wonder where the money is coming from.

—Exactly. I wonder where its money is coming from, too, because Amann is offering about $9,000 per annum less to pilots starting with it, hoping to high heaven that it can raise the amount later on and get the extra money from the Government so that it does not come out of its pocket. It is a great tragedy. As I mentioned earlier, these people have written to members of parliament asking for assistance for their livelihoods and for their families. Yet a senator from this Parliament, Senator McKiernan, wrote back to those people saying, in effect: `Sorry to hear about your problems, but join a union and they will all be solved'. That was the thrust of a letter from Senator McKiernan. For those who are interested, Senator McKiernan has a very long record with the unions. Therefore, his impartiality is not evident on this problem.

SPEECH.PARA: The role of Mr Ramsey is another thing. Mr Ramsey, from the Department, went around some of the bases and, when he got to Broome at 6 p.m. on a Saturday night, he asked the co-ordinator that a meeting be held at 8 a.m. on Sunday. Of course the co-ordinator could not get in contact with all the people on the Saturday night and he advised Mr Ramsey that they could not meet until a later stage. This man, whom this Government and the Department said was not present at the negotiation stage of determining staffing requirements, said that he would be there for those meetings, and he insisted that the meetings be arranged for a time when he would be there; he had to be there for the meeting with staff. The co-ordinator also found then that that meant a re-organisation of a scheduled coastwatch flight. Mr Ramsey specifically downgraded the coast- watch to have all staff present. Flights were curtailed on his authorisation so that the staff and he could be present. This Minister, this Government and this Department have said that that man was not present. Yet he deliberately curtailed coastwatch flights to make sure that the meetings took place.

This contract has already been extended from 31 March to 30 June. Skywest has been told that it may get a further extension, or that it may be requested to take out another extension. It has requested that the Government advise it by today whether it will have to take the job on for a further three months. At 1 o'clock Perth time the Skywest managing director was going to phone me if he had heard anything. He has not done so. It is now ten past four, eastern standard time. He has not heard from the Government as to whether it needs Skywest to carry on the contract. Yet today is the deadline.

Skywest has offered to extend the contract at the normal rate plus 15 per cent. It is in a very difficult position. It does not know whether its pilots are staying or going. It appears that most of them are staying because they have been overlooked by Amann. But it does not know whether its observers are staying. The Government says that it wants observers to do further training. How on earth can the observers do further training before joining Amann if they are expected to stay with Skywest? Mr Ramsey said that they will find that one day they are paid by Skywest and the very next day they will be paid by Amann. Unless they do their comprehensive training overnight, how on earth can they do their training and at the same time maintain critical surveillance on the northern coastline? Understandably, Skywest is winding down its staff and the service is definitely at risk. We are concerned about the service being at risk.

There was only a three-quarters of a million dollars difference between Amann's tender and the next one. Yet the Minister, only a little while ago, said that the difference was $3m. Once again he has not told the truth to this Parliament. Amann has changed its aircraft. Yet Dr Kay, in response to the question by Senator Lewis, `Did you satisfy yourself that this company would be able to provide adequate aircraft?', said: `Yes'. Obviously, the answer should have been no, because it has now had to change its aircraft. There is a difference in the cost of aircraft of $250,000 per aircraft.

Senator Vanstone read out a great shopping list of problems associated with the change of aircraft; so there will be many more costs involved in what will now be the aircraft brought in by Amann. Yet Amann and the departmental representatives at Estimates committee hearings, said that the aircraft had been ordered and that the modifications were under way. How on earth can the aircraft have been ordered and the modifications be under way when the company is now saying: `We cannot get the aircraft and we are now getting another one'?

TALK.START.PARA: —They said that they would be arriving soon.

—It has said that they are arriving soon; it has said that for weeks on end. The Minister has not answered questions. The situation as to continuing viability is absolutely outrageous. The continuing viability is at risk because of the costs that this company will have to incur. It admitted that it did not take on this contract with profit in mind. It admitted that when it took it on. Mr Amann stated publicly that he wanted a higher public profile in aviation and therefore tendered for this contract with no profit in mind. The Department of Transport is also fully aware that Amann Aviation has a paid up capital of $2 and presently has a total reliance on this contract. It has no other activities from which it can expect to fund the loss on the coastwatch contract.

SPEECH.PARA: Questions must now be asked as to how long Amann will be able to sustain coastwatch operations before compounding losses force his withdrawal, voluntarily or otherwise, and therefore how long it will be before Australia will suffer a total breakdown in surveillance of its northern coastline. This question must also be considered in light of the fact that people have been asked to withdraw operations in certain areas. The switch by Amann Aviation to a totally different type of aircraft has not just impacted on its own commercial viability; it has also prejudiced the entire activity of surveillance of the northern coastline and has therefore directly impacted on the national interest. That is just not good enough.

The other aspect that is relevant in this debate is the balance of payments. We are currently in a balance of payments crisis; yet aircraft at approximately $580,000 each are being bought overseas. The Minister told the Estimates Committee that he could not care less about the impact on the balance of payments. Senator Gietzelt said;
I am not aware of any and I do not think it was necessary to do so.

It is just outrageous to think that in the current climate it is not being treated seriously by this Minister. To wrap it up, the absurdity goes one stage further. The letterhead of a letter that was received by pilots yesterday from Amann had a photograph of a Skywest plane, showing the Skywest logo and the Skywest call sign. There was a photograph of a Shrike Commander on a letterhead from Amann.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Robertson Sen E.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think I should read the motion because although there have been two speakers from the Opposition their contributions did not have a great deal of relevance to it. Senator Knowles alluded to it briefly during the course of her remarks. The motion reads:

SPEECH.PARA: That, in the opinion of the Senate, the following is a matter of urgency:
The need for the Government to reconsider the allocation of the Coastwatch contract to ensure adequate surveillance of Australia's northern coastline.

I, as much as anyone in this place, am aware of the need for coastal surveillance of the northern coastline. I am not the least bit interested in who does it, as long as it is done effectively. Perhaps I ought to remind the Senate of what the needs for coastal surveillance are. They have not been mentioned so far, although Senator Mason, in a very reasoned address, referred to them.

Firstly, we must look at the problem of drug running, either by boats or by aircraft, in the Northern Territory. The Senate will know that aircraft can land on many of the smaller strips in the Northern Territory, and they are a problem. The second reason for coastal surveillance is to watch out for illegal visitors. I use that phrase when I refer to Indonesian fishermen because they often become illegal immigrants when they land on the coast. I also refer to illegal visitors in the sense of those on pleasure craft who bring pets with them or, if nothing else, dump their garbage along the coast. Of course, as everyone knows, that brings the possibility of exotic disease. The third area, which is most important, is that of illegal fishing-not so much by the small Indonesian illegal fisherman; rather, the poaching by the major concerns and the fishing by Australian or joint venture boats outside the defined areas or outside the times when it has been agreed fishing should take place.

Northern surveillance has been a long time interest of mine-basically, I suppose, because I am from the Northern Territory. The Northern Territory, Queensland and Western Australia are the areas which are most involved because they are the front-line States and Territories. I indicate that my concern about surveillance is real. Once again I indicate that I have no interest in who gets the contract, as long as we have effective surveillance.

I appreciate the concern of Senator Vanstone. Quite clearly, the matter has less relevance to South Australia specifically, although obviously she is interested in Australia generally. She raised this matter during Estimates committee hearings. Most of the topics she raised today were dealt with during those hearings. She raised four new issues, and I will deal with them very briefly. She said, firstly, that the 680FL motors were overheating. We know this, and the contractor has agreed to provide different and better engines and aircraft at no extra cost. Secondly, she said that extra registration and insurance costs would occur, and this would mean that the contract would go up. Quite clearly, the contractor has agreed that there will be no additional cost-it would be outside the tender. Thirdly, she said that the company has no base in Darwin. I assure her that the company has an office and staff in Darwin at this present time. She talked a great deal about Amann being a $2 company, and I will mention that later. However, I have evidence here that Amann Aviation Pty Ltd is the new name of Myruse Pty Ltd, which was registered in New South Wales.

Hansard will show that during the time of the Fraser Government I asked many questions about coastal surveillance. There were problems with the former contractor during the time of Senator Vanstone's Government. The contractor had a set schedule and flew every day at the same time. As a result, fishermen simply hid in the mangroves, waited until a plane had gone over and then went about their business. Untrained staff were recruited by the company. I remember one case that I brought to the attention of the Senate of a honeymoon couple who took on the job of being spotters. I hope that these are not the qualified, professional people that Senator Knowles referred to. The total project was not co-ordinated, and I believe that that was one of the major problems. If action was required, it took too long to do something and the boats moved away.

The present Government set out early in its period of office to correct the identified problems. The Australian Federal Police was put in charge through its control centre, and it introduced better procedures and the training of the staff by the Department of Transport. I have an interest also because the Senate Standing Committee on National Resources, in its report entitled `The Adequacy of Quarantine' had this to say:

The Committee recommends . . . the surveillance program be reviewed immediately, particularly in regard to the training of observers, the need for staggered flight times and the provision of the necessary facilities to respond to surveillance sightings.

All of this was taken note of by the present Government and incorporated into the new tender. Let me sum up this section by saying that the present Government understands the problem and has taken appropriate action, and we are discussing that action today.

The history of the current situation has been covered by previous speakers. There were some inaccuracies which I will come to later. But let me make this point: Surveillance is now operating and will continue to operate. There are plans in position for Amann to take over on 12 September, or whatever date has been agreed to. So the fact that we have surveillance operating makes a farce of the search--

TALK.START.PARA: —What is the date?

—The honourable senator will have his opportunity to speak. There has been adequate surveillance. The Opposition has asked for this and it has got it. So this urgency motion is an utter farce. The surveillance is being carried out at present by a contractor who is favoured by the Opposition. I am going to outline later why the contract was not let to Skywest. However, this was certainly not because there was any dissatisfaction with the service. We are happy to extend its time to June, and further if necessary, so that adequate surveillance can be continued.
—When are you going to let them know?

—This decision had nothing to do with the adequacy of surveillance. That company is totally aware of the situation. I think the honourable senator has been misled and she should settle down a bit. Criticisms of the Amann operation were put by the Opposition to a Senate Estimates committee. Although those criticisms have been answered, they have not been accepted. They have been put publicly through the media. They have been put through Mr Lloyd in the other place and they have been answered there. Let me repeat those criticisms. We are told that this company is a $2 shelf company. Myruse has operated a charter company for five years. That is the company we are speaking about. It is suggested that Amann has no staff and no facilities. It intends to buy these, as would any other business. One certainly would not go out before one was awarded a contract and start buying up bases or aircraft or recruiting staff. The staff will be recruited, as indicated quite clearly by Senator Mason and the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Senator Gietzelt). The 15 questions that were put to Amann were answered, and I understand that the Sydney Morning Herald aviation expert, Mr Ballantyne, commented that these were all acceptable answers to the questions put by the Opposition.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us look at Amann Aviation. The principal is a businessman, Robert Amann. He is a private pilot and he is in partnership with the chief pilot and the wives of both men. He is not a novice in the industry, as has been indicated. He has been involved in it for some years. He has operated a charter and freight company out of Camden airport. But nevertheless, as indicated so well by Senator Mason, one does not have to have experience in every field to move into it. One wonders how many of the businessmen sitting opposite us at the present time had experience when they moved into their ventures. They have the money and they buy the expertise. But Mr Amann has his chief pilot. He is a private pilot and he has expertise in running the business. He has purchased 14 Commander aircraft, and we have already mentioned these. There have been problems with the contract. This is accepted. Only four aircraft have arrived and the rest will be here in early July. Perhaps that is not good, but that is his worry. He has to have them here to take over at the agreed time. But once again, the purpose of the motion which is in front of us is that there is not adequate surveillance. I come back to the point that regardless of any problems that Mr Amann may have-and he has not got any-surveillance is being continued-it is being carried out by Skywest, the company favoured by the Opposition.

Let us look at the aircraft that he has bought. Despite the fact that Skywest sent a couple of its men to trail Mr Amann around the United States of America, they still cannot find out where he is getting the planes from. It is rather interesting that Skywest, the group that is being pushed by the Opposition at present, has thought it necessary to send two people to the United States to trail Mr Amann to try to find out about his business venture. It does not reflect very well on that company. The aircraft which have been bought-we know the details about them-are more suitable for surveillance. They are descended from the aircraft purpose-built for the US Army and the US Air Force. They are much better than the units that Skywest is operating. The units are ideally suited for northern surveillance. They are larger, more powerful and they have a 30 per cent greater cruising range of 1,300 miles as against 1,000 miles. In addition, they can carry more surveillance equipment and more personnel and they can travel at a greater speed should that be necessary.

Let us look at the tender that has been shouted about so much today. Firstly, the tender value, which has been published, was $17.7m. The proposition that was put by Amann was, according to my figures, $2.5m lower than Skywest.

TALK.START.PARA: —Not lower than Lloyd Aviation.
—I did not say anything about Lloyd Aviation; I said that it was lower than Skywest.
—Yes, but you are misrepresenting the circumstances.
—No. The honourable senator is being stupid again, as she was before.
—You misrepresented it.
—The honourable senator misrepresented the Minister and told an untruth, for which I did not pull her up.
—I did not.
—Yes, the honourable senator did.
—Mr Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. I seek a withdrawal. I have not told an untruth and I ask the honourable senator to withdraw that statement.
—If the honourable senator requests that the statement be withdrawn, I would ask the honourable senator to do so.

—Yes, I am happy to withdraw it. What the honourable senator said quite clearly is known and will be shown in Hansard. Skywest was the third lowest out of eight. The tender is for a three-year contract and was awarded after evaluation by the Department of Transport, the Department of Aviation, the Department of Primary Industry and the Coastal Protection Unit of the AFP. Also, the financial arrangements entered into and available to Amann were investigated by those who were evaluating the tender. Agreement was reached by Skywest for extension of its contract to 30 June to ensure that there would be an orderly handover. It certainly is a fact that Skywest was the only tenderer currently operating aircraft. Out of the eight who put in names, Skywest was the only one, as I understand it, which had aircraft operating. But that is not surprising. I would think that not many firms would keep 14 planes on the ground in the likely eventuality of getting a contract.

SPEECH.PARA: Even if Amann Aviation had not been awarded the contract, Skywest would not have got it because it was third on the list. There are 1,200 kilometres of coastline to be patrolled by 14 aircraft, each with a pilot and two observers-exactly the same as the Skywest procedure. That is the job that Amann will go ahead and do.

TALK.START.PARA: —When?
—When it is required to under the terms of the contract. She has no indication that it will not be doing it. The time is clearly set out when it will be doing it.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me list our conclusion. Firstly, the Government appreciates the need for surveillance and has organised appropriate organisation under the Australian Federal Police. Secondly, the contract to Amann followed the normal guidelines and satisfied procedures set by this Government and by previous governments. Amann Aviation was investigated in all aspects and found suitable. It was successful for a number of reasons including the cost tendered and the type of aircraft it was prepared to buy. There is no need to reconsider the allocation-everything is proceeding. At present there is adequate surveillance, and this will continue. In other words, this so called urgency motion is a farce and a waste of time.

In the one minute left to me I will further emphasise the points made by the Minister. First, the tendering process is absolutely proper and strictly controlled and that was the case on this occasion. Secondly, the Government is not in the business of overturning contracts because of rumours and gossip. Nor is the present Government in the business of rigging contracts for rich and powerful friends. We go through the normal tendering procedures.

TALK.START.PARA: —That happens only in Queensland.

—As Senator Reynolds says, that happens in other parts of Australia. I think it is most unfortunate that this motion has been moved. Not only are we wasting time debating it, but one wonders why it has been brought before the Senate today. It seems most unfortunate that the normal procedures of government-the letting of tenders, investigating them and making sure that they go to the right person-have been overlooked in this case. One wonders, if the tender had been let to Skywest at an additional cost of $2.5m, what Senator Michael Baume and his Waste Watch Committee would have had to say about that. One wonders what the rest of the Liberal Party would have to say about a tender not being let to a contractor who was able to offer the service that was required at a cost much lower than that proposed by the next tenderer or the person operating at present. I repeat, the urgency motion moved by Senator Vanstone is a farce and a waste of time. One must question why she has raised the matter in the Senate today.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boswell Sen R.L.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I believe that the Senate is indebted to Senator Vanstone for raising this matter of absolute importance to the nation. I think that everyone should be very thankful that she has had the gumption to bring it forward. At the outset of my contribution I make it quite clear that I am not pushing Skywest's barrow-neither am I condemning Amann Aviation. I bring before the Senate the irregularities in the way the contract has been let. I have been in business for many years so I know that one cannot let a contract to a firm in these terms.

SPEECH.PARA: The contract was let in the name of R. and P. Amann Aircraft Hire, which is a registered name but not that of a registered business or proprietary limited company. The contract was let in the name of Amann Aviation Pty Ltd. That is the first irregularity. One cannot let a contract, or go to contract, in one name and receive the benefit in another name. That is the first irregularity. The second irregularity is that there is no such firm as Amann Aviation Pty Ltd-at least, until yesterday that firm was not registered. That is the second irregularity. The Government, having found those two irregularities, should have immediately cancelled the contract. It should have said that everything was not in order and retendered. That would be the obvious thing to do. Any government that calls for tenders for the items it needs would have responded in that way.

The third irregularity-and the arrangement is full of irregularities-is that the contract was let for 14 S80FL Sky Aero Commander aircraft. However, we now find that that is not what the tenderer is supplying. The tenderer is supplying a different aircraft. If the Department of Aviation was not satisfied with 14 S80FL Sky Aero Commander aircraft, it should have said: `You do not win the tender because the planes are not acceptable'. The Department should have specified what was an acceptable plane. The contract has been awarded, but now different aircraft are to be used. The more times we go over this matter the more irregularities come to light.

The main problem as I see it is that the aerial surveillance contract for the Great Barrier Reef expires on 30 June. Until now no tenders have been called. That frightens me as a Queensland Senator, because on 30 June there will be no aerial surveillance of the Great Barrier Reef. We know from experience that, if there is no surveillance, we offer an open, lay down misere to clam poachers and a number of other people to go on to the reef. As a Senator for Queensland I am particularly concerned about that. I am concerned about surveillance of the northern coastline, about the many uninhabited miles of coastline around the gulf and the estimated 1,500 airstrips throughout northern Australia, many of which date from World War II and are extremely isolated.

In March the intergovernmental standing advisory committee on coastal surveillance and protection, at a meeting in Cairns, warned that strong and effective surveillance of northern Australian airstrips was vital in the war against illegal drug importation. I agree with that. There is more to coastal surveillance than just monitoring against attempts to import illegal drugs: We must look at defence activities, illegal immigration, Customs requirements, the illegal exporting of Australian fauna and flora, safety and rescue regulations and fishing. I know that fishermen are very concerned because they rely on coastal surveillance to enforce their closures and protect their fishing grounds against foreign fishing vessels.

There is no doubt in my mind that Amann Aviation is still unprepared and is not nearly ready to take on this very important task of monitoring the surveillance of Australia's coastline and the Great Barrier Reef. I asked numerous questions in Estimates Committee E. For instance, I asked when the planes would be available. Dr Kay replied that the intention was certainly to have the first four in Australia before the end of May. I point out that the end of May is in two weeks time. I do not believe that the planes have even been purchased; they certainly will not be out here by the end of May. I asked a number of other questions, including what would happen if the planes were not out here by 30 June, which is when the contract with Skywest Airlines Pty Ltd expires. I was told that an extension would be arranged. I have been told today by a reliable source that the extension has not been arranged. No decision has been given by Dr Kay's Department as to whether Skywest will be asked to continue to 30 September.

I am frightened that as of 30 September the Amann planes will still not be available. If they are available, will they be the types of planes that can handle this particular job? I am told that the planes that have been purchased-or that the company has said it will purchase-will not be able to handle the coastal surveillance role. I am told that they are unsuitable for low level flying at low speeds, which is what coastal surveillance is all about, because they are pressurised and have turbine engines. They are designed for high altitudes and high speed flying.

I again asked Dr Kay how fast these planes need to go, and I was told that the speed required for normal operations is between 140 and 160 knots. These planes, admittedly, can get down to a speed of 140 knots, but that is not the speed-or height-at which they are designed to fly. We will find that they will not be able to perform those types of duties without breakdowns and so forth occurring.

The other reason that we are saying that Amann Aviation is not in any position to take on this surveillance role is that at the moment it has no personnel. It has told the Skywest pilots and observers that they are not required. Within three months the company will not only have to find 14 planes, which its does not have, but it will also have to train 60-odd personnel. I asked when some of the bases would be taken over, and I was told that under contract Amann Aviation would take over Darwin on 16 July; Gove on 17 July; and, I think, Weipa on 18 July.

I ask the Senate how that company is going to take over those bases and have personnel working in those bases when it does not even have the planes. The planes that should have been out here on 4 May have not been purchased. My fear is-and it is a very significant fear-that by 30 September the planes will still not be ready, but the point that the urgency motion gets to-the very thrust of the argument-is that if tonight Skywest is not notified whether it will be required to service the coastal surveillance, it will pull the plug as from 30 June and Australia will have no coastal surveillance, the Great Barrier Reef will have no coastal surveillance and the Government will not be able to protect Australia. That shows how this Government has completely bungled the whole operation, because in two weeks time there is going to be no coastal surveillance throughout Australia unless we can get the Royal Australian Air Force or someone else to do it. I do not know who else would possibly be able to do it, but the whole of Australia is going to be unprotected from drugs being imported and birds being exported. We will not be able to protect the fishing grounds. This is a very serious position.

To my way of thinking, to offer a $17.6m contract to someone who has a $2 company is inexcusable. I have had to start a business. I went out and started on my own and developed a reasonably good business. I did not go out as a retailer and try to end up owning Myer's overnight, and that is what Amann Aviation is being asked to do. The Government is asking a very small company to provide a very large service. If it does not work the company will go to the Minister in two or three weeks time and say: `We ran into terrible problems. We couldn't get the planes. The planes we bid on were not what we needed, but I am terribly sorry about it. We will withdraw and we will lose our $2 company and we will lose $2'. Australia will lose millions of dollars. The fishing industry will be in trouble, drug runners will be able to come in to Australia, and all Amann Aviation will lose is its $2. It is an intolerable position when Australian security is put at risk. The whole security of Australia is put in the hands of a $2 company. That is how stupidly this Government has carried on. I am not here to denigrate in any way anyone that is prepared to have a go; I welcome it. I am a small businessman myself, and I think anyone who has enough initiative to get up and go should be encouraged, but it is absolutely stupid that someone who has to spend $17.6m puts up a $2 company as security. It is just not reasonable.

In the few minutes that I have remaining of my contribution, I would like to bring up the matter that I alluded to earlier, the coastal surveillance contract-this is a separate contract-for the Great Barrier Reef. It has been another case of bureaucratic bungling. I am sorry that Dr Kay is here; I do not normally like to attack public servants because they have no way to defend themselves. I apologise to him, and it probably is not his fault. I have the highest respect for public servants. The contract expires on 30 June-a mere seven weeks away. Up to date no new tenders have been called. The Department of Transport says it needs guidelines from the Department of Arts, Heritage and Environment, which foots a lot of the bill for the reef surveillance. This Department has had three years to decide guidelines and set the relevant parameters yet it has not done so. It is a classic case of bureaucratic buck passing at the expense of the industry. Many people want to tender for the contract. They have to make commercial decisions such as on importation of planes and location of businesses, yet they cannot do so until the tenders are put out and the requirements of the Government are made known.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reynolds Sen M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I find it quite extraordinary that Senator Vanstone should bring on this matter as an urgent debate this afternoon. Today is the day of the presentation of an economic statement. Today is a day when we have a large number of tertiary students camped out on the lawns in front of Parliament House concerned about future funding of tertiary education and particularly concerned about the Liberal Party policy to charge full fees. It is also the policy of the National Party, if that Party is really relevant. It is only a few days since we heard the most outrageous allegations of corruption in the Queensland Police Force and the concern about drug trafficking, particularly in far north Queensland, and the involvement of well known families.
—Why don't you move a motion on something else?

—I wonder why Senator Vanstone is so concerned about this particular issue. I doubt if there is very much northern coastal surveillance needed from the leafy suburbs of Adelaide. I find her preoccupation with this issue rather extraordinary because I would not have expected her to see it as a priority with so many other issues that are happening to her and her Party.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Boswell talked about irregularities, how frightened he is and what fear he has about the future for coastal surveillance in northern Australia. I find it difficult to take seriously the hypocrisy of Senator Boswell from the Queensland National Party saying that he is concerned about coastal surveillance when a national television program has already revealed that there is corruption in the Queensland Police Force and that a judicial inquiry will be held, and probably the National Crime Authority will also be obliged to investigate the seriousness of many of those allegations. But, of course, that is not the only hypocrisy that we have heard this afternoon. I find it quite hypocritical that Opposition senators favour one company over another when the Amann Aviation tender was 28 per cent lower than the Skywest tender. This comes from Senator Boswell, Senator Vanstone and Senator Knowles. I have heard their parties talk a great deal about cost cutting. In fact, Senator Vanstone might like to be reminded of what Mr Howard has said about cost cutting. He said:
I intend to cut spending far more heavily than any government has previously cut spending.
Mr Peacock similarly has said:
It's no use making 5 per cent cuts across the board as the programs roll on. We must cut the big ticket items. When we take office there will be howls of protest as we cut program after program.
Yet this afternoon Senator Vanstone and Senator Knowles have argued that more money should be spent on this contract and that it would be a good thing to spend in the vicinity of $2.5m more.

I also refer to the questions that were asked during an Estimates Committee meeting on 9 April. Senator Lewis was very concerned about the tender price. He was advised that there was something of the order of $750,000 difference between the lowest conforming tender and the second lowest. Senator Lewis is a member of the party that is so concerned about the need to cut costs. Senator Michael Baume, who is in the chamber, often reminds us of his Waste Watch Committee. However, I note that he is not speaking in the debate this afternoon. Senator Lewis says: `Oh, only three-quarters of a million dollars!' That is how concerned he is about the cost cutting measures that the Opposition claims to stand by.

Let us look very closely at the absolute propriety with which this tender has been awarded. Public advertisements for tenders for the provision of aerial surveillance services were placed in the national Press in August 1986. Eight responses were received prior to the closing date of 25 November 1986. The tender evaluating committee, especially established to consider offers, had representations from the Department of Transport, the Department of Primary Industry and the Australian Federal Police and the Department of Aviation. The Committee actually interviewed the three lowest price tenderers to establish the financial and technical compliance of the tenders submitted, and the Government guidelines on tender evaluations were scrupulously adhered to. Perhaps I should remind Opposition senators of the guidelines for Commonwealth purchasing. They are: Firstly, in relation to equal opportunity, through public invitation of tenders, Commonwealth Purchasing Gazette and Press, as well as notification to potentially interested tenderers.

Secondly, in relation to fair dealing, clear specification of requirements; absolute equality of information provided to each tenderer; and common basis of evaluation. Thirdly, in relation to probity and accountability, fair application of evaluation criteria; scrupulous handling of tenders; respecting commercial nature of information; and follow correct procedures. Fourthly, in relation to the best value for money, acceptance of lowest priced tender meeting specified requirements.

The Hawke Government is a responsible Government. It accepted the lowest tender because it has to be accountable, unlike Opposition senators who come into this place and make way out allegations hoping that they might get themselves reported in the local Press. However, what Adelaide constituents are going to think of Senator Vanstone being so concerned about northern surveillance is, I am afraid, beyond me.

But let me get back to the present situation in regard to the current status of Amann Aviation. The contract with Amann Aviation requires that the company provide the full surveillance service from 12 September. I am not quite sure why Senator Boswell made a speech about how frightened he is about some deadline in his mind of a couple of weeks or the end of June--

TALK.START.PARA: —Because the takeover contract is not settled.

—The contract requires that the company provide the full surveillance service from 12 September. Perhaps Senator Boswell is far more concerned about the outcome of the judicial inquiry into corruption allegations in Queensland than he is about coastal surveillance, as outlined here this afternoon.

SPEECH.PARA: Amann Aviation is currently in the process of obtaining the required Department of Aviation approvals and clearances. The company has upgraded its aircraft and will now have the model fitted with turbine engines. The aircraft will have the same surveillance capability as the present aircraft that are being used but will have improved performance and passenger carrying capability. The first five aircraft will be due late in June or early in July. The company, as I think has already been spelt out, has appointed an operations manager, a chief pilot and a check and training captain. These details have been repeated again and again-by the Minister for Transport (Mr Peter Morris) and by the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Senator Gietzelt) in this place. Yet Senator Vanstone and others choose to waste the time of the Senate in this quite trivial debate that we have heard this afternoon.

Let me correct a couple of other inaccuracies that have been peddled here this afternoon. The contract with Amann Aviation is for the provision of surveillance services. It does not specify any particular type of aircraft, but it does specify minimum standards. Furthermore, comments were made about when Skywest took over the contract. Skywest took over the whole operation in only 1983, even though it had parts of the contract prior to that date. I think Senator Knowles expressed a sudden concern about pay rates. I have never really considered her in the role of advocate for fair industrial relations. I assure her that pilot pay scales have been negotiated with the Airline Pilots Federation. They are covered by the award. The observer pay scales are currently being negotiated with the individuals concerned because they had not previously been covered by an award. So some of the comments that have been made in this place this afternoon are completely inaccurate and quite spurious.

Let us look at surveillance. I am especially concerned about this issue because, living in far north Queensland, I have heard a number of rumours and allegations in the past couple of years about the need for increased surveillance in far north Queensland. I am very pleased with the efforts of the Government to upgrade surveillance in that area. The Australian Federal Police took over the co-ordination task from the Department of Transport, following Government consideration of the Beazley report in 1984. The Department of Transport continued to provide staff to the unit and to handle certain administrative matters, including, obviously, the letting of contracts. But the Australian Federal Police was given the co-ordination role, with good reason as it was felt that better direction could be given to coastal protection if it were handled by the Commonwealth's main law enforcement agency. That did not happen under a previous government. That priority was established by this Government.

A standing advisory committee on coastal protection and surveillance, which comprises both Commonwealth and State officers, meets at least annually, and there is, in addition, a standing interdepartmental committee of Commonwealth agencies that are vitally concerned with coastal surveillance. They include: The Australian Federal Police, the Department of the Special Minister of State, the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet, the Department of Primary Industry, the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, the Department of Arts, Heritage and Environment, the Department of Health, the Department of Defence and the Australian Customs Service. The Coastal Protection Unit is staffed by the Federal Police and civilian officers and staff of the Department of Transport. Customs and Defence have liaison officers posted to the Unit to act as advisers in relation to responses to sightings. Defence usually responds to fisheries breaches, while Customs handles all other responses, apart from search and rescue, in which it gives whatever assistance is required.

There are approximately 200 surveillance flights per month, undertaking visual search of the littoral area between Karratha in Western Australia and Townsville in Queensland, at an average of seven to eight flights on any particular day. Each flight generates a telexed report to Canberra, which in turn is forwarded to Customs officers and other recipients around Australia. In addition, there is immediate follow-up of particular sightings with Customs vessels around the coastline covered by the program as they are routinely tasked to follow up any sightings in their area of operation.

In the minute of my speech remaining I will say that I certainly believe that much more serious issues are raised about coastal surveillance than the ones that we have heard this afternoon. I will certainly be asking the two relevant Ministers responsible for Federal Police and Customs whether they will be passing on to the Queensland judicial inquiry into unusual activities in the far north any information reported to them over the last few years that they have not been able to resolve with the Queensland Police Department.

DEBATE.TITLE: PRESIDENT OF THE AUSTRALIAN CONCILIATION AND ARBITRATION COMMISSION

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

I do not wish to say very much at this stage, but the tabling of the report of the President of the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission gives me an opportunity to indicate that the Government has announced its intention to make very substantial changes to the conciliation and arbitration system. Whether by accident or design, details of this legislation have apparently been leaked to the news media before these have been made available to the Parliament. I wish to put on record my concern about the suggestion that has appeared in a number of newspapers, principally in the Australian this morning, that a central feature of the legislation which the Government is to bring down will be the expansion of the role of the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission or its successor. That new body will have the power to make decisions on whether employers can have access to the remedies contained in the Trade Practices Act.

It is quite clear from the surveys that have been taken, both by newspapers and by the Hancock Committee of Review of the Australian Industrial Relations Law and Systems, that there is enormous public disquiet about the state of our industrial relations system and the fact that the trade unions seem to have the capacity to run all over the other elements of the system. When it is indicated, as it was this morning, that the central thrust of the Government's legislation will be to reduce the capacity of employers to withstand abuses of trade union power and take action when unionists behave in an illegal fashion, there is room for a great deal of concern.

The Opposition will examine very carefully the legislation which the Government is to bring down tomorrow from the point of view of ensuring that the limited remedies currently available to employers who are faced with illegal conduct under the Trade Practices Act, with breaches of the common law or perhaps even breaches of the Crimes Act, do not see their means of redress blocked by the proposed legislation. The suggestion that the Australian industrial relations system needs altering by reducing the capacity of the community, government and employers to withstand trade union activity which is outside the law would receive an enormous horse laugh right around Australia. It is clear that there is very great public concern and, indeed, trade unionists themselves believe that the unions have too much power and are capable of overriding the rights of the individual and of the general community.

In those circumstances I put the Government on notice that it will face very strong opposition from the Liberal Party of Australia. I believe that we will be joined by the National Party of Australia which, like the Liberal Party, would not want to see the balance in the system disturbed in the way that it is suggested this legislation will disturb it. We will look to the support of the Australian Democrats to try to ensure that the conditions precedent to the use of existing remedies are not made such as to deprive those remedies of their effect. It is little consolation to read in the newspapers that the Government will insert some new capacity to impose penalties of up to $5,000, using the conciliation and arbitration authority, whatever it may be called after tomorrow's legislation is dealt with, when one compares that with the economic cost and the degree of destruction that can be caused by trade union activities outside the law.

The recent dispute involving the Plumbers and Gasfitters Employees Union of Australia was brought to an end only by a $280,000 penalty. One realises just how contemptuous this Government is of maintaining a decent balance in this area when it suggests that one can substitute that sort of remedy for penalties of something like $5,000. That will be laughed at by those elements in the trade union movement who, in the past, have shown themselves ready to thumb their noses at the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. Today at Question Time I asked about the postal workers. Again, one sees a flaunting of the power of the Australian Postal and Telecommunications Union against the directions and wishes of the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. That is the sort of thing of which most Australians are heartily sick.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I echo the remarks of my Leader, Senator Chaney, on the apparently leaked reports of the new Hancock legislation in the newspapers today. Several aspects have been emphasised by Senator Chaney which deserve to be reiterated. I refer particularly to the Government's intention to subvert the application of sections 45d and e of the Trade Practices Act. The whole point of that legislation is to protect business, the consumer and the ordinary person in the community against the predatory attacks of trade unions which seek to exploit their power at tremendous cost to the consumer, adding millions and millions of dollars to the ordinary living costs of the Australian community. This is what this Government is on about. It is making sure that the trade unions are free, with minimal penalties being applied, to exploit their power against the interests of the ordinary consumer. The trade practices law is there to protect the consumer. I notice in an article in today's Australian that the Government thinks it is pushing its constitutional power in this area to the limit. That does not surprise me. I believe that the Government will face more than a challenge in this Parliament on this legislation in terms of numbers. Certainly the Liberal Party will oppose the legislation, as I believe will the National Party of Australia, and we hope that the Australian Democrats will also join with us, but there remains the great clout in the courts that will be tested no doubt by the States and, of course, by private businesses which seek to ensure that the principles of the legislation as we know it are upheld.

SPEECH.PARA: These moves will have widespread ramifications for the whole community. This comes at a time when Australia is suffering an economic recession, when the cost of living is rising beyond the control of ordinary consumers, when people are losing their houses as a result of record interest rates and are unable to buy cars because prices have risen by more than 30 per cent in the last year, and when people are unable to look after themselves and maintain their standards of living for themselves and their children because of high taxation. The Government wants to allow a wide, sweeping range of new laws virtually to exempt trade unions from any kind of legal action. This will add substantially to the cost of living. Clearly that is ridiculous, absurd and ludicrous, but it is the sort of thing that this lunatic Government does from time to time. One has only to observe what the Government has done with its taxation laws, such as on the fringe benefits tax and capital gains tax, which are totally destructive of incentive for investment and which will take us in exactly the opposite direction to what is required.

I believe that if the reports in today's newspapers prove to be true, Australia is in for a new dark age in industrial relations. We shall see the development of a supremacy by the trade unions the like of which this country has never seen before. This has come about because of this Government's intention to give way to the pressure of the Australian Council of Trade Unions. The time of reckoning has come for this Government. It must now pay the piper in the trade union movement, and this is how the Government will repay to the trade union movement debts which have been accumulated while it has been in government. It is being done by the passage of this kind of legislation which will remove the safeguards from Australians, ordinary consumers and ordinary individuals in the community.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating papers, and the paper it is now debating is the thirteenth annual report of the President of the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. That is a rather uneventful occurrence in the Senate, but the reason why today it has excited particular passions and driven Opposition members to flights of rhetorical fancy is that it is a report which will result, one hopes, in the passage of the Hancock legislation when it is introduced by the Federal Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Willis), I understand tomorrow. I understand the Commission will be substantially restructured and vastly improved, following the result of an exhaustive inquiry, the Hancock Committee of Review into Australian Industrial Relations Law and Systems. That inquiry was lead by a distinguished professor of economics, Professor Hancock. It was assisted by George Polites, the former Executive Director of the Confederation of Australian Industry, and Charles Fitzgibbon, a former senior Vice-President of the Australian Council of Trade Unions. Thus, the inquiry was balanced neatly between practitioners at the coalface of industrial relations and academic experts and researchers. The inquiry took a massive volume of evidence and has reported to this Parliament. No doubt the Minister, in laying down the legislation tomorrow, will explain it.

SPEECH.PARA: The report is significant because it comes forward at a time when as the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) told me at Question Time today, industrial relations disputes have been vastly reduced compared with the period of office of the last conservative Government. I do not have the figures before me, but I recollect that he was talking of the Fraser years, which averaged a loss of about four million man days. The report for this past year shows that 1.1 million man days were lost in industrial disputes. Thus, there is a direct comparison, as has always been the case in industrial relations, between the way in which a Labor Government is better suited to handle the vexed field and the way in which a Liberal government or conservative government believes that industrial relations should be conducted; that is, in such a way, to take the example of the Fraser Government, as to exacerbate problems rather than solve them. Indeed, we have in Australia at the moment the spectacle of the Queensland Government enacting, though not proclaiming into law, legislation which is a travesty and mockery of anything that anyone could consider as reasonable in industrial relations. We have the spectacle in the Senate of senators no less distinguished than the Leader of the Opposition (Senator Chaney) citing newspaper reports and attacking the Government on the basis of those reports. There has been a deafening silence from the Opposition on dealing with the Sir Joh Bjelke-Petersen legislation in Queensland-legislation which from all points of view is a distortion and caricature of the creation of a commission which will be able to arbitrate and gain respect in the community as a body through which genuine and deep grievances can be resolved.

I do not intend now, on the basis of newspaper reports, to debate what Senator Chaney or any of the other speakers have said. However, it has been my long experience in industrial relations that at least two things should be done in legislation. I do not know whether they are done in the legislation that will be brought forward tomorrow, but in any new legislation at least two matters should be attended to in order to give a modern industrial commission the compass of authority in industrial relations fields that could not have been forecast or expected by our ancestors who drafted the provision in the Constitution to enable the Federal Government to make laws in this area. The first is that some attention needs to be given to the definition of a worker. With the change in work practices over time, one finds that the old definition is no longer adequate. The second area relating to what is an industrial matter, a legal definition based on the old legislation, should be broadened because matters which are palpably now within the industrial environment, industrial democracy being one of them, are prevented from being dealt with by the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. If what the Minister does tomorrow opens up those areas, they will be a boon to a new refurbished, revitalised and relevant industrial authority that is able to meet the real needs of employers, who after all are a major user of that Commission, and employees through the unions who use it in order to establish and maintain rights and improve living standards. The Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission, in the period under report, has played a key role in setting some of the parameters on wages and salaries in Australia. This has helped this Government to get a greater control over the economy than it had previously.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

I take this opportunity to make a few remarks on the annual report of the Arbitration Inspectorate because of the importance of the report itself and the work behind it. The report details the work of the Arbitration Inspectorate in the financial year 1985-86 and lists areas of concern such as the number of award investigations carried out by the Inspectorate.

At the heart of the report is the maintenance of Federal awards. At present 1,677 awards are in force federally and, of an estimated 5.6 million wage and salary earners, two million are presently covered by Federal awards. In my home State of South Australia the percentage of wage and salary earners covered by Federal awards is 33.9 per cent, or slightly more than one-third. This percentage is smaller than the percentage for State awards, which covered 52.8 per cent of the work force. Yet the number of South Australians covered under Federal awards was significant and appeared to have been growing in 1985-86. Some 305 new awards were made during 1985-86.

The vital task of the Inspectorate is closely to scrutinise the awards. The job of the Inspectorate is to ascertain whether awards are maintained in all the relevant areas and to investigate complaints relating to employer non-compliance. The Inspectorate was established in 1928 to ensure compliance with awards. The arbitration system goes back to 1904, after three years of Federation. Since that time the Inspectorate has been the instrument to enforce legitimate award entitlements for workers. In 1985-86, 119,536 award inquiries were received by Inspectorate offices throughout Australia. This figure represents a 15 per cent increase over the figure for 1984-85. The number of inquiries per working day has shown a considerable increase. Since 1983-84 the number of average daily inquiries to Inspectorate offices has grown from 407 to 479 in 1985-86. The enforcement of awards has resulted in $4,069,946 being recovered from employers, as opposed to $3,721,578 being recovered in 1984-85. This has meant that $348,366 more has been recovered in award payments than in 1984-85.

Members of the Opposition, of course, have a problem in the area of award determination and enforcement. We are not sure what policies they are now ready to promote, but until their recent problems they spent a great deal of time talking about flexibility. The Opposition appears to believe in flexibility-the flexibility to dissolve awards, to revise awards downwards or for opting out of them altogether so that legitimate wage justice can be white-anted. Australians from all walks of life and over many years have seen the necessity to have awards in place. Workers under the arbitrated award system receive commonality of pay and conditions, and the strength and popularity of the arbitration system have resulted from general public acceptance and perception of the basic fairness of this system and of determined awards in general.

The report, I am pleased to say, shows that the Inspectorate has obviously established a good working relationship with employers and employees alike. The overwhelming number of award violations by employers was rectified voluntarily. In fact, in 1985-86, 4,684 employers agreed to rectify the matter before other machinery came into force. The machinery to enforce legitimate awards is, and has been, in place for many years. It is pleasing to note, though, that this machinery can be effective if compliance with the law is flouted. In 1985-86, 79 employers were referred for prosecution and of these one case was withdrawn and all the others were found proven by the court.

One of the major functions of the Inspectorate is the provision of information. Many inquiries are made of the Inspectorate, of which the majority indicate no breaches of awards. I note in the report that, in respect of formal award complaints, 57.4 per cent of these were upheld in 1985-86.
