SPEECH.SPEAKER: Zakharov Sen A.O.

TALK.START.PARA: —In speaking to the report of the Senate Select Committee on Private Hospitals and Nursing Homes entitled `Private Hospitals in Australia', I would like to speak first about some of the points raised by Senator Brownhill in his contribution to this debate. Senator Brownhill spoke about the value of `freedom of choice' in the health sector. Freedom of choice, I believe, is a myth for most people in a situation such as hospitalisation, because very many people can make only one choice. They cannot afford private hospitals, just as they cannot afford private schools.

SPEECH.PARA: In health, as in education, the question of choice is blurred by public relations exercises of the private sector providers. Those who can afford private schools or private hospitals often choose them because they have been given misleading information. A constituent came to see me last year about a huge debt incurred when her husband had an urgent operation in a private hospital. The surgeon could have operated at a public hospital across the road, but told her husband, the patient: `You wouldn't want me to operate in the dog pen, would you?'. What sort of choice did that patient believe that he had? Yet the public hospital concerned was of an extremely high standard. Last year I was a patient in a public hospital when the `doctor of choice'-which is given as the reason to take out private insurance-in many cases gave his or her patients service that was inferior to that given to public patients in the neighbouring beds.

Senator Brownhill said that he believes that the public health sector has every right to operate under precisely the same sort of rules as those under which any similar business operates. But private hospitals are different from other businesses in that they do have a duty of care. There must be different rules where there is a risk to the customer-or, in this case, the patient-not only of receiving poor service but also possibly of suffering permanent injury or death through a lack of proper rules and of those rules being properly monitored and enforced. Senator Brownhill also alleged that Senator Giles spent more time, in presenting the report, in talking about the dissenting reports than she did about the report itself. This is not borne out by a reading of the Hansard record. It perhaps betrays a certain defensiveness about the minority report to which he was a signatory.

It is important to answer some of the issues raised in the dissenting reports. I intend to deal with some of them. In the introduction to the dissent by Senator Walters and Senator Brownhill it is said that much of the work of the Committee had been pre-empted by the changes to the funding of private hospitals in last year's Budget. This seems to imply that no action should have been taken in the private hospital field before the Committee reported. On the contrary, I would say that the Government's action demonstrates that the Committee was on the right track.

On the matter of doctors having financial interests in private hospitals, both of the dissenting reports contain recommendations which are weaker than those of the majority report. Senators Walters and Brownhill recommended that there be a requirement only that private hospitals inform patients, or their relatives where appropriate, in writing of that financial interest when referring patients to that hospital, whereas the Committee recommended that each State pass legislation prohibiting medical practitioners or their families from having any financial interest in a private hospital. This recommendation was based on a great deal of evidence, and not only on that of Opit and Morley, which has been criticised, I believe on very slight grounds, by Senators Walters and Brownhill. But the Opit and Morley evidence was borne out by the findings of the Victorian Health Advisory Committee and by the very thorough research on ownership, including extensive company searches, carried out by the Senate Select Committee.
In addition to doctors themselves, there is evidence of doctors' relatives and family trusts also being involved in the ownership of private hospitals. I quote from the report:

. . . the Committee estimates that medical practitioners and their families make up at least forty per cent of all investors in private hospitals. This figure has been estimated using the Opit and Morley data on doctors and their relatives in Victoria and New South Wales. The Committee notes that the proportion of doctors in both the Committee's survey and the Opit and Morley study is almost identical . . . If the trends in these States were to apply throughout Australia . . . then 23% of all investors would be medical practitioners and 17% would be their relatives.

The Committee's own survey found in addition that 93 per cent of doctor investors are practising and that, of that 93 per cent, 70 per cent refer their patients to a hospital in which they have an interest. In Victoria, a doctor who had a significant financial interest in a number of private hospitals where he operated has recently been charged with a number of counts involving a number of his patients. Since the matters are sub-judice, I can say only that I believe that this indicates there is certainly cause for concern about possible conflict of interest when a doctor practices in a hospital that he owns.
The dissenting report opposes the Committee's recommendation that directors of nursing be appointed to private hospitals boards of management. It states:
We are concerned that the implementation of this recommendation could impose legal obligations such as possible tort liability which some directors of nursing may be reluctant to assume . . .

It states that directors of nursing would usually be available to advise the Board. I believe this view denigrates directors of nursing, who are entitled to a real say in the decisions of hospital boards. I cannot recall Senator Walters raising this objection during our very protracted discussions on the report, and she gave no further elucidation during her speech. It will be interesting to learn which view directors of nursing take when they read the report, since the Royal Australian Nursing Federation told the Committee that it recommended that:
The Director of Nursing be a member of the Board of the institution.

Finally, I would like to pay tribute to all those who have staffed the secretariat of the Committee since its inception a number of years ago. For their sake as well as ours, I hope that we can conclude consideration of our remaining term of reference before long.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crowley Sen R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I take the opportunity to speak to the report entitled `Private Hospitals in Australia: their conduct, administration and ownership'. It is the second of what we expect to be three volumes of a report from the Senate Select Committee on Private Hospitals and Nursing Homes. I take the opportunity to thank our Chairperson, Senator Patricia Giles, particularly for her persistence and patience. This Committee has had a remarkably long duration. I will come to the reasons for that shortly. I have known Senator Giles only as the Chairperson of that Committee because I joined it when I came into this Parliament in 1983, at which time she became its Chairperson. I put on record my thanks to her for keeping us at the task at hand. It was such a lengthy task principally because of the considerable changes that have taken place in the years during which the Committee has been considering this very complex issue. I also put on record my thanks to the number of secretariat staff who have helped us with our work over that time-the research assistants and the stenographic staff who drafted, redrafted, researched, reappraised and rewrote this report and sections of it from time to time. Those changes of course were consequent on a number of other changes, in particular a change of government, and changes in terms of government regulations and decisions in this area.

SPEECH.PARA: The report also elaborates other changes, including the changing ownership and usage of private hospitals by our community over the years of the inquiry. Whilst that might sound somewhat negative, it gives a measure of the comprehensiveness of this report. At the very least it is an excellent reference document and there is little dispute from the members of the Committee about most of its substance. It provides splendid basic data about the numbers and sorts of private hospitals, the number of beds, the bed usage, the distribution of those beds, the ownership of those hospitals, the type of ownership, the type of funding and so on. I think most of those points, and particularly the points about ownership, were very adequately covered by Senator Giles in her speech.

The principles of the report, consequent on the information that we discovered, either from submissions given to us or from the evidence that we took, are very comprehensive. As well as going to the numbers and the head count sort of data, they go to the organisation, management and administration of private hospitals and to the standards of medical records and medical care. The standard of medical care was of prime concern for members of the Committee, and the reason why the other examinations were so critical. As we quite clearly understood, and as clearly emerged in our deliberations, the factors are all intertwined. The ownership of hospitals by doctors can lead to the possibility of conflict of interest, which was touched on by other senators. Whilst I would insist that most doctors are completely innocent of any such practice, it is only proper that any possibility for such conflict of interest be avoided.

I draw attention to the comments made by Senator Powell in speaking to this report and recorded in the Senate Hansard of 6 May 1987 when she quoted the code of ethics of the Australian Medical Association, which deals quite clearly with the pecuniary interests of doctors in relation to pharmacies. Paragraph 11.1.3 states:
A doctor should not have a financial interest in the sale of any pharmaceutical preparation he may have to recommend to a patient.

While that refers specifically to pecuniary interests and the potential for conflict of interest in regard to pharmaceutical preparations, I am sure the clear evidence in this report of the potential for conflict of interest-I do not wish to comment any further than that, as one can read the report for the more exact elaboration just mentioned by Senator Zakharov-will be a matter that the AMA Ethics Committee would want to address, as it has addressed the same principle of conflict of interest with regard to pecuniary interests in pharmaceuticals in the past. It is quite clear that the AMA Ethic Committee, in statements regarding pharmaceutical preparations, recognises the possibility of that principle, and the majority report also makes that point. I do not think it is even necessary to find examples of conflict of interest. It is necessary to recognise only the potential for conflict of interest and to make, as we have, recommendations that would preclude that from happening. Senator Walters and Senator Brownhill, in their comments on this report and in support of their dissenting report, commented about market forces and the importance of market forces applying in the delivery of medical services. Senator Giles argues in her comments how market forces are simply not applicable in the area of health care and health delivery, but it seems that the Opposition senators are not persuaded. They also claim that they want less government interference and less regulation, and will allow interference by the State only if a problem is recognised. However, I find some difficulty in understanding their position in that they want less government interference. In fact, Senator Brownhill says that the private health care sector has a right to select the services it provides and where, based on a demonstrated need for those services, and a right to determine its own financial arrangements. Senator Walters, on the other hand, in referring to the changes in funding of private hospitals, announced by the Treasurer, Mr Keating in his Budget Speech in August 1986, made the following comment:
We consider that this decision by the Government was a retrograde step and one that will exacerbate problems in both the public and private hospitals rather than ease them.

I find it a very strange contradiction that Opposition senators want no government interference but object to the reduction of Commonwealth Government funding through bed day subsidies. Market forces either operate in the private sector or they do not. If they do not, we are looking at the best mix that can be possibly arranged between private and public funding for the delivery of private and public services. I find that this position is significantly supported by the very recently released Special Supplement, Cotton Report-the Medical Journal of Australia in the Report of the Task Force to Review the Structure, Function and Constitution of the Australian Medical Journal where it states at page CR29:

Over the past 25 years there have been great changes in the nature of modern medical practice, its methods of delivery and funding structures. Increases in medical costs are universal in the Western world and governments by necessity have become more directly involved in the financial support, distribution and organisation of health care systems. Australia is no exception. It is a fact of life, whether we like it or not, that a significant part of the income of virtually every medical practitioner in Australia arises directly or indirectly from government funds. It is equally apparent that the size of the health budgets of state and federal governments, who now provide three-quarters of the funds for health expenditure, makes it inevitable that those governments will continue to involve themselves in the detailed monitoring of the delivery of health care.
It also states:
Governments are becoming increasingly frustrated with the profession's apparent inability to resolve its internal differences.

The report then goes on to make the point that it would prefer to have one voice-that is, the Australian Medical Association-speaking for the medical profession in the very important task of trying to provide the very best medical services of the sort that we have come to expect in this country, and that that is dependent on close collaboration and co-operation rather than suspicion from each side of the medical equation in this country.

In terms of public and private contributions, the Labor Government spelt out in its policy and through its provision of services, ably put into place by the Government and the Minister for Health (Dr Blewett), that it will continue the best option of co-operation between both sectors. I think that the report contributes very usefully to any further consideration of the delivery of health services and, in particular, the deliberation of the best way of finding a balance between public and private hospital beds in this country so as to continue to provide that excellent health care that we have become accepting of.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The majority report of the Senate Select Committee on Private Hospitals and Nursing Homes in Australia is clearly inadequate. Clearly it does not go in the direction that the Government itself is going down and, equally clearly, the minority report is a sensible, rational and coherent approach to this problem. It is evident that these qualities are absent from the majority report. There is no doubt that anyone with any understanding of this area would reject the majority report in general and certainly would embrace the minority report of Senators Walters and Brownhill. The majority report seems to be based far more on ideology and unsubstantiated attacks on the integrity of members of the medical profession. The majority report seems to have overlooked the real issues affecting users and potential users of private hospitals.

SPEECH.PARA: The majority report recommends a level of regulation of the private hospital sector to a far greater degree than exists in the public hospital area-although it does appear evident from my knowledge of the figures that, certainly on the basis of cost, the private hospital sector in many instances appears to be able to provide similar services at lower cost than public hospitals, even after taking into account some of the necessary cost additions that public hospitals have to bear because of the additional services that they are obliged to provide.

The minority view that the Medicare levy has been largely responsible for taking patients out of the private hospital sector and thus overloading the public hospital system is clearly correct as the large numbers of queues for the public hospital sector clearly demonstrate. Many Australians are now unable to afford both the Medicare levy and the additional private hospital insurance that is required to make certain that one does not have to take place in a queue, which can be up to two years long for some things, and not just major surgery matters but for some old fashioned services. One has no guarantee, if one belongs only to Medicare, that one will not have to join such a queue. The only way to ensure that one will obtain the hospital service that one needs when one most needs it, particularly in terms of removing painful and debilitating but not necessarily life endangering problems, is by joining a health insurance fund and taking out private hospital insurance. So it is self-evident that the public hospital system has been overloaded by the diversion of people from the private hospital sector to the public hospital sector.

It is all very well for the Minister for Health (Dr Blewett) or any other member of the Government to say: `But there are more people in private hospital beds now than there were three years ago'. That is true because there are now substantially more private hospital beds. The reality is that, on the proportion of beds provided to the hospital using public in Australia, private hospitals now have a diminished role. That is a shame because there are now 9,000 empty private hospital beds around Australia at a time when there are queues of people requiring hospital beds totalling 100,000. No doubt Senator Crowley will object to that statistic, but it is something like 100,000. Certainly the Victorian figures show an increase to something like 34,000 people waiting in a queue for public hospital beds-and that is in just one State alone. So that is a fair indication that the number of people waiting in a queue in Australia-many of them in pain-is enormous. It has been caused by the extent to which Medicare has discouraged people from having private hospital insurance and now simply to depend on Medicare.

The minority report also recommend that patients who choose private hospital accommodation should not be forced to pay twice, as at present; that is, through the Medicare levy and through private hospital insurance. It is evident that tonight, for example, that situation will worsen because, if the leaks are accurate, the cost of medical services to a patient in a private hospital will increase. In fact, the rebate will go from 85 per cent down to 75 per cent, and naturally that will impose additional cost burdens on the health funds and, naturally, the health funds will extend that cost burden to the contributors. If the health customers of Australia take the view that they can no longer afford these further rises in health insurance, which follow the $170m slug that they have already faced this year, there could be even further pressure on the public hospital system as potential private hospital users are forced out of this area to join the public hospital queues.

I have already raised with the Minister this question of the cost impact on the inflation rate in Australia through the booming cost of health in this country. In the past 12 months we have seen an increase of 18.5 per cent in health costs, which is double the rate of inflation in Australia. The major factor in that was, of course, the period of 12 months-not the three months that the Minister said in response to me. Certainly he unintentionally misled me. When he pointed out that hospital costs were only a small part of it, he was really referring to only the last three months. If one takes the last 12 months one will see that the great bulk of the increased costs was from health care and hospital insurance contributions, and that resulted directly from the Government's policy. What the Government is going to do again tonight is, no doubt, further add to the cost of living and further discourage people from providing for themselves by, in a discriminatory way, specifically hitting those people who choose to go into a private hospital because they know they can get the service they want when they want it. I concede that I have not seen what is contained in tonight's mini-Budget or financial statement, but the reports around certainly indicate that this is very likely. Of course, this is another discriminatory assault on people who prefer to use the private sector rather than rely on the Government, which is what is the philosophical thrust of this Government and the majority report.

There are some other elements of this report that are totally unacceptable and which the minority recommendations clearly seek to rectify. The minority report, for example, suggests-and quite sensibly-that the abolition of bulk billing for all those except disadvantaged patients would overcome concerns expressed about entrepreneurial medicine. The minority report quite properly pointed out that the Committee received no substantiated evidence to suggest impropriety by medical practitioners relating to private hospitals. In fact, the reverse was the case in the only survey submitted to the Committee which examined this area. Yet the Committee suggested that where there is some such impropriety, there should be specific controls over it. The essential point is that three members of the six-member Committee dissented from the Committee's recommendation that medical practitioners should be prohibited from holding financial interests in private hospitals, and that clearly establishes an inference that doctors somehow lack the propriety and decency to be able to act in that way. I reject that proposition.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Giles Sen P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I appreciate the fact that in speaking now I am closing this debate. I am very well aware of the fact that the debate in the community will go on for quite a long time, and not in terms that have been suggested by Senator Baume. His approach to our report is one that shows very little confidence in his own party colleagues who took part in this long inquiry. He seemed to be able to concentrate only on a range of issues which were included in the dissenting report of two of his colleagues, Senator Walters and Senator Brownhill. Most of these matters, I would point out, were not matters which were of contention during the Committee's activities. We are very puzzled indeed that, for example, the question of bulk billing should be raised. Senator Michael Baume obviously uses every opportunity that he possibly can as an excuse for a polemic against Medicare. The question of bulk billing was not at issue at any time during the conduct of this inquiry, and to see it referred to in the dissenting report was surprising, to say the least.

SPEECH.PARA: All this emphasis on the minority report should be qualified by the fact that it is essentially the work of one member of the Committee, as I say, encompassing a number of issues which were not at issue during the inquiry, supported by another member of the Committee who had seen and heard barely any of the evidence. Quite correctly Senator Michael Baume points out that those three members, including Senator Haines, were at odds with the Government members of the Committee on that one issue of doctor ownership of private hospitals. We never at any time have claimed evidence of any impropriety. What we have claimed, and have substantial support for, is the potential for conflict of interests. Time and again, people for whom we have a great deal of respect, gave evidence to this effect. They insisted that this was the case and most of us agreed.

Ideologically based attacks on medicos were not what this report was about. We are as concerned as anybody in this community to maintain the trust and integrity in which the medical profession is held by the majority of people. We are also very well aware of the fact that the Australian Medical Association and the royal colleges themselves have considerable difficulty in maintaining the sort of peer review that many of us wish was able to be maintained. It is quite extraordinary for us to hear from those on the other side, as we have done during this debate, that entrepreneurial medicine is frowned upon. There are no problems about that; we have unanimity on that particular issue. But if ownership of private hospitals by doctors who use those hospitals is not entrepreneurial medicine, I fail to understand what is in the minds of the dissenting senator.

We are not over-enthusiastic about a vast amount of unnecessary regulations, but, as has been pointed out time and time again, health care is not the same as any other consumer aspect of this society. If the care that has been provided in any institution, private or public, is found to be substandard, it is governments in the end that have to take the responsibility. We have seen this happening quite recently. That responsibility simply must be taken, if the only justification within the private sector, is that it is, still the public purse which trains doctors, nurses and technicians; it is still the public purse in the main that provides the research and development and many of the public facilities which private medicine depends upon very heavily.

Cost comparisons which are referred to by Senator Baume are very difficult to make, as he has pointed out. The Jamison report-a respected report which preceded ours by a couple of years-referred to the fact that the clientele of private hospitals is vastly different from that of public teaching hospitals; that the costs are very difficult to compare, and that on the whole it is a fruitless exercise to try to make that comparison.

Since the publication of the report we have had quite a lot of response which has been uniformly congratulatory. Amongst other pleasing aspects of its reception have been recommendations that we should send copies of the report to the British Medical Journal and to the New England Journal of Medicine for review. I do not think accolades come much higher than that. It is a source of disappointment that we should find that dissenting views were published on what were not considered to be matters of great moment during the actual discussions of the Committee. This report is simply being used in a party political way to try to demonstrate that Medicare is the root of all evil in Australia. Contrary to what Senator Michael Baume argues, the majority report did make a reference to the minor role of Medicare in the changing usage of private and public hospitals. It was not seen to be a major issue at any time during the inquiry, and to find it in the dissenting report as a major issue is quite surprising. The report should be of use. The community response has been one of considerable interest and considerable congratulation. I think our best wish is that it be a useful document for those who want to go further into many of the issues that were canvassed in the report, issues which we were not able to follow further without unduly protracting the inquiry, but issues which are of considerable importance within the debate on health care within Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, I claim to have been misrepresented. Senator Giles claimed during her speech that only one senator had worked on the minority report of the Senate Select Committee on Private Hospitals and Nursing Homes. That is a gross insult to Senator Brownhill, who has worked extremely hard on this report.
—How much of the evidence did he hear?

DEBATE.TITLE: STANDING COMMITTEE ON CONSTITUTIONAL AND LEGAL AFFAIRS

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Report on the Role of Parliament in Relation to the National Companies Scheme

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 6 May, on motion by Senator Bolkus:
That the Senate take note of the report.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The report of the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs on the role of Parliament in relation to the national companies scheme is welcome, not only because of its single recommendation, but also because of the opportunity that the Committee's inquiry provided for various bodies to air criticism of the existing scheme. Criticism came from State governments, business, lawyers and accountants.

SPEECH.PARA: The existing national uniform companies and securities scheme represented an attempt to overcome the divergence between the laws of the various States relating to companies. Laws agreed to by the Ministerial Council for Companies and Securities consisting of representatives of the six States and the Commonwealth, would be passed by the Commonwealth Parliament and would then apply automatically, by virtue of State application of laws Acts, throughout Australia.

The Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills, of which I am a member, commented on aspects of the scheme in its eighth and eleventh reports of 1986, and again in its annual report for 1985-86. It also made a submission to the Constitutional and Legal Affairs Committee on the matter. Given the functions of the Scrutiny of Bills Committee, its major concern was with the powers of the Commonwealth Parliament in relation to Bills forming part of the national uniform scheme. The Committee understood it to be the view of the Attorney-General's Department that, once a Bill had been agreed to by the Ministerial Council, acceptance by the Commonwealth Government of an amendment to that Bill, without going back to the Ministerial Council to seek approval of the amendment, would amount to a breach of the formal agreement, entitling the States to withdraw from the scheme.

The Attorney-General's Department, in its submission to the Constitutional and Legal Affairs Committee, reflected this view, stating that, although the formal agreement did not expressly prohibit the Commonwealth Government from accepting amendments moved on the floor of the Parliament, to do so would not be consistent with the spirit of the agreement. In public hearings, however, Mr Peter Levy of the Department expressed the view that the legislation as amended would apply in the States and that it would then be left to individual States to decide whether to make translator regulations under the scheme providing for the amendment not to apply. By contrast, Mr Leigh Masel, the former Chairman of the National Companies and Securities Commission, took the view that the Commonwealth's acceptance of amendments without going back to the Ministerial Council for its approval would be a breach of the agreement.

Similar doubts surround the Parliament's power to disallow regulations forming part of the uniform scheme. This was highlighted in February this year when the shadow Attorney-General, Mr Spender, moved for the disallowance of certain amendments to the companies regulations. The Attorney-General, Mr Lionel Bowen, in opposing the motion, suggested that Mr Spender was `not entitled' to move for disallowance. However, the Constitutional and Legal Affairs Committee noted that the agreement did not expressly take away the Commonwealth Parliament's power of disallowance. In fact it appeared to recognise it by providing that, if an amending regulation approved by the Ministerial Council ceased to be in force by disallowance, any State could make similar regulations. The disallowance of a regulation did not give the States a right to withdraw from the scheme, although it might in this fashion lead to a breakdown in uniformity between the States.

As the Scrutiny of Bills Committee stated in its submission in a passage quoted at some length at paragraph 3.12 of the report, the effect of the scheme is to diminish severely the ability of the Commonwealth Parliament to perform its legislative functions. Therein is our concern. If it rejects legislation forming part of the national scheme which has previously been agreed to by the Ministerial Council, then individual States may legislate in terms of the agreed Bill and uniformity will have broken down. If it amends legislation forming part of the national scheme, and either the Commonwealth Attorney-General declines to take the amendments back to the Ministerial Council, or the Ministerial Council fails to agree to the amendments by the required majority, then passage into law of the legislation as amended would give the States a right to withdraw from the national uniform scheme. Failure by the Parliament to pass the legislation without its proposed amendments would, once again, leave the individual States free to legislate in the terms agreed to by the Ministerial Council with a consequent breakdown in uniformity.

The Scrutiny of Bills Committee commented in its eighth report of 1986 that the operation of the national uniform scheme places the Parliament in an invidious position. If it amends a piece of legislation forming part of the scheme, or rejects such a piece of legislation, it may bring the scheme to an end. If, on the other hand, it fails to amend or reject such legislation, however compelling the grounds for action, it may be said, in effect, to have delegated its legislative power to the Ministerial Council without even retaining the equivalent of a power of disallowance. Indeed, to the extent that it is possible for parliamentary amendments to be taken back to the Ministerial Council for approval, it may be said that it is the Ministerial Council which has a power of veto over the legislative action of the Parliament.

Despite these defects, the national uniform scheme might be defensible if it had in fact resulted in the uniformity of company law throughout Australia. However, one of the main criticisms made in submissions to the constitutional and Legal Affairs Committee from lawyers, the Confederation of Australian Industry and the Business Council of Australia was that the administration of the scheme by the NCSC and the seven autonomous State and Territory corporate affairs commissions had led to inconsistency in the application of the law. For example, the NCSC might advise as to the contents required in a prospectus in certain circumstances, but this advice could be contradicted by the State CAC when the prospectus is lodged. The recommendation of the Constitutional and Legal Affairs Committee that the Commonwealth Parliament should enact comprehensive legislation covering the field currently regulated by the co-operative scheme is represented as the next step in a natural progression. The co-operative scheme has outlived its usefulness. The doubts which surround the Commonwealth's legislative power in relation to companies at the time the scheme was developed have now been dispelled. Sir Maurice Byers, QC, the former Commonwealth Solicitor-General, says that the Commonwealth has the power to regulate the whole range of corporate activities, from incorporation through to dissolution, in respect of all companies other than recreational, scientific, educational and charitable companies, where trading or commercial activities do not form a significant part of those companies' operations. Very few companies would fall into this category.

Australia now has a national stock exchange, and its financial institutions increasingly operate not only at a national level but also at the international level. It is important that investors should have confidence in our share market and futures and securities industries. It is also important that unnecessary costs should not be imposed on business through differences in legislation or its interpretation. I therefore welcome the recommendation of the Constitutional and Legal Affairs Committee in favour of national legislation.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to raise an issue in terms of this Bill which is directed at the establishment of a better statistical base. I preface the item by giving some statistics. In every 1,000 live births in Australia the infant mortality rate for the white population is 9.6 but for the Aboriginal population it is 30.8. I raise this item because of some discussion at Question Time today and on other occasions about some grants that have been mentioned by the Opposition's Waste Watch Committee. In particular, I refer to those grants which have been provided under the community health program to the Nursing Mothers Association of Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: The grant that has been mentioned in headlines in the Press, attacking its expenditure as a total waste of money, was provided to Aboriginal women to enable them to become counsellors on breast feeding within their communities. It is a most extraordinary type of attack for two reasons. The first is that hopefully we are aware of those types of statistics that I have just mentioned. I hope that the Australian Institute of Health, after its establishment, will be able to clarify them in greater detail than we have had to date. It is worth noting that breast feeding is one of the most efficient means of preventive medicine in Australia with regard to infant deaths. It is extraordinary that anybody should be attacking those grants. We know very well that multinational companies have promoted the use of artificial products for the feeding of young children and that they have made millions of dollars from this exercise. They have taken large numbers of Aboriginal women away from breast feeding and have encouraged them to use bottles. We know that, as a result of this exercise, there have been not hundreds but thousands of deaths in Australia and in many other countries where similar proceedings have taken place.

It is extraordinary that this attack should be made in Australia today when the Government has ceased providing funds under the community health program to the Nursing Mothers Association. It had received to date $70,000 to help it with its training of counsellors around Australia. It has 1,500 counsellors who, in the last year, counselled some 250,000 women over the phone about problems that they had with children. This is a very emotional issue for me. My wife is a Nursing Mothers Association counsellor. I know that she has spent many hours on the phone talking to women, some of whom have battered their children. She has often got off the phone in tears. This type of work is being done on a voluntary basis-sometimes up to 30 hours a week-by these women to help other women in the community in an area of social development that we seem to neglect. Our changing society has made it very difficult for women with young children, often because there is very little support for them in the community. Often, because of the changing nature of society, a child's mother might have long since ceased having children so he or she does not have sisters around, as was the case previously, to assist in those early months which are extremely trying.

We know that there is a rising incidence of battered children; we know the statistics for Aboriginal children; we know the value of this area of preventive medicine; and we know the value of women supporting other women. Yet this area is attacked both by the Opposition's Waste Watch Committee and by the Government. The Government is taking away the $70,000-a meagre amount of money-which would have assisted the training of those people. Indeed, if only one in 10 of those women went to a doctor instead of a voluntary counsellor, the cost to Medicare would be $600,000. This is an absolutely absurd proposition-to take away $70,000, yet at the same time to cost the taxpayer $600,000. Why has this been done? Because preventive medicine cannot be seen. We are stopping something and we would much prefer to spend the money on sick children than on stopping children in our community from being sick. That is basically the result of both these propositions. I hope that with the establishment of the Institute it will provide the Government with some better statistics for policy making than it had from the Department on this single item. Appalling advice was given to the Government and it took that advice. That advice will, without a doubt, lead directly to the deaths of children in Australia.

We know that there has been a big growth in the numbers of battered children and there are very few places that women can go. It is important that women should have the ability to get on the telephone and talk to other women who have young children; to be able to relieve tension in those circumstances; to get good advice which will help them over that incredibly difficult period; and hopefully to take their children along to a medical practitioner so that they and their children can be counselled properly in a less stressful situation. But the Government was quite happy to accept the advice-and we know where it came from within the Department-to lop off $70,000. That decision will cost the Government and the revenue money and it will cost young Australian lives. That is the type of decision that this Government is quite happy to make. It is also the kind of decision that the Waste Watch Committee is happy to support because it does not agree with providing money for such worthwhile activities.

DEBATE.TITLE: SUGAR CANE LEVY BILL 1987SUGAR CANE LEVY COLLECTION BILL 1987

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 7 May, on motion by Senator Gareth Evans:
That the Bills be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Sugar Cane Levy Bill 1987 and the Sugar Cane Levy Collection Bill 1987 provide for the establishment of a better-funded and co-ordinated research program for the sugar industry in line with similar reforms in most other primary industries. The industry contribution, which will be matched on a dollar for dollar basis by the Commonwealth, will be levied on both millers and growers at an initial rate of 5c per tonne with a provision for the rate to be varied to as much as 10c per tonne eventually. The sugar industry supports the measure and the short to medium term outlook for the industry is much brighter than the gloomy and dire predictions indicated as little as two years ago. The National Agricultural Outlook Conference earlier this year was told by the Bureau of Agricultural Economics that there would be a gradual improvement in world sugar prices. The principal reason for this is the gradual reduction of the sugar stockpile which has been depressing sugar prices for some years. The lower sugar stocks, complemented by increased demand, have boosted the international price from a low of US2.6c per pound to about US7.78c a pound two or three months ago. It remains roughly at that level.

SPEECH.PARA: The Soviet Union has increased its sugar imports and this year it will buy five million tonnes, partly as a result of a campaign to encourage Soviet people to drink soft drinks instead of vodka. The Australian sugar industry recently sold 180,000 tonnes of sugar to the Soviet Union and that has certainly taken the pressure off our export market. Consumption and imports of sugar are also rising in Brazil which itself is a major producer. Sugar is being imported by Brazil to produce the motor spirit gasahol. The Brazilians have done a lot of work on this and it has now become a major source of fuel for motor vehicles.

The No. 1 pool price for 1986-87 is expected to increase by 21 per cent to $270 per tonne and by 1987-88 it is expected that the price will rise as high as $345. In contrast only a couple of years ago that price was down to as little as $222 or $223 a tonne. Australian cane sugar exports rose by almost 54,000 tonnes to 2.58 million tonnes in the 1986 calendar year. The principal markets were Canada, Japan, Malaysia, Korea, New Zealand and Singapore. It is indicative of the better outlook for the sugar industry that Bundaberg Sugar announced that it had a profit lift of 20 per cent to $6.5m for the year ended 30 April 1987. A similar rise has been forecast by the Pioneer Sugar Mill as well. This shows us that there may be an improvement on the way but it does not release us from the necessity to improve our research. We cannot be complacent. World prices are expected to peak in the next five years and we could then be in for another period of low prices beyond that again. This factor highlights the need for the industry to continue its economic marketing and technical research so as to maintain Australia's competitive edge in the world sweetener market. There are a couple of examples which I believe are important to show areas in which research is having some effect. The Bureau of Sugar Experimental Stations, one of the three organisations currently conducting research into the sugar industry, is doing a great deal of work in this area. The first example I give is the recent work on harvester design where it is expected that an improvement in cane losses will save the industry as much as $20m a year in terms of a better harvest. The second major area of research is in the improvement of cane varieties. These Bills should lead to an increase in the amount of funds available for research by the sugar industry.

Ultimately the long term health of our sugar industry will depend on the dismantling of subsidised production and subsidies in other areas, and hopefully will reduce production controls and trade barriers in the world market. As with most other commodities, the only solution to price instability appears to lie in multilateral reform of the commodity trading system. While foreign governments continue to support domestic sugar prices and tightly control markets, there is little hope of stabilising the world price. If governments in the major trading nations stopped shielding producers from the world price, the change of prices slumping to disastrous levels such as existed in 1985 could be avoided. Under current circumstances, the world price is estimated to drop below US4c about one year in 20. If only 4 per cent more of the world's producers were exposed to the world market, the world price would drop below US4c only about one year in a hundred. Australia's sugar industry is extremely sensitive to world prices. If appropriate policy reforms can be achieved through the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade multilateral trade negotiations, low cost efficient countries like Australia could expand their shares of the world market. The Opposition supports the legislation and wishes it a speedy passage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Sugar is one of Australia's major exports. It is and has been for a long time a mainstay of our agricultural exporting effort. In terms of the domestic sugar price which arose out of the agreement between Queensland and the Commonwealth over 40 years ago, Australia has had a reasonably low domestic sugar price funded and subsidised very heavily by the more often than not high export price that was able to be gained by an efficient industry on the world market. The world sugar industry, whether based on beet or cane sugar as in Australia, involves almost every country. Over 100 countries engage in significant sugar production. Sugar is susceptible to a whole variety of problems such as the weather, particularly as a large amount of sugar is grown in countries which periodically suffer from cyclones, lack of monsoons, typhoons. Therefore, the sugar industry tends to fluctuate in the amount produced. However, in recent years the production of beet sugar, particularly in the European Economic Community, the growth of beet and cane sugar in the United States of America, has meant a stabilisation of production, certainly in the free market. A large amount of sugar is traded in the world within a closed structure in the COMECON countries and it is difficult to work out what precisely is occurring there. One of those countries, the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics, is a major importer of sugar from the free market and hence there is an interrelationship between those two markets.

SPEECH.PARA: Current world sugar production is around 100 million tonnes, and it has been coming up to that point for some years. Consumption of sugar world wide is also expanding, which in Australia at least may seem odd. Despite the rising levels of other types of sweetener, sugar is still the dominant sweetener in the world. When one looks, for example, at most industrialised countries, one finds in recent years a levelling out of demand. This can probably be attributed not only to the growth of those sweeteners, particularly in the United States market of the corn-derived sweeteners, but also to changing dietary habits. That occurs very largely because foods which previously used to be processed using sugar are now often processed without using sugar. In contrast-and this is the reason why the consumption of sugar world wide is still growing-we have a growing market in developing countries. That seems to have more than balanced the decline in the developed countries. Most countries produce some sugar and about 75 per cent of the total world production is consumed within the country in which it is grown. This means that only about 25 per cent of the total sugar grown in the world is part of the sugar trade between countries. Australia is dominantly dependent on exports. In fact, we export 80 per cent of our sugar. That puts us at the top of the league in the percentage of sugar exported.

It is important to look at the position world wide because there are some worrying factors on the horizon for Australia. Tonight I shall refer to only one such item and that is the United States. By concentrating my remarks on the United States I do not mean to neglect the fact that the European Community went from being a net importer to become a net exporter. I do not wish to understate the destabilising role which the EEC has already played in the world sugar market. In fact, it probably more than most led to the collapse of the international sugar agreement by its aggressive tactics of selling subsidised sugar. The concern I wish to point to is the dominant role that is played in many ways by the United States in the world sugar market. Despite the fact that the United States does not export sugar, it is still the dominant force. Before 1980 the United States was one of the world's three largest consumers of sugar with an annual demand of about 10 million tonnes-an extraordinary figure for one country when one considers the total world sugar market. It is the world's largest net importer of sugar-in terms of the world free trade, it was by far the largest net importer. Thus, actions by the United States in that market in 1980 could be seen to affect the total world market. In fact, that did happen. By 1985, in five short years, United States net imports had more than halved and imports by the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics, China and Japan exceeded those of the United States. That is a massive turn around. In fact, we felt it very badly here in Australia. It was one of the major contributing factors to the collapse of the world price and to the devastion of the Queensland sugar industry. It has led directly to a number of measures that the Government has had to take in this area, not the least of which is the legislation before us.

In that period United States consumption fell by 27 per cent and United States net imports fell by 54 per cent. Most of the decline occurred in the four years between the enactment of the Agricultural and Food Act of 1981 and 1985. In that four-year period United States consumption fell by 19 per cent and net imports by 48 per cent. The principal reason for the dramatic decline in consumption within the United States has to be the United States sugar support program. Under this program, in order to provide high support levels for the domestic sugar producers-the very opposite of the Australian domestic sugar price agreement, which provided low levels-United States consumers have paid high domestic sugar prices and so did not really experience the benefit of the low world sugar prices that prevailed after 1983. Sugar consumption declined while the price umbrella put in place by those types of support mechanisms allowed alternative sweeteners-particularly, of course, the high fructose corn syrup derivatives-to make enormous inroads into the United States sugar industry. As sugar consumption contracted, the quantity of imports also declined. Foreign suppliers to the United States market, who hold quotas under the sugar program, have therefore borne the full impact of the program on consumption by having their import quotas progressively reduced.

This is a problem with which we in Australia are now faced. Our problem is trying to predict where the United States sugar industry is likely to go from here. I give some figures to show the dramatic operation that we are involved in. We are looking at the production costs and at such items as the average world price for sugar. In 1985 this was 4c a pound as against the United States domestic raw sugar price of 20.3c a pound. From this, I think one can see that the type of support provided through the United States agricultural support system, as a result of the 1981 Act, has made an enormous differential and has led to increasing problems. Not only has there been that effect but also acreages planted and harvested for sugar production have increased since the beginning of the sugar program. The acreages as of 1986 are 16 per cent higher for beet and 7 per cent higher for cane than those planted in 1982, which reflects the high level of price support available and the incentive now within the market in the United States to proceed with the sugar industry.

It is probably anybody's guess where we go from here. A very good case can be made out for the proposition that we are looking at the possible reduction of Australia's market within the United States, with a progressive move to zero. The current year's exports look like being about 70,000 tonnes, down from the extraordinarily high levels that we were exporting just a short four years ago. That drop to zero is probably something that the Australian sugar industry, in terms of its current restructuring, could just bear. However, I point to an even more worrying proposition-one which is hedged about by some ifs and buts, but a reasonable one-that is, that the United States will move relatively rapidly to exporting sugar on to the free market. That is an incredibly worrying proposition. The reason it is worrying is that, if the move by the United States follows the type of move that we saw in the European Economic Community, the Australian sugar industry, rather than being able to look forward to a recovery of world prices-to which I think Senator Archer pointed in the more optimistic scenario that he was painting-is possibly on the verge of another devastating blow because of its dependence on exports. If the United States goes into the world market as an exporter, it will do so with enormous support potential.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thirty-five billion dollars worth.

—Yes, from that process that occurs within the United States that not only defies fiscal imagination but defies almost any imagination, considering that we are looking at upwards of $35 billion. As last year's all-party trade delegation was informed, Congress did not even know what the upper limit might be. But, even at $35 billion, we are looking at half of Australia's Budget being spent within the United States for just agricultural support. Of course, as the operation of the United States domestic sugar program proceeds, and we find an extension of growing, the United States may be looking at means of exporting that sugar in some form or another on to markets that Australia has supplied up to now.

SPEECH.PARA: Australia is one of the four largest sugar exporters in the world. In fact, those four exporters collectively account for 60 per cent of the world's free market exports this year. We are part of the group that will feel the brunt the hardest, despite the fact that Australia is one of the most cost efficient of the world's sugar producers. In 1982 Australia held an 8.3 per cent share of that dominant market in the United States and in 1981, prior to the imposition of quotas, we were exporting 800,000 tonnes to that country. That compares, as I said before, with the possibility of 70,000 tonnes next year. That is an enormous drop to bear in such a short period. The quota decline has greatly added to the hardships that have been experienced by Australia's producers and America's policies have been a large contributor to this situation.

Unlike the United States and EEC sugar producers, who have access to large domestic markets and long term support policies, Australian producers have not been subsidised through any extensive support schemes. I think that point ought to be emphasised. A history of the sugar market in Australia since the late 1930s shows that there has really been a subsidy going the other way. The sugar producers have subsidised the Australian community by means of the acceptance of a guaranteed price scheme, based on the domestic sugar price agreement which in most years was able to provide a low sugar price for Australia, propped up by a high export price. Hence, a reasonable return was given to the producers. One must acknowledge that that low price-which, of course, fed through to low processed food prices-was a subsidy from the industry. In times such as these, in difficult restructuring times for the sugar industry, I think it is reasonable for the sugar industry to seek some support in return.

The United States and EEC sugar policies of internal subsidy are not seeking to create a competitive environment; in fact, they are seeking to create exactly the opposite. They seek, ultimately, to depress the world price, to drive a whole range of countries out of the market. Many of those countries, of course, are developing countries that depend extremely heavily, in terms of their ability to trade, on their exports. Australia, while it is a developed country, is very much, of course, dependent on its agricultural exports, of which sugar is a major item. What we are now seeing in the predatory policies of the United States and the EEC is a further attack which, in relation to my State of Queensland, will devastate our regional economies.

Unfortunately, it is not well known in other parts of Australia that Queensland, as a decentralised State, has been heavily dependent, in supporting that decentralisation, on having a regional economy-an economy which is not based totally on the capital city but which is self-supporting and income generating for the community and for the country. If one heads north from Brisbane one finds that a large number of the coastal towns, from not very far north of Brisbane to the farthest coastal towns-with a couple of notable exceptions, such as Rockhampton and Gladstone-are heavily dependent on the sugar industry. Those communities will have devastating economic problems.

Senator Archer raised the other matter that I wish to refer to before I complete my remarks-that is, the need within the industry to continue and to promote research. Of course, these Bills seek to produce the wherewithal to enable that to proceed apace. Research is absolutely vital not only in terms of the quality and quantity of sugar that can be produced from an acre, and greater efficiency of production, but also, I suggest, in terms of alternative uses for sugar products. Unfortunately, in times of high export prices there is very little incentive to go down that track. We must go down that track now. Indeed, there are a number of commercial ventures under way. Some are based in companies, others are based on research undertaken by universities in Queensland and others are based on the work being done by the sugar experimental stations. These ventures are looking for alternative uses. Of course, we know of a number; but what we must look at, of course, is not simply alternative uses but economic alternative uses. We can name any number of alternative uses for sugar at the moment. We can look at ethanol production, biomass and high fructose experiments. There is a range of possibilities in that area. We need to make sure that they are economic possibilities and not simply further drains on the economy.

I believe that there are some very exciting possibilities in that area. The combining, for example, of the biomass and the high fructose processes in a single process will obviously be an economic venture. DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Report on the Redevelopment of Migrant Accommodation Facilities, Wacol, Queensland

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Foreman Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —In accordance with the provisions of the Public Works Committee Act, I present the report relating to the redevelopment of migrant accommodation facilities, Wacol, Queensland.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to make a statement and to incorporate it in Hansard.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The statement read as follows-

The Committee believes that a need exists to reduce migrant centre costs, while maintaining the level of support services required. The proposed conversion of accommodation units to self-contained, self-catering units should assist in refugees remaining at migrant centres for longer periods than at present.

The Committee recommends that the concept of self-contained, self-catering accommodation should be adopted for migrant centres throughout Australia, subject to the satisfactory evaluation of the Penington Centre in South Australia. The Committee also recommends that the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs take follow-up action on how to address the wider issues involved in the premature departure of refugees from migrant centres.

Although redevelopment of the present site is cheaper in capital cost and in long-term operating costs than the alternatives considered by the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, the Committee is not convinced that Wacol is the best location for the migrant centre. A site closer to public transport and community facilities may be more conducive to refugees staying at Wacol for longer periods of time.

The Committee recommends that the project should not proceed at Wacol and that the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs further investigate sites closer to public transport and facilities as possible alternatives.

The Committee is concerned over the redundancy of the 5-year old kitchen/dining facility. The Committee believes that it may be premature to convert this facility to other uses before the new concept has been fully tested.
The Committee recommends that further consideration be given to the future use of the kitchen/dining facility.
